b'Security Policy
***
If an end-user discovers a vulnerability in the update_full-unix script, it can be reported to:
< tangier_commiters@simplelogin.com >

When disclosing a security vulnerability, please write everything into the text of the email.
I WILL NOT LOOK AT EMAILS WITH ATTACHMENTS!
Please do not send any security notifications regarding any of package managers used.
I cannot control anything of any package manager.
Make sure that the security vulnerabilities are about the script itself.
'

b'# Reporting security vulnerabilities

Oracle values the independent security research community and believes that
responsible disclosure of security vulnerabilities helps us ensure the security
and privacy of all our users.

Please do NOT raise a GitHub Issue to report a security vulnerability. If you
believe you have found a security vulnerability, please submit a report to
[secalert_us@oracle.com][1] preferably with a proof of concept. Please review
some additional information on [how to report security vulnerabilities to Oracle][2].
We encourage people who contact Oracle Security to use email encryption using
[our encryption key][3].

We ask that you do not use other channels or contact the project maintainers
directly.

Non-vulnerability related security issues including ideas for new or improved
security features are welcome on GitHub Issues.

## Security updates, alerts and bulletins

Security updates will be released on a regular cadence. Many of our projects
will typically release security fixes in conjunction with the
[Oracle Critical Patch Update][3] program. Additional
information, including past advisories, is available on our [security alerts][4]
page.

## Security-related information

We will provide security related information such as a threat model, considerations
for secure use, or any known security issues in our documentation. Please note
that labs and sample code are intended to demonstrate a concept and may not be
sufficiently hardened for production use.

[1]: mailto:secalert_us@oracle.com
[2]: https://www.oracle.com/corporate/security-practices/assurance/vulnerability/reporting.html
[3]: https://www.oracle.com/security-alerts/encryptionkey.html
[4]: https://www.oracle.com/security-alerts/
'

b'# Security Considerations

Tribuo is a library designed to be incorporated into larger programs.
Therefore, we consider the trust boundary to live somewhere outside of Tribuo
in the larger program. While we provide data loaders, we expect them to be used
on trusted or cleaned data. We expect that the larger program will control
access to Tribuo's interfaces. Tribuo's data loaders and other interfaces
perform defensive copying and other standard procedures when user code crosses
over into Tribuo's internals. For performance reasons, however, this defensive
behavior is not generally the case for calls within Tribuo (e.g., the linear
algebra library exposes mutable state to reduce copying).

## Serialized files
Tribuo models are stored as Java serialized objects. Due to the inherent issues
with Java serialization, these object files should only be loaded and saved to
trusted locations where third parties do not have access. We have provided a
[JEP 290](https://openjdk.java.net/jeps/290) [filter](jep-290-filter.txt)
which will allow the deserialization of only the classes found in the Tribuo
library. This filter should be enabled on the code paths which deserialize
models or datasets. As Tribuo supports Java 8+, and JEP 290 is an addition to
the Java 8 API from 8u121, the best way to use the filter for the main 
programs provided with Tribuo is by setting it as a process-wide flag.  
Additionally, when running with a security manager, Tribuo will need access to
the relevant filesystem locations to load or save model files. See the section 
on [Configuration](#Configuration) for more details.

In Tribuo 4.3 we introduced protobuf based serialization for all supported Java
serializable types. This is the preferred serialization mechanism, and Java
serialization support will be removed in the next major release of Tribuo.

## Database access
Tribuo provides a SQL interface that can load data via a JDBC connection. As
it's frequently necessary to load data via a joined query from an unknown
schema, Tribuo *does not* validate the input SQL. It is expected that the
program developer will perform this validation since they know the schema from
which they are loading. Tribuo supports connections via public key wallets via
JDBC. To use this functionality, supply the wallet configuration to the JVM as
a system property and use the constructors that accept a java.util.Properties
instance with the appropriate configuration.

## Native code
Tribuo uses several native libraries via JNI interfaces. Native code has
different considerations as compared to pure Java code because native code can
cause issues in the running JVM. We are active contributors to all the native
ML libraries that Tribuo uses, and we fix issues upstream if we find them.
Nevertheless, you should think carefully before running a model that requires
native code inside an application container like a JavaEE or JakartaEE server.
Multiple instances of Tribuo running inside separate containers may cause
issues with JNI library loading due to ClassLoader security considerations.

## SecurityManager configuration
Tribuo uses [OLCUT](https://github.com/oracle/olcut)'s configuration and
provenance systems, which use reflection to construct and inspect classes.
Therefore, when running with a Java security manager, you need to give the
OLCUT jar appropriate permissions. We have tested this set of permissions,
which allows the configuration and provenance systems to work:

    // OLCUT permissions
    grant codeBase "file:/path/to/olcut/olcut-core-5.2.0.jar" {
            permission java.lang.RuntimePermission "accessDeclaredMembers";
            permission java.lang.reflect.ReflectPermission "suppressAccessChecks";
            permission java.util.logging.LoggingPermission "control";
            permission java.io.FilePermission "<<ALL FILES>>", "read";
            permission java.util.PropertyPermission "*", "read,write";
    };

The read FilePermission can be restricted to the jars which contain
configuration files, configuration files on disk, and the locations of
serialised objects. The FilePermission in this example provides access to the
complete filesystem because the necessary read locations are program specific.
This scope should be narrowed based on your requirements. If you need to save
an OLCUT configuration, you will also need to add write permissions for the
save location.

Tribuo uses `ForkJoinPool` for parallelism, which requires the `modifyThread`
and `modifyThreadGroup` privileges when running under a `java.lang.SecurityManager`.
Therefore classes which have parallel execution inside will require those
permissions in addition to the ones listed for OLCUT above.

File read and write permissions are necessary for Tribuo to be able to
load and save models; therefore, you'll need to grant Tribuo those permissions
using a similar snippet when running with a security manager.

## Threat Model
As a library incorporated into other programs, Tribuo expects it's inputs to be
checked by the wider program; however, there are threats which are specific to
ML systems that can result in model or data leakage.

| Threat | Description | Exposed Assets | Possible Mitigations |
| ------ | ----------- | -------------- | -------------------- |
| Model replication | If an attacker can repeatedly query the model, where they either know or control the features, and they can observe the full prediction (e.g., the complete predicted probability distribution) for each query, then this can provide sufficient information for them to replicate the model.  If the model is considered an important asset, allowing an attacker to copy it could be detrimental. | The model parameters | Only return a small number of predictions (i.e., the top n) or do not provide the probability distribution. This slows down the attack, but does not completely prevent it. Other mitigations such as employing rate limiting or preventing the attacker from controlling or observing the feature inputs are necessary to fully prevent this attack.|
| Training metadata leak | The model file contains information about the training data such as the feature names, number of features, and number of examples. This information is potentially sensitive, as in the case of bigrams or trigrams from text. | Training metadata | Firstly, treat model files as confidential if the data itself is confidential. Secondly, use Tribuo's methods for one-way hashing of the feature names. Hashing prevents attackers from trivially discovering the features without needing to complete the process of supplying the input text and testing if the model output changes. Thirdly, other information present in the model file, such as the number of examples, can be redacted by removing the provenance information before the model is deployed. | 
| Training data leak | If an attacker can repeatedly query the model, it's possible for an attacker to find specific training data points that are part of the training data set. This attack is accomplished by measuring the confidence of the prediction (as training data points usually have a predicted confidence close to 1.0). | Training data | The most important mitigation is to treat model files as confidential if the training data is confidential. Once access to the model has been prevented, the mitigations for model replication apply. This attack is a variant of model replication that usually requires some foreknowledge of the identity of the training corpus. |


'

b'# Security Policy

We take security seriously at MyIntro. We appreciate any efforts to improve the security of our project, and we are committed to addressing security issues in a timely and responsible manner.

## Reporting a Vulnerability

If you believe you have discovered a security vulnerability in our project, please report it to us as soon as possible. You can report security vulnerabilities by contacting DeveloperCron though discord/twitter.

Please include the following information in your report:

- A description of the vulnerability
- Steps to reproduce the vulnerability
- Any other relevant information that could help us
  address the issue

## Expectations

When reporting a security vulnerability, we ask that you:

Do not publicly disclose the vulnerability until we have had a chance to address it.
Do not exploit the vulnerability in any way beyond what is necessary to demonstrate the vulnerability.
Do not modify or delete any data on our system.

## Response

We will acknowledge your report within 48 hours and provide an estimated timeframe for addressing the vulnerability. We will also keep you informed of our progress and any necessary steps you need to take during the process.

## Rewards

We believe in acknowledging the efforts of security researchers who help us improve the security of our project. If you report a security vulnerability to us, we will consider providing a reward or recognition for your efforts, at our discretion.

Thank you for helping us keep our project secure!
'

b'# Security Policy

## Supported Versions

Typically, only the latest released version is supported for patches - if a major issue appears, old ones will be considered for patching, or yanked.

## Reporting a Vulnerability

Please contact me via email at james+renamer@terminaloutcomes.com'

b"---
Title: 'Security Testing'
Description: 'Security testing is a critical aspect of the software development life cycle that helps protect systems and applications from potential security threats.'
Subjects:
  - 'Cybersecurity'
Tags:
  - 'Cybersecurity'
  - 'Ethical Hacking'
  - 'Infrastructure'
CatalogContent:
  - 'learn-security-testing'
  - 'paths/cybersecurity'
---

**Security testing** is a critical aspect of software development that helps protect systems and applications from potential security threats.

- It examines security, discovers weaknesses, and confirms compliance with industry standards and regulations.
- With growing cyber attacks and data breaches, security testing is crucial to ensure the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of sensitive data.

There are three main methods for security testing:

- Black Box Testing
  - This approach to security testing evaluates a system or application without knowledge of its internal structure or implementation details. Black box testing focuses on functional requirements and the user interface, and can be used to identify security vulnerabilities that an attacker would exploit.
- White Box Testing
  - This approach to security testing evaluates a system or application with knowledge of its internal structure and implementation details. White box testing focuses on code-level security, including input validation, error handling, and access controls.
- Gray Box Testing
  - This approach to security testing combines elements of both black box and white box testing. Gray box testing provides some knowledge of the internal structure of a system or application, but not a complete understanding. This type of testing is useful for identifying security vulnerabilities that would be missed by black box testing but may not be as comprehensive as white box testing.

### Additional Domains and Elements of Security Testing

- Vulnerability assessment: This is the process of identifying, classifying, and prioritizing vulnerabilities in a system or application. Vulnerability assessments can be performed manually or with automated tools.
- Penetration Testing: This type of testing simulates an attack on a system or application to identify security weaknesses and vulnerabilities. Penetration testing is usually performed by ethical hackers, who use the same tools and techniques as malicious hackers to identify potential security issues.
- Network Security Testing: This type of testing focuses on the security of a network infrastructure, including firewalls, routers, and switches. Network security testing can identify vulnerabilities in network configurations and help prevent unauthorized access, data theft, and other security threats.
- Application Security Testing: This type of testing focuses on the security of individual applications, including web applications, mobile apps, and desktop applications. Application security testing can identify vulnerabilities in the code, architecture, and deployment of an application.
- Database Security Testing: This type of testing focuses on the security of databases and the sensitive data they contain. Database security testing can identify vulnerabilities in database configurations, access controls, data encryption, and help prevent unauthorized access to sensitive data.
- Infrastructure Security Testing: This type of testing focuses on the security of an organization's infrastructure, including servers, storage devices, and other components that make up the backbone of an organization's IT environment. Infrastructure security testing can identify vulnerabilities in the configuration and deployment of infrastructure components.
- Threat modeling: This is a process of identifying potential security threats to a system or application and determining the likelihood and impact of each threat. Threat modeling helps prioritize security testing efforts and identify areas that need improvement.
- Compliance Testing: This type of testing verifies that a system or application complies with industry regulations and standards, such as PCI DSS, HIPAA, or ISO 27001. Compliance testing helps ensure that an organization's security practices meet the requirements of regulatory bodies and help prevent legal and financial consequences.
- Remediation: After security weaknesses are identified during testing, remediation involves fixing the vulnerabilities and implementing security controls to prevent similar issues in the future.
- Maintenance: Security testing should be an ongoing process to ensure the continued security of a system or application. Regular security testing, vulnerability assessments, and remediation are essential to maintaining the security of a system or application over time.
"

b'# Security Policy

## Supported Versions

We support the latest version of Folder Directory Tree Generator and the previous major version.

## Reporting a Vulnerability

If you discover a security vulnerability in Folder Directory Tree Generator, please contact us at [INSERT CONTACT EMAIL]. We take security issues very seriously and will respond promptly to fix confirmed vulnerabilities.

Please do not publicly disclose the vulnerability until it has been resolved by our team.

## Vulnerability Response

Our team will investigate reported vulnerabilities and provide a timeline for fixing the issue. We will keep the reporter updated on our progress and coordinate the disclosure of the vulnerability.

## End of Life Policy

When a version of Folder Directory Tree Generator reaches end of life, we will no longer provide support or security updates for that version.

## License

This project is licensed under the [MIT License](https://opensource.org/licenses/MIT).
'

b'---
title: "Handling security validations"
date: 2020-06-30T08:55:00-05:00
draft: false
weight: 14
description: "Why am I seeing these security warnings?"
---

> After applying the July2021 PSU, I'm now seeing security warnings, such as:
>
> Description: Production Mode is enabled but user lockout settings are not secure in realm: myrealm, i.e. LockoutThreshold should not be greater than 5, LockoutDuration should not be less than 30.
>
> SOLUTION: Update the user lockout settings (LockoutThreshold, LockoutDuration) to be secure.

WebLogic Server has a new, important feature to ensure and help you secure your WLS domains when running in production. With the July 2021 PSU applied, WebLogic Server regularly validates your domain configuration settings against a set of security configuration guidelines to determine whether the domain meets key security guidelines recommended by Oracle. For more information and additional details, see [MOS Doc 2788605.1](https://support.oracle.com/rs?type=doc&id=2788605.1) "WebLogic Server Security Warnings Displayed Through the Admin Console" and [Review Potential Security Issues](https://docs.oracle.com/en/middleware/fusion-middleware/weblogic-server/12.2.1.4/lockd/secure.html#GUID-4148D1BE-2D54-4DA5-8E94-A35D48DCEF1D) in _Securing a Production Environment for Oracle WebLogic Server_.

Warnings may be at the level of the JDK, or that SSL is not enabled. Some warnings may recommend updating your WebLogic configuration. You can make the recommended configuration changes using an approach that depends on your [domain home source type]({{< relref "/managing-domains/choosing-a-model/_index.md" >}}):

- For Domain in PV, use the WebLogic Scripting Tool (WLST), WebLogic Server Administration Console, WebLogic Deploy Tooling (WDT), or [configuration overrides]({{< relref "/managing-domains/configoverrides/_index.md" >}}).

- For Domain in Image, create a new image with the recommended changes or use [configuration overrides]({{< relref "/managing-domains/configoverrides/_index.md" >}}).

- For Model in Image, supply model files with the recommended changes in its image's `modelHome` directory or use [runtime updates]({{< relref "/managing-domains/model-in-image/runtime-updates.md" >}}).


> Msg ID: 090985
>
> Description: Production Mode is enabled but the the file or directory /u01/oracle/user_projects/domains/domain/bin/setDomainEnv.sh is insecure since its permission is not a minimum of umask 027.
>
> SOLUTION: Change the file or directory permission to at most allow only write by owner, read by group.
>
> Description:  The file or directory SerializedSystemIni.dat is insecure since its permission is not a minimum of umask 027.
>
> SOLUTION: Change the file or directory permission to at most allow only write by owner, read by group.

When the [WebLogic Image Tool](https://oracle.github.io/weblogic-image-tool/) (WIT) creates a [Domain Home in Image]({{< relref "/managing-domains/choosing-a-model/_index.md" >}}), you can specify the `--target OpenShift` option so that when WIT creates the domain, it sets the correct permissions in the domain home. When no `--target` option is specified, then the domain home directory has a umask of 027.

{{% notice note %}}
For information about handling file permission warnings on the OpenShift Kubernetes Platform, see the [OpenShift]({{<relref "/security/openshift.md">}}) documentation.
{{% /notice %}}
'

b'
configuring SSH servers and clients

configuration file
/etc/ssh/sshd_config      (sshd -> the D means daemon)   man sshd_config
/etc/ssh/ssh_config       (this is the config file for client, no D)


/etc/ssh/sshd_config
  can change the port number
  can change the AddressFamily, this can change for ipv4, ipv6 or both (look at man page and search for Family)
  can change ListernAddress, so you can specify a IP addr to listen
  can change PermitRootLogin, this case you can login as a root using ssh service
  can change the PasswordAuthentication, this case choosen no, only ssh keys it will be possible to login
  can change the x11forwarding - start a remote app and forwarding to you local machine to interact
  
For example disable passwordauthentication global, but if you want do an exemption for an user add below PasswordAuthentication
Match User <username>
      PasswordAuthentication yes
      
After change need to reload to apply the new changes
sudo systemctl reload sshd.service


For the client we can add a file under ~/.ssh/config, change the permission chmod 600 config
inside this file we can add host with informations
  Host centos
        Hostname <IP>
        Port 22
        User <username>
 
 then you can use only ssh centos  to access the host/server
 
 To use ssh keys, generate keys in the client
 ssh-keygen
 
 then copy the public key to the server
 ssh-copy-id username@IP
 
 to remove fingerprint from a specific server saved in the known host
 ssh-keygen -R <IP>
 
 when you login using ssh, the client has some default config file
 /etc/ss/ssh_config
 this is not a good practice to make change in this file because future upgrade of the 
 ssh client it might overwrite the changes, better way is to modify in 
 /etc/ssh/ssh_config.d/<name_of_conf_file>
 then you can add new port, for example
 
 
 List and Identify SELinux file and process contexts ======================================================================
 
 linux kernel can be easily extended with so-called modules, one of them is SELinux that add variant advanced
 capabilities of restricting access
 SELinux is enable by defaut by centos 
 
 ls -Z
 drwxr-xr-x. devops devops unconfined_u:object_r:user_home_t:s0 Desktop
 
unconfined_u:object_r:user_home_t:s0   ->string is called SElabel or SElinux context
unconfined_u - user
object_r     - role
user_home_t  - type
s0           - level

only certain users can enter certains roles and certain types
lets authorized users and processes do their job, by grating the permissions they need
authorized users and processes are allowed to take only a limited set of actions
everything else is denied

ps axZ


to see the security context assigned to the current user. What got applied to our user when we logged in
you can use:
id -Z

when we log in the user we log in as is automatically map to an SELinux user
To see this mapping is done
sudo semanage login -l
sudo semanage user -l  ->group

to see the SELinux is actively restricting actions 
getenforce
the output it must be Enforcing
if is Disabled is not doing anything
if it is Permissive means it is allowing everything and locking actions that should have been restricted intead of denying



Change kernel runtime parameters, persistent and non-persistent ===========================================================

kernel runtime parameters is what the linux kernel does its job internally
 kernel deals with low level stop like allocating memory, handling network traffic and so on. Most of those settings involve
 those types of things.
 To see all kernel runtime parameters currently in use
 sudo sysctl -a
 
 to change the values, for example ipv6.
 sudo sysctl -w net.ipv6.conf.default.disable_ipv6=1
 this change is not persistent
 
 to make a change persistent
 /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
 
 to immediately set up the changes use
 sudo sysctl -p /etc/sysctl.d/<swap-less.conf>
 
 
 
 Restore default file contexts ==============================================================================================
 
 Using booleans values to modify settings of boot time, stop the boot process
 
 can add enforcing=0 ; this cause the system to boot into permissive mode for SELinux
  
  ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/57456345/218545692-50e026f4-6160-4db4-8238-73d68c8bad80.png)

  selinux=0 ; the kernel wont load anything to SELinux and the next time the system gets booted without that parameter
  it is going to force an auto relabel of the file system to get all the file context
  
  autorelabel=1 ; force an auto relabel

b'# Security Policy

## Supported Versions

Security updates will be provided to the latest live version of the website.

## Reporting a Vulnerability

To report a vulnerability, please email *security@[website-domain].info*
'

b'# Reporting security vulnerabilities

Oracle values the independent security research community and believes that
responsible disclosure of security vulnerabilities helps us ensure the security
and privacy of all our users.

Please do NOT raise a GitHub Issue to report a security vulnerability. If you
believe you have found a security vulnerability, please submit a report to
[secalert_us@oracle.com][1] preferably with a proof of concept. Please review
some additional information on [how to report security vulnerabilities to Oracle][2].
We encourage people who contact Oracle Security to use email encryption using
[our encryption key][3].

We ask that you do not use other channels or contact the project maintainers
directly.

Non-vulnerability related security issues including ideas for new or improved
security features are welcome on GitHub Issues.

## Security updates, alerts and bulletins

Security updates will be released on a regular cadence. Many of our projects
will typically release security fixes in conjunction with the
[Oracle Critical Patch Update][3] program. Additional
information, including past advisories, is available on our [security alerts][4]
page.

## Security-related information

We will provide security related information such as a threat model, considerations
for secure use, or any known security issues in our documentation. Please note
that labs and sample code are intended to demonstrate a concept and may not be
sufficiently hardened for production use.

[1]: mailto:secalert_us@oracle.com
[2]: https://www.oracle.com/corporate/security-practices/assurance/vulnerability/reporting.html
[3]: https://www.oracle.com/security-alerts/encryptionkey.html
[4]: https://www.oracle.com/security-alerts/
'

# [Spring Security] #2 \xec\x8a\xa4\xed\x94\x84\xeb\xa7\x81 \xec\x8b\x9c\xed\x81\x90\xeb\xa6\xac\xed\x8b\xb0 \xed\x94\x84\xeb\xa1\x9c\xec\xa0\x9d\xed\x8a\xb8 \xec\xa0\x81\xec\x9a\xa9\xed\x95\x98\xea\xb8\xb0

# 1. \xeb\xa1\x9c\xea\xb7\xb8\xec\x9d\xb8/\xeb\xa1\x9c\xea\xb7\xb8\xec\x95\x84\xec\x9b\x83
## 1) security-context.xml
`<security:intercept-url>` : \xed\x8a\xb9\xec\xa0\x95\xed\x95\x9c URI\xec\x97\x90 \xec\xa0\x91\xea\xb7\xbc\xed\x95\xa0 \xeb\x95\x8c \xec\x9d\xb8\xed\x84\xb0\xec\x85\x89\xed\x84\xb0\xeb\xa5\xbc \xec\x9d\xb4\xec\x9a\xa9\xed\x95\xb4\xec\x84\x9c \xec\xa0\x91\xea\xb7\xbc\xec\x9d\x84 \xec\xa0\x9c\xed\x95\x9c\xed\x95\x98\xeb\x8a\x94 \xec\x84\xa4\xec\xa0\x95
## 2) AccessDeniedHandler \xea\xb5\xac\xed\x98\x84 \xeb\xb0\xa9\xec\x8b\x9d
1. \xed\x8a\xb9\xec\xa0\x95\xed\x95\x9c uri \xec\xa7\x80\xec\xa0\x95
   - \xec\x82\xac\xec\x9a\xa9\xec\x9e\x90\xea\xb0\x80 \xec\xa0\x91\xea\xb7\xbc\xed\x96\x88\xeb\x8d\x98 uri \xec\x9e\x90\xec\xb2\xb4\xec\x9d\x98 \xeb\xb3\x80\xed\x99\x94\xeb\x8a\x94 \xec\x97\x86\xec\x9d\x8c.  
   ex) /admin uri\xeb\xa1\x9c \xec\xa0\x91\xea\xb7\xbc \xe2\x86\x92 \xec\xa7\x80\xec\xa0\x95\xed\x96\x88\xeb\x8d\x98 uri(\xec\x97\x90\xeb\x9f\xac\xed\x8e\x98\xec\x9d\xb4\xec\xa7\x80)\xec\x9d\x98 \xea\xb2\xb0\xea\xb3\xbc\xeb\xa7\x8c \xeb\xb3\xb4\xec\x9d\xb4\xea\xb3\xa0 uri\xeb\x8a\x94 /admin \xea\xb7\xb8\xeb\x8c\x80\xeb\xa1\x9c\xec\x9e\x84.
2. AccessDeniedHandler \xec\x9d\xb8\xed\x84\xb0\xed\x8e\x98\xec\x9d\xb4\xec\x8a\xa4\xec\x9d\x98 \xea\xb5\xac\xed\x98\x84\xec\xb2\xb4 \xec\xa7\x80\xec\xa0\x95
    - \xec\xa0\x91\xea\xb7\xbc \xec\xa0\x9c\xed\x95\x9c\xec\x9d\xb4 \xeb\x90\x9c \xea\xb2\xbd\xec\x9a\xb0\xec\x97\x90 \xeb\x8b\xa4\xec\x96\x91\xed\x95\x9c \xec\xb2\x98\xeb\xa6\xac\xeb\xa5\xbc \xed\x95\x98\xea\xb3\xa0 \xec\x8b\xb6\xec\x9d\x84 \xeb\x95\x8c \xec\x9d\xb8\xed\x84\xb0\xed\x8e\x98\xec\x9d\xb4\xec\x8a\xa4\xeb\xa5\xbc \xec\xa7\x81\xec\xa0\x91 \xea\xb5\xac\xed\x98\x84.  
    ex) \xec\xa0\x91\xea\xb7\xbc \xec\xa0\x9c\xed\x95\x9c\xec\x9d\xb4 \xeb\x90\x98\xec\x97\x88\xec\x9d\x84 \xeb\x95\x8c \xec\xbf\xa0\xed\x82\xa4\xeb\x82\x98 \xec\x84\xb8\xec\x85\x98\xec\x97\x90 \xed\x8a\xb9\xec\xa0\x95\xed\x95\x9c \xec\x9e\x91\xec\x97\x85\xec\x9d\x84 \xed\x95\x98\xea\xb1\xb0\xeb\x82\x98, HttpServletResponse\xec\x97\x90 \xed\x8a\xb9\xec\xa0\x95\xed\x95\x9c \xed\x97\xa4\xeb\x8d\x94 \xec\xa0\x95\xeb\xb3\xb4\xeb\xa5\xbc \xec\xb6\x94\xea\xb0\x80\xed\x95\x98\xeb\x8a\x94 \xeb\x93\xb1\xec\x9d\x98 \xed\x96\x89\xec\x9c\x84
    - `response.sendRedirect("/ycc/error/403");` : \xec\xa0\x91\xea\xb7\xbc \xec\xa0\x9c\xed\x95\x9c\xec\x97\x90 \xea\xb1\xb8\xeb\xa6\xac\xeb\x8a\x94 \xea\xb2\xbd\xec\x9a\xb0 \xeb\xa6\xac\xeb\x8b\xa4\xec\x9d\xb4\xeb\xa0\x89\xed\x8a\xb8 \xed\x95\x98\xeb\x8a\x94 \xeb\xb0\xa9\xec\x8b\x9d\xec\x9c\xbc\xeb\xa1\x9c \xeb\x8f\x99\xec\x9e\x91\xeb\x90\x98\xeb\x8a\x94\xeb\x8d\xb0, \xec\x9d\xb4 \xea\xb3\xbc\xec\xa0\x95\xec\x97\x90\xec\x84\x9c uri\xea\xb0\x80 \xeb\xb3\x80\xea\xb2\xbd\xeb\x90\x8c(/ycc/error/403)

## 3) CSRF(Cross-site request forgery) \xea\xb3\xb5\xea\xb2\xa9\xea\xb3\xbc \xed\x86\xa0\xed\x81\xb0
### 1. CSRF \xea\xb3\xb5\xea\xb2\xa9
   - CSRF \xea\xb3\xb5\xea\xb2\xa9 : \xec\x84\x9c\xeb\xb2\x84\xec\x97\x90\xec\x84\x9c \xeb\xb0\x9b\xec\x95\x84\xeb\x93\xa4\xec\x9d\xb4\xeb\x8a\x94 \xec\x9a\x94\xec\xb2\xad\xec\x9d\x84 \xed\x95\xb4\xec\x84\x9d\xed\x95\x98\xea\xb3\xa0 \xec\xb2\x98\xeb\xa6\xac\xed\x95\xa0 \xeb\x95\x8c \xec\x96\xb4\xeb\x96\xa4 \xec\xb6\x9c\xec\xb2\x98\xec\x97\x90\xec\x84\x9c \xed\x98\xb8\xec\xb6\x9c\xec\x9d\xb4 \xec\xa7\x84\xed\x96\x89\xeb\x90\x98\xec\x97\x88\xeb\x8a\x94\xec\xa7\x80 \xeb\x94\xb0\xec\xa7\x80\xec\xa7\x80 \xec\x95\x8a\xea\xb8\xb0 \xeb\x95\x8c\xeb\xac\xb8\xec\x97\x90 \xec\x83\x9d\xea\xb8\xb0\xeb\x8a\x94 \xed\x97\x88\xec\xa0\x90\xec\x9d\x84 \xeb\x85\xb8\xeb\xa6\xac\xeb\x8a\x94 \xea\xb3\xb5\xea\xb2\xa9 \xeb\xb0\xa9\xec\x8b\x9d = \xec\x82\xac\xec\x9d\xb4\xed\x8a\xb8\xea\xb0\x84 \xec\x9a\x94\xec\xb2\xad \xec\x9c\x84\xec\xa1\xb0.    
   ex) \xec\x9d\xb4\xeb\xa9\x94\xec\x9d\xbc\xec\x97\x90 \xec\xb2\xa8\xeb\xb6\x80\xeb\x90\x9c \xeb\xa7\x81\xed\x81\xac\xeb\xa5\xbc \xeb\x88\x84\xeb\xa5\xb4\xeb\xa9\xb4 \xeb\x82\xb4 \xec\x9d\x80\xed\x96\x89\xea\xb3\x84\xec\xa2\x8c\xec\x9d\x98 \xeb\x8f\x88\xec\x9d\xb4 \xeb\xb9\xa0\xec\xa0\xb8\xeb\x82\x98\xea\xb0\x80\xeb\x8a\x94 \xeb\xb0\xa9\xec\x8b\x9d\xec\x9d\x98 \xed\x95\xb4\xed\x82\xb9 \xeb\x93\xb1
  - CSRF \xea\xb3\xb5\xea\xb2\xa9\xec\x9d\x84 \xeb\xa7\x89\xea\xb8\xb0 \xec\x9c\x84\xed\x95\x9c \xeb\xb0\xa9\xeb\xb2\x95  
    1. \xec\x82\xac\xec\x9a\xa9\xec\x9e\x90\xec\x9d\x98 \xec\x9a\x94\xec\xb2\xad\xec\x97\x90 \xeb\x8c\x80\xed\x95\x9c \xec\xb6\x9c\xec\xb2\x98\xeb\xa5\xbc \xec\x9d\x98\xeb\xaf\xb8\xed\x95\x98\xeb\x8a\x94 referer \xed\x97\xa4\xeb\x8d\x94\xeb\xa5\xbc \xec\xb2\xb4\xed\x81\xac
    2. REST\xeb\xb0\xa9\xec\x8b\x9d\xec\x97\x90\xec\x84\x9c \xec\x82\xac\xec\x9a\xa9\xeb\x90\x98\xeb\x8a\x94 PUT, DELETE\xec\x99\x80 \xea\xb0\x99\xec\x9d\x80 \xeb\xb0\xa9\xec\x8b\x9d\xec\x9d\x84 \xec\x9d\xb4\xec\x9a\xa9
    3. CSRF\xed\x86\xa0\xed\x81\xb0

### 2. CSRF \xed\x86\xa0\xed\x81\xb0
   - \xec\x8a\xa4\xed\x94\x84\xeb\xa7\x81 \xec\x8b\x9c\xed\x81\x90\xeb\xa6\xac\xed\x8b\xb0\xec\x97\x90\xec\x84\x9c POST \xeb\xb0\xa9\xec\x8b\x9d\xec\x9d\x84 \xec\x9d\xb4\xec\x9a\xa9\xed\x95\x98\xeb\x8a\x94 \xea\xb2\xbd\xec\x9a\xb0 \xea\xb8\xb0\xeb\xb3\xb8\xec\xa0\x81\xec\x9c\xbc\xeb\xa1\x9c CSRF \xed\x86\xa0\xed\x81\xb0\xec\x9d\x84 \xec\x9d\xb4\xec\x9a\xa9\xed\x95\x98\xea\xb2\x8c \xeb\x90\x8c.
   - CSRF \xed\x86\xa0\xed\x81\xb0 : 
     1. \xec\x84\x9c\xeb\xb2\x84\xec\x97\x90 \xeb\x93\xa4\xec\x96\xb4\xec\x98\xa8 \xec\x9a\x94\xec\xb2\xad\xec\x9d\xb4 \xec\x8b\xa4\xec\xa0\x9c \xec\x84\x9c\xeb\xb2\x84\xec\x97\x90\xec\x84\x9c \xed\x97\x88\xec\x9a\xa9\xed\x95\x9c \xec\x9a\x94\xec\xb2\xad\xec\x9d\xb4 \xeb\xa7\x9e\xeb\x8a\x94\xec\xa7\x80 \xed\x99\x95\xec\x9d\xb8\xed\x95\x98\xea\xb8\xb0 \xec\x9c\x84\xed\x95\x9c \xed\x86\xa0\xed\x81\xb0.  
     2. CSRF Token\xec\x9d\x80 \xec\x9e\x84\xec\x9d\x98\xec\x9d\x98 \xeb\x82\x9c\xec\x88\x98\xeb\xa5\xbc \xec\x83\x9d\xec\x84\xb1\xed\x95\x98\xea\xb3\xa0 \xec\x84\xb8\xec\x85\x98\xec\x97\x90 \xec\xa0\x80\xec\x9e\xa5\xed\x95\xa8.    
     \xec\x82\xac\xec\x9a\xa9\xec\x9e\x90\xea\xb0\x80 POST\xec\x9a\x94\xec\xb2\xad\xec\x9d\x84 \xed\x95\xa0 \xeb\x95\x8c, \xed\x95\xb4\xeb\x8b\xb9 \xeb\x82\x9c\xec\x88\x98 \xea\xb0\x92(\xed\x86\xa0\xed\x81\xb0\xea\xb0\x92)\xec\x9d\x84 \xed\x8f\xac\xed\x95\xa8\xed\x95\xb4\xec\x84\x9c \xec\x84\x9c\xeb\xb2\x84\xeb\xa1\x9c \xec\xa0\x84\xec\x86\xa1\xec\x8b\x9c\xed\x82\xa4\xea\xb3\xa0, \xec\x84\x9c\xeb\xb2\x84\xec\x97\x90\xec\x84\x9c\xeb\x8a\x94 \xec\x9a\x94\xec\xb2\xad\xec\x9d\x84 \xeb\xb0\x9b\xec\x9d\x84 \xeb\x95\x8c\xeb\xa7\x88\xeb\x8b\xa4 \xec\x84\xb8\xec\x85\x98\xec\x97\x90 \xec\xa0\x80\xec\x9e\xa5\xeb\x90\x9c \xed\x86\xa0\xed\x81\xb0\xea\xb0\x92\xea\xb3\xbc \xec\x9a\x94\xec\xb2\xad \xed\x8c\x8c\xeb\x9d\xbc\xeb\xaf\xb8\xed\x84\xb0\xec\x97\x90 \xec\xa0\x84\xeb\x8b\xac\xeb\x90\x9c \xed\x86\xa0\xed\x81\xb0\xea\xb0\x92\xec\x9d\xb4 \xea\xb0\x99\xec\x9d\x80\xec\xa7\x80 \xec\xb2\xb4\xed\x81\xac\xed\x95\xa8.  
     \xeb\xa7\x8c\xec\x9d\xbc \xed\x86\xa0\xed\x81\xb0\xea\xb0\x92\xec\x9d\xb4 \xeb\x8b\xa4\xeb\xa5\xb4\xeb\x8b\xa4\xeb\xa9\xb4 \xec\x9e\x91\xec\x97\x85\xec\x9d\x84 \xec\xb2\x98\xeb\xa6\xac\xed\x95\x98\xec\xa7\x80 \xec\x95\x8a\xeb\x8a\x94 \xeb\xb0\xa9\xec\x8b\x9d.

# 2. JDBC\xeb\xa5\xbc \xec\x9d\xb4\xec\x9a\xa9\xed\x95\x98\xeb\x8a\x94 \xea\xb0\x84\xed\x8e\xb8 \xec\x9d\xb8\xec\xa6\x9d/\xea\xb6\x8c\xed\x95\x9c \xec\xb2\x98\xeb\xa6\xac
## 1) BCryptPasswordEncoder \xed\x81\xb4\xeb\x9e\x98\xec\x8a\xa4\xeb\xa5\xbc \xec\x9d\xb4\xec\x9a\xa9\xed\x95\x9c \xed\x8c\xa8\xec\x8a\xa4\xec\x9b\x8c\xeb\x93\x9c \xeb\xb3\xb4\xed\x98\xb8
- \xec\x95\x94\xed\x98\xb8\xed\x99\x94\xea\xb0\x80 \xed\x95\x84\xec\x9a\x94\xed\x95\x9c \xec\x9d\xb4\xec\x9c\xa0
  1. \xeb\x8c\x80\xeb\xb6\x80\xeb\xb6\x84\xec\x9d\x98 \xec\x82\xac\xec\x9a\xa9\xec\x9e\x90\xea\xb0\x80 \xec\x97\xac\xeb\x9f\xac \xec\x9b\xb9 \xec\x82\xac\xec\x9d\xb4\xed\x8a\xb8\xeb\xa5\xbc \xec\x9d\xb4\xec\x9a\xa9\xed\x95\x98\xeb\x8a\x94\xeb\x8d\xb0 \xec\x9d\xb4 \xeb\x95\x8c \xeb\x8f\x99\xec\x9d\xbc\xed\x95\x9c \xed\x8c\xa8\xec\x8a\xa4\xec\x9b\x8c\xeb\x93\x9c\xeb\xa5\xbc \xec\x82\xac\xec\x9a\xa9\xed\x95\x98\xeb\x8b\xa4\xea\xb0\x80 \xec\x96\xb4\xeb\x8a\x90 \xed\x95\x9c \xec\x9b\xb9 \xec\x82\xac\xec\x9d\xb4\xed\x8a\xb8\xec\x97\x90\xec\x84\x9c \xeb\xb9\x84\xeb\xb0\x80\xeb\xb2\x88\xed\x98\xb8\xea\xb0\x80 \xec\x9c\xa0\xec\xb6\x9c\xeb\x90\x98\xeb\xa9\xb4 \xec\x9d\xb4 \xec\x82\xac\xeb\x9e\x8c\xec\x9d\xb4 \xea\xb0\x80\xec\x9e\x85\xeb\x90\x9c \xeb\xaa\xa8\xeb\x93\xa0 \xec\x9b\xb9 \xec\x82\xac\xec\x9d\xb4\xed\x8a\xb8\xea\xb0\x80 \xed\x95\xb4\xed\x82\xb9\xeb\x90\x9c \xec\x9d\xbc\xec\x9d\xb4 \xeb\xb2\x8c\xec\x96\xb4\xec\xa7\x88\xec\x88\x98 \xec\x9e\x88\xec\x9d\x8c.        
  \xeb\x94\xb0\xeb\x9d\xbc\xec\x84\x9c \xec\x95\x94\xed\x98\xb8\xed\x99\x94\xeb\xa5\xbc \xed\x95\xb4\xeb\x91\x90\xeb\xa9\xb4 \xec\x84\xa4\xec\x82\xac \xec\x84\x9c\xeb\xb2\x84\xea\xb0\x80 \xed\x84\xb8\xeb\xa0\xa4\xec\x84\x9c \xed\x8c\xa8\xec\x8a\xa4\xec\x9b\x8c\xeb\x93\x9c\xea\xb0\x80 \xec\x9c\xa0\xec\xb6\x9c\xeb\x90\x9c\xeb\x8b\xa4 \xed\x95\x98\xeb\x8d\x94\xeb\x9d\xbc\xeb\x8f\x84 \xed\x95\xb4\xeb\x8b\xb9 \xec\x82\xac\xec\x9a\xa9\xec\x9e\x90\xec\x9d\x98 \xec\x9d\xb4\xeb\xa9\x94\xec\x9d\xbc\xeb\xa1\x9c \xea\xb0\x80\xec\x9e\x85\xeb\x90\x9c \xeb\x8b\xa4\xeb\xa5\xb8 \xec\x9b\xb9\xec\x82\xac\xec\x9d\xb4\xed\x8a\xb8\xec\x97\x90 \xec\xa0\x91\xea\xb7\xbc\xed\x95\x98\xec\xa7\x80 \xeb\xaa\xbb\xed\x95\xa0 \xea\xb2\x83.
  2. \xeb\xb9\x84\xeb\xb0\x80\xeb\xb2\x88\xed\x98\xb8\xeb\xa5\xbc \xec\x95\x94\xed\x98\xb8\xed\x99\x94 \xed\x95\xa8\xec\x9c\xbc\xeb\xa1\x9c\xec\x8d\xa8 \xeb\xb9\x84\xeb\xb0\x80\xeb\xb2\x88\xed\x98\xb8 \xeb\x8d\xb0\xec\x9d\xb4\xed\x84\xb0\xea\xb0\x80 \xeb\x85\xb8\xec\xb6\x9c\xeb\x90\x98\xeb\x8d\x94\xeb\x9d\xbc\xeb\x8f\x84 \xed\x99\x95\xec\x9d\xb8\xed\x95\x98\xea\xb8\xb0 \xec\x96\xb4\xeb\xa0\xb5\xeb\x8f\x84\xeb\xa1\x9d \xeb\xa7\x8c\xeb\x93\xa4\xec\x96\xb4 \xec\xa4\x84 \xec\x88\x98 \xec\x9e\x88\xec\x9d\x8c.

## 2) JUnit\xec\x9d\x84 \xec\x82\xac\xec\x9a\xa9\xed\x95\x9c \xec\x9e\x90\xeb\xb0\x94 \xeb\x8b\xa8\xec\x9c\x84\xed\x85\x8c\xec\x8a\xa4\xed\x8a\xb8
- \xeb\x8b\xa8\xec\x9c\x84\xed\x85\x8c\xec\x8a\xa4\xed\x8a\xb8\xeb\x9e\x80?   
\xed\x8a\xb9\xec\xa0\x95 \xec\x86\x8c\xec\x8a\xa4\xec\xbd\x94\xeb\x93\x9c\xec\x9d\x98 \xeb\xaa\xa8\xeb\x93\x88\xec\x9d\xb4 \xec\x9d\x98\xeb\x8f\x84\xed\x95\x9c \xeb\x8c\x80\xeb\xa1\x9c \xec\x9e\x91\xeb\x8f\x99\xed\x95\x98\xeb\x8a\x94\xec\xa7\x80 \xea\xb2\x80\xec\xa6\x9d\xed\x95\x98\xeb\x8a\x94 \xed\x85\x8c\xec\x8a\xa4\xed\x8a\xb8.    
\xec\xa6\x89, \xed\x95\xa8\xec\x88\x98 \xeb\xb0\x8f \xeb\xa9\x94\xec\x86\x8c\xeb\x93\x9c\xec\x97\x90 \xeb\x8c\x80\xed\x95\x9c \xed\x85\x8c\xec\x8a\xa4\xed\x8a\xb8\xeb\xa5\xbc \xed\x95\x98\xeb\x8a\x94 \xec\x9e\x91\xec\x97\x85.
1. [MemberTest.java] PasswordEncoder\xeb\xa5\xbc \xec\x9d\xb4\xec\x9a\xa9\xed\x95\xb4\xec\x84\x9c \xec\x95\x94\xed\x98\xb8\xed\x99\x94\xeb\x90\x9c \xeb\xb9\x84\xeb\xb0\x80\xeb\xb2\x88\xed\x98\xb8\xeb\xa5\xbc tb_user \xed\x85\x8c\xec\x9d\xb4\xeb\xb8\x94\xec\x97\x90 insert\xed\x95\x98\xeb\xa9\xb4\xec\x84\x9c \xec\x82\xac\xec\x9a\xa9\xec\x9e\x90 \xeb\x8d\xb0\xec\x9d\xb4\xed\x84\xb0 \xec\x83\x9d\xec\x84\xb1

2. [AuthTest.java] user_auth \xed\x85\x8c\xec\x9d\xb4\xeb\xb8\x94\xec\x97\x90 \xec\x82\xac\xec\x9a\xa9\xec\x9e\x90\xec\x9d\x98 \xea\xb6\x8c\xed\x95\x9c \xeb\xb6\x80\xec\x97\xac\xed\x95\x98\xeb\x8a\x94 insert\xeb\xac\xb8 \xec\x8b\xa4\xed\x96\x89


# 3. \xec\xbb\xa4\xec\x8a\xa4\xed\x85\x80 UserDetailsService \xed\x99\x9c\xec\x9a\xa9
- UserDetailsService : \xec\x9b\x90\xed\x95\x98\xeb\x8a\x94 \xea\xb0\x9d\xec\xb2\xb4\xeb\xa5\xbc \xec\x9d\xb8\xec\xa6\x9d\xea\xb3\xbc \xea\xb6\x8c\xed\x95\x9c \xec\xb2\xb4\xed\x81\xac\xec\x97\x90 \xed\x99\x9c\xec\x9a\xa9\xed\x95\xa0 \xec\x88\x98 \xec\x9e\x88\xec\x9d\x8c
## 1) MemberMapper.xml
### 1. `<resultMap>`
- User \xea\xb0\x9d\xec\xb2\xb4\xeb\xa5\xbc \xea\xb0\x80\xec\xa0\xb8\xec\x98\xa4\xeb\x8a\x94 \xea\xb2\xbd\xec\x9a\xb0, \xed\x95\x9c \xeb\xb2\x88\xec\x97\x90 tb_user\xec\x99\x80 user_auth\xeb\xa5\xbc \xec\xa1\xb0\xec\x9d\xb8\xed\x95\xb4\xec\x84\x9c \xec\xb2\x98\xeb\xa6\xac\xed\x95\xa0 \xec\x88\x98 \xec\x9e\x88\xeb\x8a\x94 \xeb\xb0\xa9\xec\x8b\x9d\xec\x9c\xbc\xeb\xa1\x9c `<resultMap>` \xec\x9d\x84 \xec\x82\xac\xec\x9a\xa9\xed\x95\xa8   
- \xed\x95\x98\xeb\x82\x98\xec\x9d\x98 MemberDto \xec\x9d\xb8\xec\x8a\xa4\xed\x84\xb4\xec\x8a\xa4\xeb\x8a\x94 \xeb\x82\xb4\xeb\xb6\x80\xec\xa0\x81\xec\x9c\xbc\xeb\xa1\x9c \xec\x97\xac\xeb\x9f\xac \xea\xb0\x9c\xec\x9d\x98 AuthDto\xeb\xa5\xbc \xea\xb0\x80\xec\xa7\x80\xeb\x8a\x94\xeb\x8d\xb0 \xec\x9d\xb4\xeb\xa5\xbc '1+N \xea\xb4\x80\xea\xb3\x84'\xeb\x9d\xbc\xea\xb3\xa0 \xed\x95\xa8.   
\xec\xa6\x89, \xed\x95\x98\xeb\x82\x98\xec\x9d\x98 \xeb\x8d\xb0\xec\x9d\xb4\xed\x84\xb0\xea\xb0\x80 \xec\x97\xac\xeb\x9f\xac \xea\xb0\x9c\xec\x9d\x98 \xed\x95\x98\xec\x9c\x84 \xeb\x8d\xb0\xec\x9d\xb4\xed\x84\xb0\xeb\xa5\xbc \xed\x8f\xac\xed\x95\xa8\xed\x95\x98\xea\xb3\xa0 \xec\x9e\x88\xeb\x8a\x94 \xea\xb2\x83\xec\x9d\x84 \xec\x9d\x98\xeb\xaf\xb8.    
- `<resultMap>` : \xed\x95\x98\xeb\x82\x98\xec\x9d\x98 \xea\xb2\xb0\xea\xb3\xbc\xec\x97\x90 \xeb\xb6\x80\xea\xb0\x80\xec\xa0\x81\xec\x9c\xbc\xeb\xa1\x9c \xec\x97\xac\xeb\x9f\xac \xea\xb0\x9c\xec\x9d\x98 \xeb\x8d\xb0\xec\x9d\xb4\xed\x84\xb0\xeb\xa5\xbc \xec\xb2\x98\xeb\xa6\xac\xed\x95\x98\xeb\x8a\x94 \xea\xb2\xbd\xec\x9a\xb0 1:N\xec\x9d\x98 \xea\xb2\xb0\xea\xb3\xbc\xeb\xa5\xbc \xec\xb2\x98\xeb\xa6\xac\xed\x95\xa0 \xec\x88\x98 \xec\x9e\x88\xea\xb2\x8c \xed\x95\xb4\xec\xa3\xbc\xeb\x8a\x94 \xed\x83\x9c\xea\xb7\xb8.
```xml
	<resultMap type="MemberDto" id="memberMap">
		<id property="user_id" column="user_id"/>
		<result property="user_id" column="user_id"/>
		<result property="user_name" column="user_name"/>
		<result property="user_pw" column="user_pw"/>
		<result property="user_gender" column="user_gender"/>
		<result property="user_birth_date" column="user_birth_date"/>
		<result property="user_email" column="user_email"/>
		<result property="user_phone_number" column="user_phone_number"/>
		<result property="user_postcode" column="user_postcode"/>
		<result property="user_rNameAddr" column="user_rnameaddr"/>
		<result property="user_detailAddr" column="user_detailaddr"/>
		<result property="user_regdate" column="user_regdate"/>
		<result property="user_grade" column="user_grade"/>
		<result property="user_social_type" column="user_social_type"/>
		<collection property="authList" resultMap="authMap"></collection>
	</resultMap>
	 	
	<resultMap type="AuthDto" id="authMap">
		<result property="user_id" column="user_id"/>
		<result property="auth" column="auth"/>
	</resultMap>
  ```
- `id="memberMap"`\xec\x9d\xb8 `<resultMap>`\xec\x9d\x80 `<result>`\xec\x99\x80 `<collection>`\xec\x9d\x84 \xec\x9d\xb4\xec\x9a\xa9\xed\x95\xb4 \xeb\xb0\x94\xea\xb9\xa5\xec\xaa\xbd \xea\xb0\x9d\xec\xb2\xb4(MemberDto\xec\x9d\x98 \xec\x9d\xb8\xec\x8a\xa4\xed\x84\xb4\xec\x8a\xa4)\xec\x99\x80 \xec\x95\x88\xec\xaa\xbd \xea\xb0\x9d\xec\xb2\xb4\xeb\x93\xa4(AuthDto\xec\x9d\x98 \xec\x9d\xb8\xec\x8a\xa4\xed\x84\xb4\xec\x8a\xa4\xeb\x93\xa4)\xec\x9d\x84 \xea\xb5\xac\xec\x84\xb1\xed\x95\xa0 \xec\x88\x98 \xec\x9e\x88\xec\x9d\x8c.

### 2. `resultMap="memberMap"`\xec\x9d\xb8 select\xeb\xac\xb8
```xml
	<select id="read" parameterType="String"  resultMap="memberMap">
		SELECT 
			tb_user.user_id , user_name, user_pw, user_gender, user_birth_date, user_email, user_phone_number,
			user_postcode, user_rnameaddr, user_detailaddr, user_regdate, user_grade, user_social_type, auth
		FROM tb_user tb_user, user_auth user_auth 
		where tb_user.user_id = user_auth.user_id 
		and tb_user.user_id = #{user_id}
	</select>  
```
- user\xec\x9d\x98 auth\xea\xb0\x80 2\xea\xb0\x9c \xec\x9d\xb4\xec\x83\x81\xec\x9d\xbc \xea\xb2\xbd\xec\x9a\xb0, \xed\x95\xb4\xeb\x8b\xb9 \xec\xbf\xbc\xeb\xa6\xac\xec\x9d\x98 \xea\xb2\xb0\xea\xb3\xbc\xeb\xa1\x9c auth\xec\xbb\xac\xeb\x9f\xbc \xea\xb0\x92\xec\x9d\x80 \xeb\x8b\xa4\xeb\xa5\xb4\xec\xa7\x80\xeb\xa7\x8c, \xeb\x82\x98\xeb\xa8\xb8\xec\xa7\x80 tb_user \xec\xbb\xac\xeb\x9f\xbc \xea\xb0\x92\xec\x9d\x80 \xeb\x8f\x99\xec\x9d\xbc\xed\x95\x98\xea\xb2\x8c \xec\xb6\x9c\xeb\xa0\xa5\xeb\x90\x8c.

## 2) CustomUserDetailsService \xea\xb5\xac\xec\x84\xb1
### 1. `AuthenticationProvider`
```xml
	<security:authentication-manager >
		<security:authentication-provider user-service-ref="customUserDetailsService">
			<security:password-encoder ref="bcryptPasswordEncoder" />
		</security:authentication-provider>
	</security:authentication-manager>
```
- `AuthenticationProvider` : db\xec\x97\x90\xec\x84\x9c \xea\xb0\x80\xec\xa0\xb8\xec\x98\xa8 \xec\xa0\x95\xeb\xb3\xb4\xec\x99\x80 input \xeb\x90\x9c \xec\xa0\x95\xeb\xb3\xb4\xea\xb0\x80 \xeb\xb9\x84\xea\xb5\x90\xeb\x90\x98\xec\x84\x9c \xec\xb2\xb4\xed\x81\xac\xeb\x90\x98\xeb\x8a\x94 \xeb\xa1\x9c\xec\xa7\x81\xec\x9d\xb4 \xed\x8f\xac\xed\x95\xa8\xeb\x90\x98\xec\x96\xb4\xec\x9e\x88\xeb\x8a\x94 \xec\x9d\xb8\xed\x84\xb0\xed\x8e\x98\xec\x9d\xb4\xec\x8a\xa4.
- db\xec\x97\x90\xec\x84\x9c \xec\x82\xac\xec\x9a\xa9\xec\x9e\x90 \xec\xa0\x95\xeb\xb3\xb4\xeb\xa5\xbc \xea\xb0\x80\xec\xa7\x80\xea\xb3\xa0 \xec\x98\xa4\xeb\xa0\xa4\xeb\xa9\xb4 `UserDetailsService`\xec\x9d\x98 `loadUserByUsername()` \xeb\xa9\x94\xec\x84\x9c\xeb\x93\x9c\xea\xb0\x80 \xeb\xa6\xac\xed\x84\xb4\xed\x95\xb4\xec\xa3\xbc\xeb\x8a\x94 \xea\xb0\x92(=UserDetails)\xec\x9d\x84 \xea\xb0\x80\xec\xa7\x80\xea\xb3\xa0 \xec\x82\xac\xec\x9a\xa9\xec\x9d\xb4 \xea\xb0\x80\xeb\x8a\xa5\xed\x95\xa8.
- \xeb\xa6\xac\xed\x84\xb4\xeb\x90\x9c user \xec\xa0\x95\xeb\xb3\xb4\xeb\xa5\xbc \xea\xb0\x80\xec\xa7\x80\xea\xb3\xa0 PasswordEncoder bean\xec\x9d\x84 \xec\x82\xac\xec\x9a\xa9\xed\x95\x98\xec\x97\xac\xec\x84\x9c input \xeb\x90\x9c \xeb\xb9\x84\xeb\xb0\x80\xeb\xb2\x88\xed\x98\xb8\xec\x99\x80 \xeb\xa7\xa4\xec\xb9\xad \xec\x8b\x9c\xec\xbc\x9c\xec\xa3\xbc\xeb\x8a\x94 \xeb\xb0\xa9\xec\x8b\x9d.

## 3) MemberDto\xeb\xa5\xbc UserDetails \xed\x83\x80\xec\x9e\x85\xec\x9c\xbc\xeb\xa1\x9c \xeb\xb3\x80\xed\x99\x98\xed\x95\x98\xea\xb8\xb0
- \xec\xb5\x9c\xec\xa2\x85\xec\xa0\x81\xec\x9c\xbc\xeb\xa1\x9c MemberDto\xec\x9d\x98 \xec\x9d\xb8\xec\x8a\xa4\xed\x84\xb4\xec\x8a\xa4\xeb\xa5\xbc \xec\x8a\xa4\xed\x94\x84\xeb\xa7\x81 \xec\x8b\x9c\xed\x81\x90\xeb\xa6\xac\xed\x8b\xb0\xec\x9d\x98 UserDetails \xed\x83\x80\xec\x9e\x85\xec\x9c\xbc\xeb\xa1\x9c \xeb\xb3\x80\xed\x99\x98\xed\x95\x98\xeb\x8a\x94 \xec\x9e\x91\xec\x97\x85\xec\x9d\x84 \xec\xb2\x98\xeb\xa6\xac\xed\x95\xb4\xec\x95\xbc \xed\x95\xa8.
- \xeb\xb3\x80\xed\x99\x98 \xed\x9b\x84 [CustomUserDetailsService.java]\xec\x97\x90\xec\x84\x9c [CustomUser.java]\xeb\xa5\xbc \xeb\xb0\x98\xed\x99\x98\xed\x95\x98\xeb\x8f\x84\xeb\xa1\x9d \xec\x88\x98\xec\xa0\x95.
- [CustomUser.java] : UserDetails\xeb\xa5\xbc \xea\xb5\xac\xed\x98\x84\xed\x95\x9c User \xed\x81\xb4\xeb\x9e\x98\xec\x8a\xa4\xeb\xa5\xbc \xec\x83\x81\xec\x86\x8d\xeb\xb0\x9b\xeb\x8a\x94 \xed\x81\xb4\xeb\x9e\x98\xec\x8a\xa4.
### \xed\x9d\x90\xeb\xa6\x84
1. `UserDetailsService`\xec\x9d\x98 `loadUserByUsername()`\xec\x9d\x80 \xeb\x82\xb4\xeb\xb6\x80\xec\xa0\x81\xec\x9c\xbc\xeb\xa1\x9c MemberMapper\xeb\xa5\xbc \xec\x9d\xb4\xec\x9a\xa9\xed\x95\xb4\xec\x84\x9c MemberDto\xeb\xa5\xbc \xec\xa1\xb0\xed\x9a\x8c\xed\x95\xa8.
2. \xeb\xa7\x8c\xec\x9d\xbc MemberDto\xec\x9d\x98 \xec\x9d\xb8\xec\x8a\xa4\xed\x84\xb4\xec\x8a\xa4\xeb\xa5\xbc \xec\x96\xbb\xec\x9d\x84 \xec\x88\x98 \xec\x9e\x88\xeb\x8b\xa4\xeb\xa9\xb4 CustomUser \xed\x83\x80\xec\x9e\x85\xec\x9d\x98 \xea\xb0\x9d\xec\xb2\xb4\xeb\xa1\x9c \xeb\xb3\x80\xed\x99\x98 \xed\x9b\x84 \xeb\xb0\x98\xed\x99\x98\xed\x95\xa8.
3. [CustomUserDetailsService.java] \xec\xa0\x81\xec\x9a\xa9 \xec\xbd\x94\xeb\x93\x9c
```java
	@Override
	// DB\xec\x97\x90 \xec\x9e\x88\xeb\x8a\x94 \xec\x82\xac\xec\x9a\xa9\xec\x9e\x90\xec\x9d\x98 \xec\xa0\x95\xeb\xb3\xb4\xeb\xa5\xbc UserDetails\xed\x83\x80\xec\x9e\x85\xec\x9c\xbc\xeb\xa1\x9c \xea\xb0\x80\xec\xa0\xb8\xec\x98\xb4 
	// \xec\x9e\x85\xeb\xa0\xa5\xeb\x90\x9c \xec\xa0\x95\xeb\xb3\xb4\xec\x99\x80 DB\xec\x97\x90 \xec\xa0\x80\xec\x9e\xa5\xeb\x90\x98\xec\x96\xb4\xec\x9e\x88\xeb\x8a\x94 \xec\xa0\x95\xeb\xb3\xb4\xeb\xa5\xbc \xeb\xb9\x84\xea\xb5\x90, \xeb\x91\x90 \xea\xb0\x9c\xec\x9d\x98 \xec\xa0\x95\xeb\xb3\xb4\xea\xb0\x80 \xeb\x8b\xa4\xeb\xa5\xb4\xeb\x8b\xa4\xeb\xa9\xb4 UsernameNotFoundException\xec\x9d\x84 \xed\x86\xb5\xed\x95\xb4 \xec\x98\x88\xec\x99\xb8\xec\xb2\x98\xeb\xa6\xac
	public UserDetails loadUserByUsername(String user_id) throws UsernameNotFoundException {
		
	    MemberDto dto = null;
		try {
			dto = service.read(user_id);
		} catch (Exception e) {
			e.printStackTrace();
		}
		// null\xec\x9d\xb4 \xec\x95\x84\xeb\x8b\x88\xeb\xa9\xb4 CustomUser\xeb\xa5\xbc \xeb\xb0\x98\xed\x99\x98
		return dto == null ? null : new CustomUser(dto);

	}
```

# 4. \xec\x8a\xa4\xed\x94\x84\xeb\xa7\x81 \xec\x8b\x9c\xed\x81\x90\xeb\xa6\xac\xed\x8b\xb0\xeb\xa5\xbc JSP\xec\x97\x90\xec\x84\x9c \xec\x82\xac\xec\x9a\xa9\xed\x95\x98\xea\xb8\xb0
## 1) \xea\xb0\x9c\xec\x9a\x94
- \xeb\x8b\xa8\xec\x88\x9c\xed\x9e\x88 JDBC\xeb\xa5\xbc \xec\x9d\xb4\xec\x9a\xa9\xed\x95\x98\xec\xa7\x80 \xec\x95\x8a\xea\xb3\xa0, `CustomUserDetailsService`\xec\x99\x80 \xea\xb0\x99\xec\x9d\xb4 \xeb\xb3\x84\xeb\x8f\x84\xec\x9d\x98 \xec\x9d\xb8\xec\xa6\x9d/\xea\xb6\x8c\xed\x95\x9c \xec\xb2\xb4\xed\x81\xac\xeb\xa5\xbc \xed\x95\x98\xeb\x8a\x94 \xea\xb0\x80\xec\x9e\xa5 \xed\x81\xb0 \xec\x9d\xb4\xec\x9c\xa0\xeb\x8a\x94 JSP \xeb\x93\xb1\xec\x97\x90\xec\x84\x9c \xeb\x8b\xa8\xec\x88\x9c\xed\x9e\x88 \xec\x82\xac\xec\x9a\xa9\xec\x9e\x90\xec\x9d\x98 \xec\x95\x84\xec\x9d\xb4\xeb\x94\x94(username) \xec\xa0\x95\xeb\x8f\x84\xea\xb0\x80 \xec\x95\x84\xeb\x8b\x8c \xec\x82\xac\xec\x9a\xa9\xec\x9e\x90\xec\x9d\x98 \xec\x9d\xb4\xeb\xa6\x84\xec\x9d\xb4\xeb\x82\x98 \xec\x9d\xb4\xeb\xa9\x94\xec\x9d\xbc\xea\xb3\xbc \xea\xb0\x99\xec\x9d\x80 \xec\xb6\x94\xea\xb0\x80\xec\xa0\x81\xec\x9d\xb8 \xec\xa0\x95\xeb\xb3\xb4\xeb\xa5\xbc \xec\x9d\xb4\xec\x9a\xa9\xed\x95\x98\xea\xb8\xb0 \xec\x9c\x84\xed\x95\xb4\xec\x84\x9c\xec\x9e\x84.

## 2) JSP\xec\x97\x90\xec\x84\x9c \xeb\xa1\x9c\xea\xb7\xb8\xec\x9d\xb8\xed\x95\x9c \xec\x82\xac\xec\x9a\xa9\xec\x9e\x90 \xec\xa0\x95\xeb\xb3\xb4 \xeb\xb3\xb4\xec\x97\xac\xec\xa3\xbc\xea\xb8\xb0(\xec\x8b\x9c\xed\x81\x90\xeb\xa6\xac\xed\x8b\xb0\xec\x99\x80 \xea\xb4\x80\xeb\xa0\xa8\xeb\x90\x9c \xec\xa0\x95\xeb\xb3\xb4 \xec\xb6\x9c\xeb\xa0\xa5)
### 1. \xec\x8b\x9c\xed\x81\x90\xeb\xa6\xac\xed\x8b\xb0 \xea\xb4\x80\xeb\xa0\xa8 \xed\x83\x9c\xea\xb7\xb8 \xeb\x9d\xbc\xec\x9d\xb4\xeb\xb8\x8c\xeb\x9f\xac\xeb\xa6\xac \xec\x84\xa0\xec\x96\xb8			
```jsp
<%@taglib prefix="sec" uri="http://www.springframework.org/security/tags" %>
```
### 2. `<sec:authentication>` \xed\x83\x9c\xea\xb7\xb8\xec\x99\x80 `principal` \xec\x86\x8d\xec\x84\xb1 \xec\x82\xac\xec\x9a\xa9
- `<sec:authentication property="principal" />` :	
</br>							
  - `principal` = `UserDetailsService`\xec\x97\x90\xec\x84\x9c \xeb\xb0\x98\xed\x99\x98\xeb\x90\x9c \xea\xb0\x9d\xec\xb2\xb4 = `loadUserByUsername()`\xec\x97\x90\xec\x84\x9c \xeb\xb0\x98\xed\x99\x98\xeb\x90\x9c `CustomUser` \xea\xb0\x9d\xec\xb2\xb4 
  - \xec\xa6\x89, `principal` = `CustomUser`\xeb\xa5\xbc \xec\x9d\x98\xeb\xaf\xb8\xed\x95\x98\xeb\xaf\x80\xeb\xa1\x9c 	
  </br>	
  `principal.member`\xeb\x8a\x94 `CustomUser` \xea\xb0\x9d\xec\xb2\xb4\xec\x9d\x98 `getMember()`\xeb\xa5\xbc \xed\x98\xb8\xec\xb6\x9c\xed\x95\xa8
  </br>	 			
  \xe2\x86\x92 [CustomUser.java] \xec\x97\x90\xec\x84\x9c `this.member = dto;` \xeb\xb6\x80\xeb\xb6\x84.
  </br>	
  \xec\x97\xac\xea\xb8\xb0\xec\x84\x9c \xed\x8c\x8c\xeb\x9d\xbc\xeb\xaf\xb8\xed\x84\xb0\xeb\xa1\x9c \xeb\xb0\x9b\xec\x9d\x80 dto\xeb\x8a\x94 \xeb\xa1\x9c\xea\xb7\xb8\xec\x9d\xb8\xed\x95\x9c \xec\x82\xac\xec\x9a\xa9\xec\x9e\x90\xec\x9d\x98 \xec\xa0\x95\xeb\xb3\xb4\xeb\xa5\xbc \xec\x9d\x98\xeb\xaf\xb8.	
  </br>		
  \xe2\x86\x92 \xec\xa6\x89, dto\xeb\x8a\x94 [CustomUserDetailsService.java] \xec\x97\x90\xec\x84\x9c `service.read(user_id)`\xeb\xa1\x9c \xeb\xa7\xa4\xed\x8d\xbc \xea\xb5\xac\xeb\xac\xb8 \xec\x8b\xa4\xed\x96\x89\xed\x9b\x84 select\xeb\x90\x9c \xec\x82\xac\xec\x9a\xa9\xec\x9e\x90\xec\x9d\x98 \xec\xa0\x95\xeb\xb3\xb4(dto)\xeb\xa5\xbc
  </br>			
  `return dto == null ? null : new CustomUser(dto)` 
  </br>	
  CustomUser \xea\xb0\x9d\xec\xb2\xb4\xeb\xa1\x9c \xeb\xb3\x80\xed\x99\x98\xed\x95\x9c \xea\xb2\x83\xec\x9e\x84.
  </br>			
  [CustomUserDetailsService.java]
	```java
		@Override
		// DB\xec\x97\x90 \xec\x9e\x88\xeb\x8a\x94 \xec\x82\xac\xec\x9a\xa9\xec\x9e\x90\xec\x9d\x98 \xec\xa0\x95\xeb\xb3\xb4\xeb\xa5\xbc UserDetails\xed\x83\x80\xec\x9e\x85\xec\x9c\xbc\xeb\xa1\x9c \xea\xb0\x80\xec\xa0\xb8\xec\x98\xb4 
		// \xec\x9e\x85\xeb\xa0\xa5\xeb\x90\x9c \xec\xa0\x95\xeb\xb3\xb4\xec\x99\x80 DB\xec\x97\x90 \xec\xa0\x80\xec\x9e\xa5\xeb\x90\x98\xec\x96\xb4\xec\x9e\x88\xeb\x8a\x94 \xec\xa0\x95\xeb\xb3\xb4\xeb\xa5\xbc \xeb\xb9\x84\xea\xb5\x90, \xeb\x91\x90 \xea\xb0\x9c\xec\x9d\x98 \xec\xa0\x95\xeb\xb3\xb4\xea\xb0\x80 \xeb\x8b\xa4\xeb\xa5\xb4\xeb\x8b\xa4\xeb\xa9\xb4 UsernameNotFoundException\xec\x9d\x84 \xed\x86\xb5\xed\x95\xb4 \xec\x98\x88\xec\x99\xb8\xec\xb2\x98\xeb\xa6\xac 
		public UserDetails loadUserByUsername(String user_id) throws UsernameNotFoundException {
				
			MemberDto dto = null;
			try {
				dto = service.read(user_id);
			} catch (Exception e) {
				e.printStackTrace();
			}
			// null\xec\x9d\xb4 \xec\x95\x84\xeb\x8b\x88\xeb\xa9\xb4 CustomUser\xeb\xa5\xbc \xeb\xb0\x98\xed\x99\x98
			return dto == null ? null : new CustomUser(dto);

		}
	```
- \xec\x98\x88\xec\x8b\x9c
	- [MemberDto.java]
		```java
		public class MemberDto {

			private String user_id;
			private String user_name;

		}
		```	

	- jsp
		```jsp
		<p>\xec\x82\xac\xec\x9a\xa9\xec\x9e\x90 \xec\x95\x84\xec\x9d\xb4\xeb\x94\x94 : <sec:authentication property="principal.member.user_id" /></p>	//user0
		<p>\xec\x82\xac\xec\x9a\xa9\xec\x9e\x90 \xec\x9d\xb4\xeb\xa6\x84 : <sec:authentication property="principal.member.user_name" /></p>	//\xed\x9a\x8c\xec\x9b\x900
		```


## 3) \xed\x91\x9c\xed\x98\x84\xec\x8b\x9d\xec\x9d\x84 \xec\x9d\xb4\xec\x9a\xa9\xed\x95\x98\xeb\x8a\x94 \xeb\x8f\x99\xec\xa0\x81 \xed\x99\x94\xeb\xa9\xb4 \xea\xb5\xac\xec\x84\xb1

# 5. \xec\x9e\x90\xeb\x8f\x99\xeb\xa1\x9c\xea\xb7\xb8\xec\x9d\xb8(remember-me)
## 1. \xea\xb0\x9c\xec\x9a\x94
- \xec\x9e\x90\xeb\x8f\x99 \xeb\xa1\x9c\xea\xb7\xb8\xec\x9d\xb8 \xea\xb8\xb0\xeb\x8a\xa5\xec\x9d\x84 \xec\xb2\x98\xeb\xa6\xac\xed\x95\x98\xeb\x8a\x94 \xeb\xb0\xa9\xec\x8b\x9d \xec\xa4\x91\xec\x97\x90\xec\x84\x9c \xea\xb0\x80\xec\x9e\xa5 \xeb\xa7\x8e\xec\x9d\xb4 \xec\x82\xac\xec\x9a\xa9\xeb\x90\x98\xeb\x8a\x94 \xeb\xb0\xa9\xec\x8b\x9d\xec\x9d\x80 \xeb\xa1\x9c\xea\xb7\xb8\xec\x9d\xb8\xec\x9d\xb4 \xeb\x90\x98\xec\x97\x88\xeb\x8d\x98 \xec\xa0\x95\xeb\xb3\xb4\xeb\xa5\xbc \xeb\x8d\xb0\xec\x9d\xb4\xed\x84\xb0\xeb\xb2\xa0\xec\x9d\xb4\xec\x8a\xa4\xeb\xa5\xbc \xec\x9d\xb4\xec\x9a\xa9\xed\x95\xb4\xec\x84\x9c \xea\xb8\xb0\xeb\xa1\x9d\xed\x95\xb4 \xeb\x91\x90\xec\x97\x88\xeb\x8b\xa4\xea\xb0\x80 \xec\x82\xac\xec\x9a\xa9\xec\x9e\x90\xec\x9d\x98 \xec\x9e\xac\xeb\xb0\xa9\xeb\xac\xb8 \xec\x8b\x9c \xec\x84\xb8\xec\x85\x98\xec\x97\x90 \xec\xa0\x95\xeb\xb3\xb4\xea\xb0\x80 \xec\x97\x86\xec\x9c\xbc\xeb\xa9\xb4 \xeb\x8d\xb0\xec\x9d\xb4\xed\x84\xb0\xeb\xb2\xa0\xec\x9d\xb4\xec\x8a\xa4\xeb\xa5\xbc \xec\xa1\xb0\xed\x9a\x8c\xed\x95\xb4\xec\x84\x9c \xec\x82\xac\xec\x9a\xa9\xed\x95\x98\xeb\x8a\x94 \xeb\xb0\xa9\xec\x8b\x9d\xec\x9e\x84.
- \xec\x84\x9c\xeb\xb2\x84\xec\x9d\x98 \xeb\xa9\x94\xeb\xaa\xa8\xeb\xa6\xac\xec\x83\x81\xec\x97\x90\xeb\xa7\x8c \xeb\x8d\xb0\xec\x9d\xb4\xed\x84\xb0\xeb\xa5\xbc \xec\xa0\x80\xec\x9e\xa5\xed\x95\x98\xeb\x8a\x94 \xeb\xb0\xa9\xec\x8b\x9d\xeb\xb3\xb4\xeb\x8b\xa4 \xec\xa2\x8b\xec\x9d\x80 \xec\xa0\x90\xec\x9d\x80 \xeb\x8d\xb0\xec\x9d\xb4\xed\x84\xb0\xeb\xb2\xa0\xec\x9d\xb4\xec\x8a\xa4\xec\x97\x90 \xec\xa0\x95\xeb\xb3\xb4\xea\xb0\x80 \xea\xb3\xb5\xec\x9c\xa0\xeb\x90\x98\xea\xb8\xb0 \xeb\x95\x8c\xeb\xac\xb8\xec\x97\x90 \xec\xa2\x80 \xeb\x8d\x94 \xec\x95\x88\xec\xa0\x95\xec\xa0\x81\xec\x9c\xbc\xeb\xa1\x9c \xec\x9a\xb4\xec\x98\x81\xec\x9d\xb4 \xea\xb0\x80\xeb\x8a\xa5\xed\x95\x98\xeb\x8b\xa4\xeb\x8a\x94 \xec\xa0\x90.

## 2. \xeb\x8d\xb0\xec\x9d\xb4\xed\x84\xb0\xeb\xb2\xa0\xec\x9d\xb4\xec\x8a\xa4\xeb\xa5\xbc \xec\x9d\xb4\xec\x9a\xa9\xed\x95\x98\xeb\x8a\x94 \xec\x9e\x90\xeb\x8f\x99 \xeb\xa1\x9c\xea\xb7\xb8\xec\x9d\xb8
- \xec\x8a\xa4\xed\x94\x84\xeb\xa7\x81 \xec\x8b\x9c\xed\x81\x90\xeb\xa6\xac\xed\x8b\xb0\xec\x97\x90\xec\x84\x9c `remember-me` \xea\xb8\xb0\xeb\x8a\xa5\xec\x9d\x80 \xec\xa7\x80\xec\xa0\x95\xeb\x90\x9c \xec\x9d\xb4\xeb\xa6\x84\xec\x9d\x98 \xed\x85\x8c\xec\x9d\xb4\xeb\xb8\x94\xec\x9d\x84 \xec\x83\x9d\xec\x84\xb1\xed\x95\x98\xeb\xa9\xb4 \xec\xa7\x80\xec\xa0\x95\xeb\x90\x9c SQL\xeb\xac\xb8\xec\x9d\xb4 \xec\x8b\xa4\xed\x96\x89\xeb\x90\x98\xeb\xa9\xb4\xec\x84\x9c \xec\x9d\xb4\xeb\xa5\xbc \xec\xb2\x98\xeb\xa6\xac\xed\x95\x98\xeb\x8a\x94 \xeb\xb0\xa9\xec\x8b\x9d\xec\x9d\xb4 \xec\x9e\x88\xec\x9d\x8c.
### 1) \xec\x8b\x9c\xed\x81\x90\xeb\xa6\xac\xed\x8b\xb0\xec\x97\x90\xec\x84\x9c \xec\xa0\x9c\xea\xb3\xb5\xed\x95\x98\xeb\x8a\x94 \xeb\xa1\x9c\xea\xb7\xb8\xec\x9d\xb8 \xec\xa0\x95\xeb\xb3\xb4 \xec\x9c\xa0\xec\xa7\x80 \xed\x85\x8c\xec\x9d\xb4\xeb\xb8\x94 \xec\x83\x9d\xec\x84\xb1
```sql
create table persistent_logins 
(
	username varchar(16) not null,
	series varchar(64) primary key,
	token varchar(64) not null,
	last_used timestamp not null
);
```

### 2) [security-context.xml]
- `data-source-ref="dataSource"` \xec\xa7\x80\xec\xa0\x95\xed\x95\xb4\xec\x84\x9c \xeb\x8d\xb0\xec\x9d\xb4\xed\x84\xb0\xeb\xb2\xa0\xec\x9d\xb4\xec\x8a\xa4 \xec\x9d\xb4\xec\x9a\xa9
	```xml
	<!-- \xec\x9e\x90\xeb\x8f\x99\xeb\xa1\x9c\xea\xb7\xb8\xec\x9d\xb8 30\xec\x9d\xbc \xec\x84\xa4\xec\xa0\x95 -->
		<security:remember-me data-source-ref="dataSource" token-validity-seconds="2592000"/>
	```

### 3) [loginForm.jsp]
- \xec\x9e\x90\xeb\x8f\x99\xeb\xa1\x9c\xea\xb7\xb8\xec\x9d\xb8 \xec\xb2\xb4\xed\x81\xac\xeb\xb0\x95\xec\x8a\xa4\xec\x97\x90 `name="remember-me"` \xec\x84\xa4\xec\xa0\x95
	```jsp
	<input class="form-check-input" type="checkbox" name="remember-me" >\xec\x9e\x90\xeb\x8f\x99\xeb\xa1\x9c\xea\xb7\xb8\xec\x9d\xb8
	```

### 4) \xea\xb5\xac\xeb\x8f\x99 \xec\xb2\xb4\xed\x81\xac
- \xec\x9e\x90\xeb\x8f\x99\xeb\xa1\x9c\xea\xb7\xb8\xec\x9d\xb8 \xec\xb2\xb4\xed\x81\xac \xed\x9b\x84 \xeb\xa1\x9c\xea\xb7\xb8\xec\x9d\xb8 \xec\x8b\x9c `remember-me` \xec\xbf\xa0\xed\x82\xa4 \xec\x83\x9d\xec\x84\xb1\xeb\x90\x8c
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/99089584/221355994-d4fd38ec-d7a4-4f71-9143-40ec65fabe68.png)
- `persistent_logins` \xed\x85\x8c\xec\x9d\xb4\xeb\xb8\x94\xec\x97\x90 \xea\xb0\x92 \xeb\x93\xa4\xec\x96\xb4\xec\x98\xa8 \xea\xb2\x83 \xed\x99\x95\xec\x9d\xb8
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/99089584/221356043-d46ab4db-6b7e-40ac-b3b0-86c853196d4d.png)

### 5) \xeb\xa1\x9c\xea\xb7\xb8\xec\x95\x84\xec\x9b\x83 \xec\x8b\x9c \xec\xbf\xa0\xed\x82\xa4 \xec\x82\xad\xec\xa0\x9c
- \xec\x9e\x90\xeb\x8f\x99 \xeb\xa1\x9c\xea\xb7\xb8\xec\x9d\xb8 \xea\xb8\xb0\xeb\x8a\xa5\xec\x9d\xbc \xec\x9d\xb4\xec\x9a\xa9\xed\x95\x98\xeb\x8a\x94 \xea\xb2\xbd\xec\x9a\xb0\xec\x97\x90 \xec\x82\xac\xec\x9a\xa9\xec\x9e\x90\xea\xb0\x80 \xeb\xa1\x9c\xea\xb7\xb8\xec\x95\x84\xec\x9b\x83\xec\x9d\x84 \xed\x95\x98\xeb\xa9\xb4 \xec\x9e\x90\xeb\x8f\x99 \xeb\xa1\x9c\xea\xb7\xb8\xec\x9d\xb8\xec\x97\x90 \xec\x82\xac\xec\x9a\xa9\xed\x95\x98\xeb\x8a\x94 \xec\xbf\xa0\xed\x82\xa4\xeb\x8f\x84 \xec\x82\xad\xec\xa0\x9c\xed\x95\xb4 \xec\xa3\xbc\xeb\x8f\x84\xeb\xa1\x9d \xed\x95\xa8
- `delete-cookies="remember-me, JSESSION_ID"` \xec\x86\x8d\xec\x84\xb1 \xec\xb6\x94\xea\xb0\x80
	```xml
	<security:logout logout-url="/logout" invalidate-session="true" delete-cookies="remember-me, JSESSION_ID" />
	```

# 6. \xea\xb8\xb0\xec\xa1\xb4 \xed\x94\x84\xeb\xa1\x9c\xec\xa0\x9d\xed\x8a\xb8\xec\x97\x90 \xec\x8a\xa4\xed\x94\x84\xeb\xa7\x81 \xec\x8b\x9c\xed\x81\x90\xeb\xa6\xac\xed\x8b\xb0 \xec\xa0\x91\xeb\xaa\xa9\xed\x95\x98\xea\xb8\xb0
## 1) \xed\x8a\xb9\xec\xa0\x95 \xec\x9e\x91\xec\x97\x85 \xec\x8b\x9c(\xea\xb2\x8c\xec\x8b\x9c\xea\xb8\x80 \xec\x83\x9d\xec\x84\xb1, \xeb\x8f\x99\xec\x95\x84\xeb\xa6\xac \xec\x83\x9d\xec\x84\xb1 \xeb\x93\xb1) \xec\x8a\xa4\xed\x94\x84\xeb\xa7\x81 \xec\x8b\x9c\xed\x81\x90\xeb\xa6\xac\xed\x8b\xb0 \xec\xb2\x98\xeb\xa6\xac
- `@PreAuthorize("isAuthenticated()")` \xec\x96\xb4\xeb\x85\xb8\xed\x85\x8c\xec\x9d\xb4\xec\x85\x98 \xec\x82\xac\xec\x9a\xa9	
</br>	
\xe2\x86\x92 \xeb\xa1\x9c\xea\xb7\xb8\xec\x9d\xb8\xed\x95\x9c \xec\x82\xac\xec\x9a\xa9\xec\x9e\x90\xeb\xa7\x8c\xec\x9d\xb4 \xed\x95\xb4\xeb\x8b\xb9 \xea\xb8\xb0\xeb\x8a\xa5\xec\x9d\x84 \xec\x82\xac\xec\x9a\xa9\xed\x95\xa0 \xec\x88\x98 \xec\x9e\x88\xec\x9d\x8c.
- [ClubController.java]
	- \xeb\x8f\x99\xec\x95\x84\xeb\xa6\xac \xec\x83\x9d\xec\x84\xb1\xec\x9d\x80 \xeb\xa1\x9c\xea\xb7\xb8\xec\x9d\xb8\xed\x95\x9c \xec\x82\xac\xec\x9a\xa9\xec\x9e\x90\xeb\xa7\x8c \xed\x97\x88\xec\x9a\xa9
		```java
		@GetMapping("/club/createForm")
		@PreAuthorize("isAuthenticated()")
		public String clubCreateForm() {
			return "club/clubCreateForm";
		}
		```

## 2) \xea\xb2\x8c\xec\x8b\x9c\xeb\xac\xbc\xec\x9d\x98 \xec\x88\x98\xec\xa0\x95/\xec\x82\xad\xec\xa0\x9c
- \xec\x88\x98\xec\xa0\x95/\xec\x82\xad\xec\xa0\x9c \xeb\xa9\x94\xec\x84\x9c\xeb\x93\x9c\xeb\xa5\xbc \xec\x8b\xa4\xed\x96\x89\xed\x95\x98\xea\xb8\xb0 \xec\xa0\x84\xec\x97\x90 `@PreAuthorize` \xec\x9d\x84 \xec\x82\xac\xec\x9a\xa9\xed\x95\xa8\xec\x9c\xbc\xeb\xa1\x9c\xec\x8d\xa8 \xeb\xa1\x9c\xea\xb7\xb8\xec\x9d\xb8\xed\x95\x9c \xec\x82\xac\xec\x9a\xa9\xec\x9e\x90(=principal.username)\xec\x99\x80 \xed\x98\x84\xec\x9e\xac \xed\x8c\x8c\xeb\x9d\xbc\xeb\xaf\xb8\xed\x84\xb0\xeb\xa1\x9c \xec\xa0\x84\xeb\x8b\xac\xeb\x90\x98\xeb\x8a\x94 \xec\x9e\x91\xec\x84\xb1\xec\x9e\x90(writer)\xea\xb0\x80 \xec\x9d\xbc\xec\xb9\x98\xed\x95\x98\xeb\x8a\x94\xec\xa7\x80 \xec\xb2\xb4\xed\x81\xac.
- ex) `@PreAuthorize("principal.username == #writer")`
- `#writer`\xec\x9d\x98 `#`\xec\x9d\x80 \xed\x8c\x8c\xeb\x9d\xbc\xeb\xaf\xb8\xed\x84\xb0\xec\x97\x90 \xec\xa0\x91\xea\xb7\xbc\xed\x95\xa0 \xec\x88\x98 \xec\x9e\x88\xeb\x8a\x94 \xec\xa0\x91\xeb\x91\x90\xeb\xac\xb8\xec\x9e\x90\xeb\xa5\xbc \xec\x9d\x98\xeb\xaf\xb8.	
</br>	
\xe2\x86\x92 \xeb\x94\xb0\xeb\x9d\xbc\xec\x84\x9c `#writer`\xeb\x8a\x94 \xed\x8c\x8c\xeb\x9d\xbc\xeb\xaf\xb8\xed\x84\xb0\xeb\xa1\x9c \xec\xa0\x84\xeb\x8b\xac\xeb\x90\x98\xeb\x8a\x94 `writer`\xea\xb0\x9d\xec\xb2\xb4\xec\x9d\xb4 \xec\xa0\x91\xea\xb7\xbc\xed\x95\xa0 \xec\x88\x98 \xec\x9e\x88\xec\x9d\x8c.

## 3) Ajax\xec\x99\x80 \xec\x8a\xa4\xed\x94\x84\xeb\xa7\x81 \xec\x8b\x9c\xed\x81\x90\xeb\xa6\xac\xed\x8b\xb0 \xec\xb2\x98\xeb\xa6\xac
### 1. X-CSRF-TOKEN \xed\x97\xa4\xeb\x8d\x94 \xec\xa0\x84\xec\x86\xa1
\xec\x8a\xa4\xed\x94\x84\xeb\xa7\x81 \xec\x8b\x9c\xed\x81\x90\xeb\xa6\xac\xed\x8b\xb0\xea\xb0\x80 \xec\xa0\x81\xec\x9a\xa9\xeb\x90\x98\xeb\xa9\xb4 POST, PUT, PATCH, DELETE\xec\x99\x80 \xea\xb0\x99\xec\x9d\x80 \xeb\xb0\xa9\xec\x8b\x9d\xec\x9c\xbc\xeb\xa1\x9c \xeb\x8d\xb0\xec\x9d\xb4\xed\x84\xb0\xeb\xa5\xbc \xec\xa0\x84\xec\x86\xa1\xed\x95\x98\xeb\x8a\x94 \xea\xb2\xbd\xec\x9a\xb0\xec\x97\x90\xeb\x8a\x94 \xeb\xb0\x98\xeb\x93\x9c\xec\x8b\x9c \xec\xb6\x94\xea\xb0\x80\xec\xa0\x81\xec\x9c\xbc\xeb\xa1\x9c 'X-CSRF-TOKEN'\xea\xb3\xbc \xea\xb0\x99\xec\x9d\x80 \xed\x97\xa4\xeb\x8d\x94 \xec\xa0\x95\xeb\xb3\xb4\xeb\xa5\xbc \xec\xb6\x94\xea\xb0\x80\xed\x95\xb4\xec\x84\x9c CSRF \xed\x86\xa0\xed\x81\xb0\xea\xb0\x92\xec\x9d\x84 \xec\xa0\x84\xeb\x8b\xac\xed\x95\x98\xeb\x8f\x84\xeb\xa1\x9d \xec\x88\x98\xec\xa0\x95\xed\x95\xb4\xec\x95\xbc \xed\x95\xa8.

```jsp
var csrfHeaderName = "${_csrf.headerName}";	//X-CSRF-TOKEN
var csrfTokenValue = "${_csrf.token}";
```

### 2. ajaxSend()\xeb\xa5\xbc \xec\x82\xac\xec\x9a\xa9\xed\x95\xb4 \xeb\xaa\xa8\xeb\x93\xa0 Ajax \xec\xa0\x84\xec\x86\xa1 \xec\x8b\x9c CSRF \xed\x86\xa0\xed\x81\xb0\xec\x9d\x84 \xea\xb0\x99\xec\x9d\xb4 \xec\xa0\x84\xec\x86\xa1\xed\x95\x98\xeb\x8f\x84\xeb\xa1\x9d \xec\x84\xb8\xed\x8c\x85
```javascript
$(document).ajaxSend(function(e, xhr, options) {
	xhr.setRequestHeader(csrfHeaderName, csrfTokenValue);
});
```
