<!-- steps -->

<!--
## Set the security context for a Pod

To specify security settings for a Pod, include the `securityContext` field
in the Pod specification. The `securityContext` field is a
[PodSecurityContext](/docs/reference/generated/kubernetes-api/{{< param "version" >}}/#podsecuritycontext-v1-core) object.
The security settings that you specify for a Pod apply to all Containers in the Pod.
Here is a configuration file for a Pod that has a `securityContext` and an `emptyDir` volume:
-->
## \xe4\xb8\xba Pod \xe8\xae\xbe\xe7\xbd\xae\xe5\xae\x89\xe5\x85\xa8\xe6\x80\xa7\xe4\xb8\x8a\xe4\xb8\x8b\xe6\x96\x87   {#set-the-security-context-for-a-pod}

\xe8\xa6\x81\xe4\xb8\xba Pod \xe8\xae\xbe\xe7\xbd\xae\xe5\xae\x89\xe5\x85\xa8\xe6\x80\xa7\xe8\xae\xbe\xe7\xbd\xae\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\x8f\xaf\xe5\x9c\xa8 Pod \xe8\xa7\x84\xe7\xba\xa6\xe4\xb8\xad\xe5\x8c\x85\xe5\x90\xab `securityContext` \xe5\xad\x97\xe6\xae\xb5\xe3\x80\x82`securityContext` \xe5\xad\x97\xe6\xae\xb5\xe5\x80\xbc\xe6\x98\xaf\xe4\xb8\x80\xe4\xb8\xaa
[PodSecurityContext](/docs/reference/generated/kubernetes-api/{{< param "version" >}}/#podsecuritycontext-v1-core)
\xe5\xaf\xb9\xe8\xb1\xa1\xe3\x80\x82\xe4\xbd\xa0\xe4\xb8\xba Pod \xe6\x89\x80\xe8\xae\xbe\xe7\xbd\xae\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\xae\x89\xe5\x85\xa8\xe6\x80\xa7\xe9\x85\x8d\xe7\xbd\xae\xe4\xbc\x9a\xe5\xba\x94\xe7\x94\xa8\xe5\x88\xb0 Pod \xe4\xb8\xad\xe6\x89\x80\xe6\x9c\x89 Container \xe4\xb8\x8a\xe3\x80\x82
\xe4\xb8\x8b\xe9\x9d\xa2\xe6\x98\xaf\xe4\xb8\x80\xe4\xb8\xaa Pod \xe7\x9a\x84\xe9\x85\x8d\xe7\xbd\xae\xe6\x96\x87\xe4\xbb\xb6\xef\xbc\x8c\xe8\xaf\xa5 Pod \xe5\xae\x9a\xe4\xb9\x89\xe4\xba\x86 `securityContext` \xe5\x92\x8c\xe4\xb8\x80\xe4\xb8\xaa `emptyDir` \xe5\x8d\xb7\xef\xbc\x9a

{{< codenew file="pods/security/security-context.yaml" >}}

<!--
In the configuration file, the `runAsUser` field specifies that for any Containers in
the Pod, all processes run with user ID 1000. The `runAsGroup` field specifies the primary group ID of 3000 for
all processes within any containers of the Pod. If this field is omitted, the primary group ID of the containers
will be root(0). Any files created will also be owned by user 1000 and group 3000 when `runAsGroup` is specified.
Since `fsGroup` field is specified, all processes of the container are also part of the supplementary group ID 2000.
The owner for volume `/data/demo` and any files created in that volume will be Group ID 2000.

Create the Pod:
-->
\xe5\x9c\xa8\xe9\x85\x8d\xe7\xbd\xae\xe6\x96\x87\xe4\xbb\xb6\xe4\xb8\xad\xef\xbc\x8c`runAsUser` \xe5\xad\x97\xe6\xae\xb5\xe6\x8c\x87\xe5\xae\x9a Pod \xe4\xb8\xad\xe7\x9a\x84\xe6\x89\x80\xe6\x9c\x89\xe5\xae\xb9\xe5\x99\xa8\xe5\x86\x85\xe7\x9a\x84\xe8\xbf\x9b\xe7\xa8\x8b\xe9\x83\xbd\xe4\xbd\xbf\xe7\x94\xa8\xe7\x94\xa8\xe6\x88\xb7 ID 1000
\xe6\x9d\xa5\xe8\xbf\x90\xe8\xa1\x8c\xe3\x80\x82`runAsGroup` \xe5\xad\x97\xe6\xae\xb5\xe6\x8c\x87\xe5\xae\x9a\xe6\x89\x80\xe6\x9c\x89\xe5\xae\xb9\xe5\x99\xa8\xe4\xb8\xad\xe7\x9a\x84\xe8\xbf\x9b\xe7\xa8\x8b\xe9\x83\xbd\xe4\xbb\xa5\xe4\xb8\xbb\xe7\xbb\x84 ID 3000 \xe6\x9d\xa5\xe8\xbf\x90\xe8\xa1\x8c\xe3\x80\x82
\xe5\xa6\x82\xe6\x9e\x9c\xe5\xbf\xbd\xe7\x95\xa5\xe6\xad\xa4\xe5\xad\x97\xe6\xae\xb5\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\x88\x99\xe5\xae\xb9\xe5\x99\xa8\xe7\x9a\x84\xe4\xb8\xbb\xe7\xbb\x84 ID \xe5\xb0\x86\xe6\x98\xaf root\xef\xbc\x880\xef\xbc\x89\xe3\x80\x82
\xe5\xbd\x93 `runAsGroup` \xe8\xa2\xab\xe8\xae\xbe\xe7\xbd\xae\xe6\x97\xb6\xef\xbc\x8c\xe6\x89\x80\xe6\x9c\x89\xe5\x88\x9b\xe5\xbb\xba\xe7\x9a\x84\xe6\x96\x87\xe4\xbb\xb6\xe4\xb9\x9f\xe4\xbc\x9a\xe5\x88\x92\xe5\xbd\x92\xe7\x94\xa8\xe6\x88\xb7 1000 \xe5\x92\x8c\xe7\xbb\x84 3000\xe3\x80\x82
\xe7\x94\xb1\xe4\xba\x8e `fsGroup` \xe8\xa2\xab\xe8\xae\xbe\xe7\xbd\xae\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\xae\xb9\xe5\x99\xa8\xe4\xb8\xad\xe6\x89\x80\xe6\x9c\x89\xe8\xbf\x9b\xe7\xa8\x8b\xe4\xb9\x9f\xe4\xbc\x9a\xe6\x98\xaf\xe9\x99\x84\xe7\xbb\x84 ID 2000 \xe7\x9a\x84\xe4\xb8\x80\xe9\x83\xa8\xe5\x88\x86\xe3\x80\x82
\xe5\x8d\xb7 `/data/demo` \xe5\x8f\x8a\xe5\x9c\xa8\xe8\xaf\xa5\xe5\x8d\xb7\xe4\xb8\xad\xe5\x88\x9b\xe5\xbb\xba\xe7\x9a\x84\xe4\xbb\xbb\xe4\xbd\x95\xe6\x96\x87\xe4\xbb\xb6\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\xb1\x9e\xe4\xb8\xbb\xe9\x83\xbd\xe4\xbc\x9a\xe6\x98\xaf\xe7\xbb\x84 ID 2000\xe3\x80\x82

\xe5\x88\x9b\xe5\xbb\xba\xe8\xaf\xa5 Pod\xef\xbc\x9a

```shell
kubectl apply -f https://k8s.io/examples/pods/security/security-context.yaml
```

<!--
Verify that the Pod's Container is running:
-->
\xe6\xa3\x80\xe6\x9f\xa5 Pod \xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\xae\xb9\xe5\x99\xa8\xe5\xa4\x84\xe4\xba\x8e\xe8\xbf\x90\xe8\xa1\x8c\xe7\x8a\xb6\xe6\x80\x81\xef\xbc\x9a

```shell
kubectl get pod security-context-demo
```

<!--
Get a shell to the running Container:
-->
\xe5\xbc\x80\xe5\x90\xaf\xe4\xb8\x80\xe4\xb8\xaa Shell \xe8\xbf\x9b\xe5\x85\xa5\xe5\x88\xb0\xe8\xbf\x90\xe8\xa1\x8c\xe4\xb8\xad\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\xae\xb9\xe5\x99\xa8\xef\xbc\x9a

```shell
kubectl exec -it security-context-demo -- sh
```

<!--
In your shell, list the running processes:
-->
\xe5\x9c\xa8\xe4\xbd\xa0\xe7\x9a\x84 Shell \xe4\xb8\xad\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\x88\x97\xe4\xb8\xbe\xe8\xbf\x90\xe8\xa1\x8c\xe4\xb8\xad\xe7\x9a\x84\xe8\xbf\x9b\xe7\xa8\x8b\xef\xbc\x9a

```shell
ps
```

<!--
The output shows that the processes are running as user 1000, which is the value of `runAsUser`:
-->
\xe8\xbe\x93\xe5\x87\xba\xe6\x98\xbe\xe7\xa4\xba\xe8\xbf\x9b\xe7\xa8\x8b\xe4\xbb\xa5\xe7\x94\xa8\xe6\x88\xb7 1000 \xe8\xbf\x90\xe8\xa1\x8c\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\x8d\xb3 `runAsUser` \xe6\x89\x80\xe8\xae\xbe\xe7\xbd\xae\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\x80\xbc\xef\xbc\x9a

```none
PID   USER     TIME  COMMAND
    1 1000      0:00 sleep 1h
    6 1000      0:00 sh
...
```

<!--
In your shell, navigate to `/data`, and list the one directory:
-->
\xe5\x9c\xa8\xe4\xbd\xa0\xe7\x9a\x84 Shell \xe4\xb8\xad\xef\xbc\x8c\xe8\xbf\x9b\xe5\x85\xa5 `/data` \xe7\x9b\xae\xe5\xbd\x95\xe5\x88\x97\xe4\xb8\xbe\xe5\x85\xb6\xe5\x86\x85\xe5\xae\xb9\xef\xbc\x9a

```shell
cd /data
ls -l
```

<!--
The output shows that the `/data/demo` directory has group ID 2000, which is
the value of `fsGroup`.
-->
\xe8\xbe\x93\xe5\x87\xba\xe6\x98\xbe\xe7\xa4\xba `/data/demo` \xe7\x9b\xae\xe5\xbd\x95\xe7\x9a\x84\xe7\xbb\x84 ID \xe4\xb8\xba 2000\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\x8d\xb3 `fsGroup` \xe7\x9a\x84\xe8\xae\xbe\xe7\xbd\xae\xe5\x80\xbc\xef\xbc\x9a

```none
drwxrwsrwx 2 root 2000 4096 Jun  6 20:08 demo
```

<!--
In your shell, navigate to `/data/demo`, and create a file:
-->
\xe5\x9c\xa8\xe4\xbd\xa0\xe7\x9a\x84 Shell \xe4\xb8\xad\xef\xbc\x8c\xe8\xbf\x9b\xe5\x85\xa5\xe5\x88\xb0 `/data/demo` \xe7\x9b\xae\xe5\xbd\x95\xe4\xb8\x8b\xe5\x88\x9b\xe5\xbb\xba\xe4\xb8\x80\xe4\xb8\xaa\xe6\x96\x87\xe4\xbb\xb6\xef\xbc\x9a

```shell
cd demo
echo hello > testfile
```

<!--
List the file in the `/data/demo` directory:
-->
\xe5\x88\x97\xe4\xb8\xbe `/data/demo` \xe7\x9b\xae\xe5\xbd\x95\xe4\xb8\x8b\xe7\x9a\x84\xe6\x96\x87\xe4\xbb\xb6\xef\xbc\x9a

```shell
ls -l
```

<!--
The output shows that `testfile` has group ID 2000, which is the value of `fsGroup`.
-->
\xe8\xbe\x93\xe5\x87\xba\xe6\x98\xbe\xe7\xa4\xba `testfile` \xe7\x9a\x84\xe7\xbb\x84 ID \xe4\xb8\xba 2000\xef\xbc\x8c\xe4\xb9\x9f\xe5\xb0\xb1\xe6\x98\xaf `fsGroup` \xe6\x89\x80\xe8\xae\xbe\xe7\xbd\xae\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\x80\xbc\xef\xbc\x9a

```none
-rw-r--r-- 1 1000 2000 6 Jun  6 20:08 testfile
```

<!--
Run the following command:
-->
\xe8\xbf\x90\xe8\xa1\x8c\xe4\xb8\x8b\xe9\x9d\xa2\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\x91\xbd\xe4\xbb\xa4\xef\xbc\x9a

```shell
id
```

<!--
The output is similar to this:
-->
\xe8\xbe\x93\xe5\x87\xba\xe7\xb1\xbb\xe4\xbc\xbc\xe4\xba\x8e\xef\xbc\x9a

```none
uid=1000 gid=3000 groups=2000
```

<!--
From the output, you can see that `gid` is 3000 which is same as the `runAsGroup` field.
If the `runAsGroup` was omitted, the `gid` would remain as 0 (root) and the process will
be able to interact with files that are owned by the root(0) group and groups that have
the required group permissions for the root (0) group.

Exit your shell:
-->
\xe4\xbb\x8e\xe8\xbe\x93\xe5\x87\xba\xe4\xb8\xad\xe4\xbd\xa0\xe4\xbc\x9a\xe7\x9c\x8b\xe5\x88\xb0 `gid` \xe5\x80\xbc\xe4\xb8\xba 3000\xef\xbc\x8c\xe4\xb9\x9f\xe5\xb0\xb1\xe6\x98\xaf `runAsGroup` \xe5\xad\x97\xe6\xae\xb5\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\x80\xbc\xe3\x80\x82
\xe5\xa6\x82\xe6\x9e\x9c `runAsGroup` \xe8\xa2\xab\xe5\xbf\xbd\xe7\x95\xa5\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\x88\x99 `gid` \xe4\xbc\x9a\xe5\x8f\x96\xe5\x80\xbc 0\xef\xbc\x88root\xef\xbc\x89\xef\xbc\x8c\xe8\x80\x8c\xe8\xbf\x9b\xe7\xa8\x8b\xe5\xb0\xb1\xe8\x83\xbd\xe5\xa4\x9f\xe4\xb8\x8e root
\xe7\x94\xa8\xe6\x88\xb7\xe7\xbb\x84\xe6\x89\x80\xe6\x8b\xa5\xe6\x9c\x89\xe4\xbb\xa5\xe5\x8f\x8a\xe8\xa6\x81\xe6\xb1\x82 root \xe7\x94\xa8\xe6\x88\xb7\xe7\xbb\x84\xe8\xae\xbf\xe9\x97\xae\xe6\x9d\x83\xe9\x99\x90\xe7\x9a\x84\xe6\x96\x87\xe4\xbb\xb6\xe4\xba\xa4\xe4\xba\x92\xe3\x80\x82

\xe9\x80\x80\xe5\x87\xba\xe4\xbd\xa0\xe7\x9a\x84 Shell\xef\xbc\x9a

```shell
exit
```

<!--
## Configure volume permission and ownership change policy for Pods
-->
## \xe4\xb8\xba Pod \xe9\x85\x8d\xe7\xbd\xae\xe5\x8d\xb7\xe8\xae\xbf\xe9\x97\xae\xe6\x9d\x83\xe9\x99\x90\xe5\x92\x8c\xe5\xb1\x9e\xe4\xb8\xbb\xe5\x8f\x98\xe6\x9b\xb4\xe7\xad\x96\xe7\x95\xa5

{{< feature-state for_k8s_version="v1.23" state="stable" >}}

<!--
By default, Kubernetes recursively changes ownership and permissions for the contents of each
volume to match the `fsGroup` specified in a Pod's `securityContext` when that volume is
mounted.
For large volumes, checking and changing ownership and permissions can take a lot of time,
slowing Pod startup. You can use the `fsGroupChangePolicy` field inside a `securityContext`
to control the way that Kubernetes checks and manages ownership and permissions
for a volume.
-->
\xe9\xbb\x98\xe8\xae\xa4\xe6\x83\x85\xe5\x86\xb5\xe4\xb8\x8b\xef\xbc\x8cKubernetes \xe5\x9c\xa8\xe6\x8c\x82\xe8\xbd\xbd\xe4\xb8\x80\xe4\xb8\xaa\xe5\x8d\xb7\xe6\x97\xb6\xef\xbc\x8c\xe4\xbc\x9a\xe9\x80\x92\xe5\xbd\x92\xe5\x9c\xb0\xe6\x9b\xb4\xe6\x94\xb9\xe6\xaf\x8f\xe4\xb8\xaa\xe5\x8d\xb7\xe4\xb8\xad\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\x86\x85\xe5\xae\xb9\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\xb1\x9e\xe4\xb8\xbb\xe5\x92\x8c\xe8\xae\xbf\xe9\x97\xae\xe6\x9d\x83\xe9\x99\x90\xef\xbc\x8c
\xe4\xbd\xbf\xe4\xb9\x8b\xe4\xb8\x8e Pod \xe7\x9a\x84 `securityContext` \xe4\xb8\xad\xe6\x8c\x87\xe5\xae\x9a\xe7\x9a\x84 `fsGroup` \xe5\x8c\xb9\xe9\x85\x8d\xe3\x80\x82
\xe5\xaf\xb9\xe4\xba\x8e\xe8\xbe\x83\xe5\xa4\xa7\xe7\x9a\x84\xe6\x95\xb0\xe6\x8d\xae\xe5\x8d\xb7\xef\xbc\x8c\xe6\xa3\x80\xe6\x9f\xa5\xe5\x92\x8c\xe5\x8f\x98\xe6\x9b\xb4\xe5\xb1\x9e\xe4\xb8\xbb\xe4\xb8\x8e\xe8\xae\xbf\xe9\x97\xae\xe6\x9d\x83\xe9\x99\x90\xe5\x8f\xaf\xe8\x83\xbd\xe4\xbc\x9a\xe8\x8a\xb1\xe8\xb4\xb9\xe5\xbe\x88\xe9\x95\xbf\xe6\x97\xb6\xe9\x97\xb4\xef\xbc\x8c\xe9\x99\x8d\xe4\xbd\x8e Pod \xe5\x90\xaf\xe5\x8a\xa8\xe9\x80\x9f\xe5\xba\xa6\xe3\x80\x82
\xe4\xbd\xa0\xe5\x8f\xaf\xe4\xbb\xa5\xe5\x9c\xa8 `securityContext` \xe4\xb8\xad\xe4\xbd\xbf\xe7\x94\xa8 `fsGroupChangePolicy` \xe5\xad\x97\xe6\xae\xb5\xe6\x9d\xa5\xe6\x8e\xa7\xe5\x88\xb6 Kubernetes
\xe6\xa3\x80\xe6\x9f\xa5\xe5\x92\x8c\xe7\xae\xa1\xe7\x90\x86\xe5\x8d\xb7\xe5\xb1\x9e\xe4\xb8\xbb\xe5\x92\x8c\xe8\xae\xbf\xe9\x97\xae\xe6\x9d\x83\xe9\x99\x90\xe7\x9a\x84\xe6\x96\xb9\xe5\xbc\x8f\xe3\x80\x82

<!--
**fsGroupChangePolicy** -  `fsGroupChangePolicy` defines behavior for changing ownership
  and permission of the volume before being exposed inside a Pod.
  This field only applies to volume types that support `fsGroup` controlled ownership and permissions.
  This field has two possible values:

* _OnRootMismatch_: Only change permissions and ownership if the permission and the ownership of
  root directory does not match with expected permissions of the volume.
  This could help shorten the time it takes to change ownership and permission of a volume.
* _Always_: Always change permission and ownership of the volume when volume is mounted.

For example:
-->
**fsGroupChangePolicy** - `fsGroupChangePolicy` \xe5\xae\x9a\xe4\xb9\x89\xe5\x9c\xa8\xe5\x8d\xb7\xe8\xa2\xab\xe6\x9a\xb4\xe9\x9c\xb2\xe7\xbb\x99 Pod \xe5\x86\x85\xe9\x83\xa8\xe4\xb9\x8b\xe5\x89\x8d\xe5\xaf\xb9\xe5\x85\xb6
\xe5\x86\x85\xe5\xae\xb9\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\xb1\x9e\xe4\xb8\xbb\xe5\x92\x8c\xe8\xae\xbf\xe9\x97\xae\xe8\xae\xb8\xe5\x8f\xaf\xe8\xbf\x9b\xe8\xa1\x8c\xe5\x8f\x98\xe6\x9b\xb4\xe7\x9a\x84\xe8\xa1\x8c\xe4\xb8\xba\xe3\x80\x82\xe6\xad\xa4\xe5\xad\x97\xe6\xae\xb5\xe4\xbb\x85\xe9\x80\x82\xe7\x94\xa8\xe4\xba\x8e\xe9\x82\xa3\xe4\xba\x9b\xe6\x94\xaf\xe6\x8c\x81\xe4\xbd\xbf\xe7\x94\xa8 `fsGroup` \xe6\x9d\xa5
\xe6\x8e\xa7\xe5\x88\xb6\xe5\xb1\x9e\xe4\xb8\xbb\xe4\xb8\x8e\xe8\xae\xbf\xe9\x97\xae\xe6\x9d\x83\xe9\x99\x90\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\x8d\xb7\xe7\xb1\xbb\xe5\x9e\x8b\xe3\x80\x82\xe6\xad\xa4\xe5\xad\x97\xe6\xae\xb5\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\x8f\x96\xe5\x80\xbc\xe5\x8f\xaf\xe4\xbb\xa5\xe6\x98\xaf\xef\xbc\x9a

* `OnRootMismatch`\xef\xbc\x9a\xe5\x8f\xaa\xe6\x9c\x89\xe6\xa0\xb9\xe7\x9b\xae\xe5\xbd\x95\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\xb1\x9e\xe4\xb8\xbb\xe4\xb8\x8e\xe8\xae\xbf\xe9\x97\xae\xe6\x9d\x83\xe9\x99\x90\xe4\xb8\x8e\xe5\x8d\xb7\xe6\x89\x80\xe6\x9c\x9f\xe6\x9c\x9b\xe7\x9a\x84\xe6\x9d\x83\xe9\x99\x90\xe4\xb8\x8d\xe4\xb8\x80\xe8\x87\xb4\xe6\x97\xb6\xef\xbc\x8c
  \xe6\x89\x8d\xe6\x94\xb9\xe5\x8f\x98\xe5\x85\xb6\xe4\xb8\xad\xe5\x86\x85\xe5\xae\xb9\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\xb1\x9e\xe4\xb8\xbb\xe5\x92\x8c\xe8\xae\xbf\xe9\x97\xae\xe6\x9d\x83\xe9\x99\x90\xe3\x80\x82\xe8\xbf\x99\xe4\xb8\x80\xe8\xae\xbe\xe7\xbd\xae\xe6\x9c\x89\xe5\x8a\xa9\xe4\xba\x8e\xe7\xbc\xa9\xe7\x9f\xad\xe6\x9b\xb4\xe6\x94\xb9\xe5\x8d\xb7\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\xb1\x9e\xe4\xb8\xbb\xe4\xb8\x8e\xe8\xae\xbf\xe9\x97\xae
  \xe6\x9d\x83\xe9\x99\x90\xe6\x89\x80\xe9\x9c\x80\xe8\xa6\x81\xe7\x9a\x84\xe6\x97\xb6\xe9\x97\xb4\xe3\x80\x82
* `Always`\xef\xbc\x9a\xe5\x9c\xa8\xe6\x8c\x82\xe8\xbd\xbd\xe5\x8d\xb7\xe6\x97\xb6\xe6\x80\xbb\xe6\x98\xaf\xe6\x9b\xb4\xe6\x94\xb9\xe5\x8d\xb7\xe4\xb8\xad\xe5\x86\x85\xe5\xae\xb9\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\xb1\x9e\xe4\xb8\xbb\xe5\x92\x8c\xe8\xae\xbf\xe9\x97\xae\xe6\x9d\x83\xe9\x99\x90\xe3\x80\x82

\xe4\xbe\x8b\xe5\xa6\x82\xef\xbc\x9a

```yaml
securityContext:
  runAsUser: 1000
  runAsGroup: 3000
  fsGroup: 2000
  fsGroupChangePolicy: "OnRootMismatch"
```

<!--
This field has no effect on ephemeral volume types such as
[`secret`](/docs/concepts/storage/volumes/#secret),
[`configMap`](/docs/concepts/storage/volumes/#configmap),
and [`emptydir`](/docs/concepts/storage/volumes/#emptydir).
-->
{{< note >}}
\xe6\xad\xa4\xe5\xad\x97\xe6\xae\xb5\xe5\xaf\xb9\xe4\xba\x8e [`secret`](/zh-cn/docs/concepts/storage/volumes/#secret)\xe3\x80\x81
[`configMap`](/zh-cn/docs/concepts/storage/volumes/#configmap)
\xe5\x92\x8c [`emptydir`](/zh-cn/docs/concepts/storage/volumes/#emptydir)
\xe8\xbf\x99\xe7\xb1\xbb\xe4\xb8\xb4\xe6\x97\xb6\xe6\x80\xa7\xe5\xad\x98\xe5\x82\xa8\xe6\x97\xa0\xe6\x95\x88\xe3\x80\x82
{{< /note >}}

<!--
## Delegating volume permission and ownership change to CSI driver
-->
## \xe5\xb0\x86\xe5\x8d\xb7\xe6\x9d\x83\xe9\x99\x90\xe5\x92\x8c\xe6\x89\x80\xe6\x9c\x89\xe6\x9d\x83\xe6\x9b\xb4\xe6\x94\xb9\xe5\xa7\x94\xe6\xb4\xbe\xe7\xbb\x99 CSI \xe9\xa9\xb1\xe5\x8a\xa8\xe7\xa8\x8b\xe5\xba\x8f
{{< feature-state for_k8s_version="v1.26" state="stable" >}}

<!--
If you deploy a [Container Storage Interface (CSI)](https://github.com/container-storage-interface/spec/blob/master/spec.md)
driver which supports the `VOLUME_MOUNT_GROUP` `NodeServiceCapability`, the
process of setting file ownership and permissions based on the
`fsGroup` specified in the `securityContext` will be performed by the CSI driver
instead of Kubernetes. In this case, since Kubernetes doesn't perform any
ownership and permission change, `fsGroupChangePolicy` does not take effect, and
as specified by CSI, the driver is expected to mount the volume with the
provided `fsGroup`, resulting in a volume that is readable/writable by the
`fsGroup`.
-->
\xe5\xa6\x82\xe6\x9e\x9c\xe4\xbd\xa0\xe9\x83\xa8\xe7\xbd\xb2\xe4\xba\x86\xe4\xb8\x80\xe4\xb8\xaa[\xe5\xae\xb9\xe5\x99\xa8\xe5\xad\x98\xe5\x82\xa8\xe6\x8e\xa5\xe5\x8f\xa3 (CSI)](https://github.com/container-storage-interface/spec/blob/master/spec.md)
\xe9\xa9\xb1\xe5\x8a\xa8\xef\xbc\x8c\xe8\x80\x8c\xe8\xaf\xa5\xe9\xa9\xb1\xe5\x8a\xa8\xe6\x94\xaf\xe6\x8c\x81 `VOLUME_MOUNT_GROUP` `NodeServiceCapability`\xef\xbc\x8c
\xe5\x9c\xa8 `securityContext` \xe4\xb8\xad\xe6\x8c\x87\xe5\xae\x9a `fsGroup` \xe6\x9d\xa5\xe8\xae\xbe\xe7\xbd\xae\xe6\x96\x87\xe4\xbb\xb6\xe6\x89\x80\xe6\x9c\x89\xe6\x9d\x83\xe5\x92\x8c\xe6\x9d\x83\xe9\x99\x90\xe7\x9a\x84\xe8\xbf\x87\xe7\xa8\x8b\xe5\xb0\x86\xe7\x94\xb1 CSI
\xe9\xa9\xb1\xe5\x8a\xa8\xe8\x80\x8c\xe4\xb8\x8d\xe6\x98\xaf Kubernetes \xe6\x9d\xa5\xe6\x89\xa7\xe8\xa1\x8c\xe3\x80\x82\xe5\x9c\xa8\xe8\xbf\x99\xe7\xa7\x8d\xe6\x83\x85\xe5\x86\xb5\xe4\xb8\x8b\xef\xbc\x8c\xe7\x94\xb1\xe4\xba\x8e Kubernetes \xe4\xb8\x8d\xe6\x89\xa7\xe8\xa1\x8c\xe4\xbb\xbb\xe4\xbd\x95\xe6\x89\x80\xe6\x9c\x89\xe6\x9d\x83\xe5\x92\x8c\xe6\x9d\x83\xe9\x99\x90\xe6\x9b\xb4\xe6\x94\xb9\xef\xbc\x8c
`fsGroupChangePolicy` \xe4\xb8\x8d\xe4\xbc\x9a\xe7\x94\x9f\xe6\x95\x88\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\xb9\xb6\xe4\xb8\x94\xe6\x8c\x89\xe7\x85\xa7 CSI \xe7\x9a\x84\xe8\xa7\x84\xe5\xae\x9a\xef\xbc\x8cCSI \xe9\xa9\xb1\xe5\x8a\xa8\xe5\xba\x94\xe8\xaf\xa5\xe4\xbd\xbf\xe7\x94\xa8\xe6\x89\x80\xe6\x8c\x87\xe5\xae\x9a\xe7\x9a\x84
`fsGroup` \xe6\x9d\xa5\xe6\x8c\x82\xe8\xbd\xbd\xe5\x8d\xb7\xef\xbc\x8c\xe4\xbb\x8e\xe8\x80\x8c\xe7\x94\x9f\xe6\x88\x90\xe4\xba\x86\xe4\xb8\x80\xe4\xb8\xaa\xe5\xaf\xb9 `fsGroup` \xe5\x8f\xaf\xe8\xaf\xbb/\xe5\x8f\xaf\xe5\x86\x99\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\x8d\xb7.

<!--
## Set the security context for a Container

To specify security settings for a Container, include the `securityContext` field
in the Container manifest. The `securityContext` field is a
[SecurityContext](/docs/reference/generated/kubernetes-api/{{< param "version" >}}/#securitycontext-v1-core) object.
Security settings that you specify for a Container apply only to
the individual Container, and they override settings made at the Pod level when
there is overlap. Container settings do not affect the Pod's Volumes.

Here is the configuration file for a Pod that has one Container. Both the Pod
and the Container have a `securityContext` field:
-->
## \xe4\xb8\xba Container \xe8\xae\xbe\xe7\xbd\xae\xe5\xae\x89\xe5\x85\xa8\xe6\x80\xa7\xe4\xb8\x8a\xe4\xb8\x8b\xe6\x96\x87  {#set-the-security-context-for-a-container}

\xe8\x8b\xa5\xe8\xa6\x81\xe4\xb8\xba Container \xe8\xae\xbe\xe7\xbd\xae\xe5\xae\x89\xe5\x85\xa8\xe6\x80\xa7\xe9\x85\x8d\xe7\xbd\xae\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\x8f\xaf\xe4\xbb\xa5\xe5\x9c\xa8 Container \xe6\xb8\x85\xe5\x8d\x95\xe4\xb8\xad\xe5\x8c\x85\xe5\x90\xab `securityContext` 
\xe5\xad\x97\xe6\xae\xb5\xe3\x80\x82`securityContext` \xe5\xad\x97\xe6\xae\xb5\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\x8f\x96\xe5\x80\xbc\xe6\x98\xaf\xe4\xb8\x80\xe4\xb8\xaa
[SecurityContext](/docs/reference/generated/kubernetes-api/{{< param "version" >}}/#securitycontext-v1-core)
\xe5\xaf\xb9\xe8\xb1\xa1\xe3\x80\x82\xe4\xbd\xa0\xe4\xb8\xba Container \xe8\xae\xbe\xe7\xbd\xae\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\xae\x89\xe5\x85\xa8\xe6\x80\xa7\xe9\x85\x8d\xe7\xbd\xae\xe4\xbb\x85\xe9\x80\x82\xe7\x94\xa8\xe4\xba\x8e\xe8\xaf\xa5\xe5\xae\xb9\xe5\x99\xa8\xe6\x9c\xac\xe8\xba\xab\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\xb9\xb6\xe4\xb8\x94\xe6\x89\x80\xe6\x8c\x87\xe5\xae\x9a\xe7\x9a\x84\xe8\xae\xbe\xe7\xbd\xae\xe5\x9c\xa8\xe4\xb8\x8e
Pod \xe5\xb1\x82\xe9\x9d\xa2\xe8\xae\xbe\xe7\xbd\xae\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\x86\x85\xe5\xae\xb9\xe5\x8f\x91\xe7\x94\x9f\xe9\x87\x8d\xe5\x8f\xa0\xe6\x97\xb6\xef\xbc\x8c\xe4\xbc\x9a\xe9\x87\x8d\xe5\x86\x99 Pod \xe5\xb1\x82\xe9\x9d\xa2\xe7\x9a\x84\xe8\xae\xbe\xe7\xbd\xae\xe3\x80\x82Container \xe5\xb1\x82\xe9\x9d\xa2\xe7\x9a\x84\xe8\xae\xbe\xe7\xbd\xae\xe4\xb8\x8d\xe4\xbc\x9a\xe5\xbd\xb1\xe5\x93\x8d\xe5\x88\xb0 Pod \xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\x8d\xb7\xe3\x80\x82

\xe4\xb8\x8b\xe9\x9d\xa2\xe6\x98\xaf\xe4\xb8\x80\xe4\xb8\xaa Pod \xe7\x9a\x84\xe9\x85\x8d\xe7\xbd\xae\xe6\x96\x87\xe4\xbb\xb6\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\x85\xb6\xe4\xb8\xad\xe5\x8c\x85\xe5\x90\xab\xe4\xb8\x80\xe4\xb8\xaa Container\xe3\x80\x82Pod \xe5\x92\x8c Container \xe9\x83\xbd\xe6\x9c\x89
`securityContext` \xe5\xad\x97\xe6\xae\xb5\xef\xbc\x9a

{{< codenew file="pods/security/security-context-2.yaml" >}}

<!--
Create the Pod:
-->
\xe5\x88\x9b\xe5\xbb\xba\xe8\xaf\xa5 Pod\xef\xbc\x9a

```shell
kubectl apply -f https://k8s.io/examples/pods/security/security-context-2.yaml
```

<!--
Verify that the Pod's Container is running:
-->
\xe9\xaa\x8c\xe8\xaf\x81 Pod \xe4\xb8\xad\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\xae\xb9\xe5\x99\xa8\xe5\xa4\x84\xe4\xba\x8e\xe8\xbf\x90\xe8\xa1\x8c\xe7\x8a\xb6\xe6\x80\x81\xef\xbc\x9a

```shell
kubectl get pod security-context-demo-2
```

<!--
Get a shell into the running Container:
-->
\xe5\x90\xaf\xe5\x8a\xa8\xe4\xb8\x80\xe4\xb8\xaa Shell \xe8\xbf\x9b\xe5\x85\xa5\xe5\x88\xb0\xe8\xbf\x90\xe8\xa1\x8c\xe4\xb8\xad\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\xae\xb9\xe5\x99\xa8\xe5\x86\x85\xef\xbc\x9a

```shell
kubectl exec -it security-context-demo-2 -- sh
```

<!--
In your shell, list the running processes:
-->
\xe5\x9c\xa8\xe4\xbd\xa0\xe7\x9a\x84 Shell \xe4\xb8\xad\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\x88\x97\xe4\xb8\xbe\xe8\xbf\x90\xe8\xa1\x8c\xe4\xb8\xad\xe7\x9a\x84\xe8\xbf\x9b\xe7\xa8\x8b\xef\xbc\x9a

```shell
ps aux
```

<!--
The output shows that the processes are running as user 2000. This is the value
of `runAsUser` specified for the Container. It overrides the value 1000 that is
specified for the Pod.
-->

<!--
## Set capabilities for a Container

With [Linux capabilities](https://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man7/capabilities.7.html),
you can grant certain privileges to a process without granting all the privileges
of the root user. To add or remove Linux capabilities for a Container, include the
`capabilities` field in the `securityContext` section of the Container manifest.

First, see what happens when you don't include a `capabilities` field.
Here is configuration file that does not add or remove any Container capabilities:
-->
## \xe4\xb8\xba Container \xe8\xae\xbe\xe7\xbd\xae\xe6\x9d\x83\xe8\x83\xbd   {#set-capabilities-for-a-container}

\xe4\xbd\xa0\xe5\x8f\xaf\xe4\xbb\xa5\xe8\xb5\x8b\xe4\xba\x88\xe8\xbf\x9b\xe7\xa8\x8b root \xe7\x94\xa8\xe6\x88\xb7\xe6\x89\x80\xe6\x8b\xa5\xe6\x9c\x89\xe7\x9a\x84\xe6\x9f\x90\xe4\xba\x9b\xe7\x89\xb9\xe6\x9d\x83\xef\xbc\x8c\xe4\xbd\x86\xe4\xb8\x8d\xe5\xbf\x85\xe8\xb5\x8b\xe4\xba\x88\xe5\x85\xb6\xe5\x85\xa8\xe9\x83\xa8\xe7\x89\xb9\xe6\x9d\x83\xe3\x80\x82
\xe8\xa6\x81\xe4\xb8\xba Container \xe6\xb7\xbb\xe5\x8a\xa0\xe6\x88\x96\xe7\xa7\xbb\xe9\x99\xa4 Linux \xe6\x9d\x83\xe8\x83\xbd\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\x8f\xaf\xe4\xbb\xa5\xe5\x9c\xa8 Container \xe6\xb8\x85\xe5\x8d\x95\xe7\x9a\x84 `securityContext`
\xe8\x8a\x82\xe5\x8c\x85\xe5\x90\xab `capabilities` \xe5\xad\x97\xe6\xae\xb5\xe3\x80\x82

\xe9\xa6\x96\xe5\x85\x88\xef\xbc\x8c\xe7\x9c\x8b\xe4\xb8\x80\xe4\xb8\x8b\xe4\xb8\x8d\xe5\x8c\x85\xe5\x90\xab `capabilities` \xe5\xad\x97\xe6\xae\xb5\xe6\x97\xb6\xe5\x80\x99\xe4\xbc\x9a\xe5\x8f\x91\xe7\x94\x9f\xe4\xbb\x80\xe4\xb9\x88\xe3\x80\x82
\xe4\xb8\x8b\xe9\x9d\xa2\xe6\x98\xaf\xe4\xb8\x80\xe4\xb8\xaa\xe9\x85\x8d\xe7\xbd\xae\xe6\x96\x87\xe4\xbb\xb6\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\x85\xb6\xe4\xb8\xad\xe6\xb2\xa1\xe6\x9c\x89\xe6\xb7\xbb\xe5\x8a\xa0\xe6\x88\x96\xe7\xa7\xbb\xe9\x99\xa4\xe5\xae\xb9\xe5\x99\xa8\xe7\x9a\x84\xe6\x9d\x83\xe8\x83\xbd\xef\xbc\x9a

<!--
In the capability bitmap of the first container, bits 12 and 25 are clear. In the second container,
bits 12 and 25 are set. Bit 12 is `CAP_NET_ADMIN`, and bit 25 is `CAP_SYS_TIME`.
See [capability.h](https://github.com/torvalds/linux/blob/master/include/uapi/linux/capability.h)
for definitions of the capability constants.
-->
\xe5\x9c\xa8\xe7\xac\xac\xe4\xb8\x80\xe4\xb8\xaa\xe5\xae\xb9\xe5\x99\xa8\xe7\x9a\x84\xe6\x9d\x83\xe8\x83\xbd\xe4\xbd\x8d\xe5\x9b\xbe\xe4\xb8\xad\xef\xbc\x8c\xe4\xbd\x8d 12 \xe5\x92\x8c 25 \xe6\x98\xaf\xe6\xb2\xa1\xe6\x9c\x89\xe8\xae\xbe\xe7\xbd\xae\xe7\x9a\x84\xe3\x80\x82\xe5\x9c\xa8\xe7\xac\xac\xe4\xba\x8c\xe4\xb8\xaa\xe5\xae\xb9\xe5\x99\xa8\xe4\xb8\xad\xef\xbc\x8c\xe4\xbd\x8d 12
\xe5\x92\x8c 25 \xe6\x98\xaf\xe8\xae\xbe\xe7\xbd\xae\xe4\xba\x86\xe7\x9a\x84\xe3\x80\x82\xe4\xbd\x8d 12 \xe6\x98\xaf `CAP_NET_ADMIN` \xe8\x80\x8c\xe4\xbd\x8d 25 \xe5\x88\x99\xe6\x98\xaf `CAP_SYS_TIME`\xe3\x80\x82
\xe5\x8f\x82\xe8\xa7\x81 [capability.h](https://github.com/torvalds/linux/blob/master/include/uapi/linux/capability.h)
\xe4\xba\x86\xe8\xa7\xa3\xe6\x9d\x83\xe8\x83\xbd\xe5\xb8\xb8\xe6\x95\xb0\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\xae\x9a\xe4\xb9\x89\xe3\x80\x82

<!--
Linux capability constants have the form `CAP_XXX`.
But when you list capabilities in your container manifest, you must
omit the `CAP_` portion of the constant.
For example, to add `CAP_SYS_TIME`, include `SYS_TIME` in your list of capabilities.
-->
{{< note >}}
Linux \xe6\x9d\x83\xe8\x83\xbd\xe5\xb8\xb8\xe6\x95\xb0\xe5\xae\x9a\xe4\xb9\x89\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\xbd\xa2\xe5\xbc\x8f\xe4\xb8\xba `CAP_XXX`\xe3\x80\x82\xe4\xbd\x86\xe6\x98\xaf\xe4\xbd\xa0\xe5\x9c\xa8 container \xe6\xb8\x85\xe5\x8d\x95\xe4\xb8\xad\xe5\x88\x97\xe4\xb8\xbe\xe6\x9d\x83\xe8\x83\xbd\xe6\x97\xb6\xef\xbc\x8c
\xe8\xa6\x81\xe5\xb0\x86\xe6\x9d\x83\xe8\x83\xbd\xe5\x90\x8d\xe7\xa7\xb0\xe4\xb8\xad\xe7\x9a\x84 `CAP_` \xe9\x83\xa8\xe5\x88\x86\xe5\x8e\xbb\xe6\x8e\x89\xe3\x80\x82\xe4\xbe\x8b\xe5\xa6\x82\xef\xbc\x8c\xe8\xa6\x81\xe6\xb7\xbb\xe5\x8a\xa0 `CAP_SYS_TIME`\xef\xbc\x8c
\xe5\x8f\xaf\xe5\x9c\xa8\xe6\x9d\x83\xe8\x83\xbd\xe5\x88\x97\xe8\xa1\xa8\xe4\xb8\xad\xe6\xb7\xbb\xe5\x8a\xa0 `SYS_TIME`\xe3\x80\x82
{{< /note >}}

<!--
## Set the Seccomp Profile for a Container

To set the Seccomp profile for a Container, include the `seccompProfile` field
in the `securityContext` section of your Pod or Container manifest. The
`seccompProfile` field is a
[SeccompProfile](/docs/reference/generated/kubernetes-api/{{< param "version"
>}}/#seccompprofile-v1-core) object consisting of `type` and `localhostProfile`.
Valid options for `type` include `RuntimeDefault`, `Unconfined`, and
`Localhost`. `localhostProfile` must only be set if `type: Localhost`. It
indicates the path of the pre-configured profile on the node, relative to the
kubelet's configured Seccomp profile location (configured with the `--root-dir`
flag).

Here is an example that sets the Seccomp profile to the node's container runtime
default profile:
-->
## \xe4\xb8\xba\xe5\xae\xb9\xe5\x99\xa8\xe8\xae\xbe\xe7\xbd\xae Seccomp \xe9\x85\x8d\xe7\xbd\xae 

\xe8\x8b\xa5\xe8\xa6\x81\xe4\xb8\xba\xe5\xae\xb9\xe5\x99\xa8\xe8\xae\xbe\xe7\xbd\xae Seccomp \xe9\x85\x8d\xe7\xbd\xae\xef\xbc\x88Profile\xef\xbc\x89\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\x8f\xaf\xe5\x9c\xa8\xe4\xbd\xa0\xe7\x9a\x84 Pod \xe6\x88\x96 Container \xe6\xb8\x85\xe5\x8d\x95\xe7\x9a\x84
`securityContext` \xe8\x8a\x82\xe4\xb8\xad\xe5\x8c\x85\xe5\x90\xab `seccompProfile` \xe5\xad\x97\xe6\xae\xb5\xe3\x80\x82\xe8\xaf\xa5\xe5\xad\x97\xe6\xae\xb5\xe6\x98\xaf\xe4\xb8\x80\xe4\xb8\xaa 
[SeccompProfile](/docs/reference/generated/kubernetes-api/{{< param "version" >}}/#seccompprofile-v1-core)
\xe5\xaf\xb9\xe8\xb1\xa1\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\x8c\x85\xe5\x90\xab `type` \xe5\x92\x8c `localhostProfile` \xe5\xb1\x9e\xe6\x80\xa7\xe3\x80\x82
`type` \xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\x90\x88\xe6\xb3\x95\xe9\x80\x89\xe9\xa1\xb9\xe5\x8c\x85\xe6\x8b\xac `RuntimeDefault`\xe3\x80\x81`Unconfined` \xe5\x92\x8c `Localhost`\xe3\x80\x82
`localhostProfile` \xe5\x8f\xaa\xe8\x83\xbd\xe5\x9c\xa8 `type: Localhost` \xe9\x85\x8d\xe7\xbd\xae\xe4\xb8\x8b\xe6\x89\x8d\xe5\x8f\xaf\xe4\xbb\xa5\xe8\xae\xbe\xe7\xbd\xae\xe3\x80\x82
\xe8\xaf\xa5\xe5\xad\x97\xe6\xae\xb5\xe6\xa0\x87\xe6\x98\x8e\xe8\x8a\x82\xe7\x82\xb9\xe4\xb8\x8a\xe9\xa2\x84\xe5\x85\x88\xe8\xae\xbe\xe5\xae\x9a\xe7\x9a\x84\xe9\x85\x8d\xe7\xbd\xae\xe7\x9a\x84\xe8\xb7\xaf\xe5\xbe\x84\xef\xbc\x8c\xe8\xb7\xaf\xe5\xbe\x84\xe6\x98\xaf\xe7\x9b\xb8\xe5\xaf\xb9\xe4\xba\x8e kubelet \xe6\x89\x80\xe9\x85\x8d\xe7\xbd\xae\xe7\x9a\x84
Seccomp \xe9\x85\x8d\xe7\xbd\xae\xe8\xb7\xaf\xe5\xbe\x84\xef\xbc\x88\xe4\xbd\xbf\xe7\x94\xa8 `--root-dir` \xe8\xae\xbe\xe7\xbd\xae\xef\xbc\x89\xe8\x80\x8c\xe8\xa8\x80\xe7\x9a\x84\xe3\x80\x82

\xe4\xb8\x8b\xe9\x9d\xa2\xe6\x98\xaf\xe4\xb8\x80\xe4\xb8\xaa\xe4\xbe\x8b\xe5\xad\x90\xef\xbc\x8c\xe8\xae\xbe\xe7\xbd\xae\xe5\xae\xb9\xe5\x99\xa8\xe4\xbd\xbf\xe7\x94\xa8\xe8\x8a\x82\xe7\x82\xb9\xe4\xb8\x8a\xe5\xae\xb9\xe5\x99\xa8\xe8\xbf\x90\xe8\xa1\x8c\xe6\x97\xb6\xe7\x9a\x84\xe9\xbb\x98\xe8\xae\xa4\xe9\x85\x8d\xe7\xbd\xae\xe4\xbd\x9c\xe4\xb8\xba Seccomp \xe9\x85\x8d\xe7\xbd\xae\xef\xbc\x9a

```yaml
...
securityContext:
  seccompProfile:
    type: RuntimeDefault
```

<!--
Here is an example that sets the Seccomp profile to a pre-configured file at
`<kubelet-root-dir>/seccomp/my-profiles/profile-allow.json`:
-->
\xe4\xb8\x8b\xe9\x9d\xa2\xe6\x98\xaf\xe5\x8f\xa6\xe4\xb8\x80\xe4\xb8\xaa\xe4\xbe\x8b\xe5\xad\x90\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\xb0\x86 Seccomp \xe7\x9a\x84\xe6\xa0\xb7\xe6\x9d\xbf\xe8\xae\xbe\xe7\xbd\xae\xe4\xb8\xba\xe4\xbd\x8d\xe4\xba\x8e
`<kubelet-\xe6\xa0\xb9\xe7\x9b\xae\xe5\xbd\x95>/seccomp/my-profiles/profile-allow.json`
\xe7\x9a\x84\xe4\xb8\x80\xe4\xb8\xaa\xe9\xa2\x84\xe5\x85\x88\xe9\x85\x8d\xe7\xbd\xae\xe7\x9a\x84\xe6\x96\x87\xe4\xbb\xb6\xe3\x80\x82

```yaml
...
securityContext:
  seccompProfile:
    type: Localhost
    localhostProfile: my-profiles/profile-allow.json
```

<!--
## Assign SELinux labels to a Container

To assign SELinux labels to a Container, include the `seLinuxOptions` field in
the `securityContext` section of your Pod or Container manifest. The
`seLinuxOptions` field is an
[SELinuxOptions](/docs/reference/generated/kubernetes-api/{{< param "version" >}}/#selinuxoptions-v1-core)
object. Here's an example that applies an SELinux level:
-->
## \xe4\xb8\xba Container \xe8\xb5\x8b\xe4\xba\x88 SELinux \xe6\xa0\x87\xe7\xad\xbe

\xe8\x8b\xa5\xe8\xa6\x81\xe7\xbb\x99 Container \xe8\xae\xbe\xe7\xbd\xae SELinux \xe6\xa0\x87\xe7\xad\xbe\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\x8f\xaf\xe4\xbb\xa5\xe5\x9c\xa8 Pod \xe6\x88\x96 Container \xe6\xb8\x85\xe5\x8d\x95\xe7\x9a\x84
`securityContext` \xe8\x8a\x82\xe5\x8c\x85\xe5\x90\xab `seLinuxOptions` \xe5\xad\x97\xe6\xae\xb5\xe3\x80\x82
`seLinuxOptions` \xe5\xad\x97\xe6\xae\xb5\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\x8f\x96\xe5\x80\xbc\xe6\x98\xaf\xe4\xb8\x80\xe4\xb8\xaa
[SELinuxOptions](/docs/reference/generated/kubernetes-api/{{< param "version" >}}/#selinuxoptions-v1-core)
\xe5\xaf\xb9\xe8\xb1\xa1\xe3\x80\x82\xe4\xb8\x8b\xe9\x9d\xa2\xe6\x98\xaf\xe4\xb8\x80\xe4\xb8\xaa\xe5\xba\x94\xe7\x94\xa8 SELinux \xe6\xa0\x87\xe7\xad\xbe\xe7\x9a\x84\xe4\xbe\x8b\xe5\xad\x90\xef\xbc\x9a

```yaml
...
securityContext:
  seLinuxOptions:
    level: "s0:c123,c456"
```

<!--
To assign SELinux labels, the SELinux security module must be loaded on the host operating system.
-->
{{< note >}}
\xe8\xa6\x81\xe6\x8c\x87\xe5\xae\x9a SELinux\xef\xbc\x8c\xe9\x9c\x80\xe8\xa6\x81\xe5\x9c\xa8\xe5\xae\xbf\xe4\xb8\xbb\xe6\x93\x8d\xe4\xbd\x9c\xe7\xb3\xbb\xe7\xbb\x9f\xe4\xb8\xad\xe8\xa3\x85\xe8\xbd\xbd SELinux \xe5\xae\x89\xe5\x85\xa8\xe6\x80\xa7\xe6\xa8\xa1\xe5\x9d\x97\xe3\x80\x82
{{< /note >}}

<!--
### Efficient SELinux volume relabeling
-->
### \xe9\xab\x98\xe6\x95\x88\xe9\x87\x8d\xe6\x89\x93 SELinux \xe5\x8d\xb7\xe6\xa0\x87\xe7\xad\xbe

{{< feature-state for_k8s_version="v1.25" state="alpha" >}}

<!--
By default, the contrainer runtime recursively assigns SELinux label to all
files on all Pod volumes. To speed up this process, Kubernetes can change the
SELinux label of a volume instantly by using a mount option
`-o context=<label>`.
-->
\xe9\xbb\x98\xe8\xae\xa4\xe6\x83\x85\xe5\x86\xb5\xe4\xb8\x8b\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\xae\xb9\xe5\x99\xa8\xe8\xbf\x90\xe8\xa1\x8c\xe6\x97\xb6\xe9\x80\x92\xe5\xbd\x92\xe5\x9c\xb0\xe5\xb0\x86 SELinux \xe6\xa0\x87\xe7\xad\xbe\xe8\xb5\x8b\xe4\xba\x88\xe6\x89\x80\xe6\x9c\x89 Pod \xe5\x8d\xb7\xe4\xb8\x8a\xe7\x9a\x84\xe6\x89\x80\xe6\x9c\x89\xe6\x96\x87\xe4\xbb\xb6\xe3\x80\x82
\xe4\xb8\xba\xe4\xba\x86\xe5\x8a\xa0\xe5\xbf\xab\xe8\xaf\xa5\xe8\xbf\x87\xe7\xa8\x8b\xef\xbc\x8cKubernetes \xe4\xbd\xbf\xe7\x94\xa8\xe6\x8c\x82\xe8\xbd\xbd\xe5\x8f\xaf\xe9\x80\x89\xe9\xa1\xb9 `-o context=<label>` \xe5\x8f\xaf\xe4\xbb\xa5\xe7\xab\x8b\xe5\x8d\xb3\xe6\x94\xb9\xe5\x8f\x98\xe5\x8d\xb7\xe7\x9a\x84 SELinux \xe6\xa0\x87\xe7\xad\xbe\xe3\x80\x82

<!--
To benefit from this speedup, all these conditions must be met:
-->
\xe8\xa6\x81\xe4\xbd\xbf\xe7\x94\xa8\xe8\xbf\x99\xe9\xa1\xb9\xe5\x8a\xa0\xe9\x80\x9f\xe5\x8a\x9f\xe8\x83\xbd\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\xbf\x85\xe9\xa1\xbb\xe6\xbb\xa1\xe8\xb6\xb3\xe4\xb8\x8b\xe5\x88\x97\xe6\x9d\xa1\xe4\xbb\xb6\xef\xbc\x9a

<!--
* Alpha feature gates `ReadWriteOncePod` and `SELinuxMountReadWriteOncePod` must
  be enabled.
-->
* \xe5\xbf\x85\xe9\xa1\xbb\xe5\x90\xaf\xe7\x94\xa8 Alpha \xe7\x89\xb9\xe6\x80\xa7\xe9\x97\xa8\xe6\x8e\xa7 `ReadWriteOncePod` \xe5\x92\x8c `SELinuxMountReadWriteOncePod`\xe3\x80\x82

<!--
* Pod must use PersistentVolumeClaim with `accessModes: ["ReadWriteOncePod"]`.
-->
* Pod \xe5\xbf\x85\xe9\xa1\xbb\xe4\xbb\xa5 `accessModes: ["ReadWriteOncePod"]` \xe6\xa8\xa1\xe5\xbc\x8f\xe4\xbd\xbf\xe7\x94\xa8 PersistentVolumeClaim\xe3\x80\x82

<!--
* Pod (or all its Containers that use the PersistentVolumeClaim) must
  have `seLinuxOptions` set.
-->
* Pod\xef\xbc\x88\xe6\x88\x96\xe5\x85\xb6\xe4\xb8\xad\xe4\xbd\xbf\xe7\x94\xa8 PersistentVolumeClaim \xe7\x9a\x84\xe6\x89\x80\xe6\x9c\x89\xe5\xae\xb9\xe5\x99\xa8\xef\xbc\x89\xe5\xbf\x85\xe9\xa1\xbb\xe8\xae\xbe\xe7\xbd\xae `seLinuxOptions`\xe3\x80\x82

<!--
* The corresponding PersistentVolume must be either a volume that uses a
  {{< glossary_tooltip text="CSI" term_id="csi" >}} driver, or a volume that uses the
  legacy `iscsi` volume type.
  * If you use a volume backed by a CSI driver, that CSI driver must announce that it
    supports mounting with `-o context` by setting `spec.seLinuxMount: true` in
    its CSIDriver instance.
-->
* \xe5\xaf\xb9\xe5\xba\x94\xe7\x9a\x84 PersistentVolume \xe5\xbf\x85\xe9\xa1\xbb\xe6\x98\xaf\xe4\xbd\xbf\xe7\x94\xa8 {< glossary_tooltip text="CSI" term_id="csi" >}}
  \xe9\xa9\xb1\xe5\x8a\xa8\xe7\xa8\x8b\xe5\xba\x8f\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\x8d\xb7\xef\xbc\x8c\xe6\x88\x96\xe8\x80\x85\xe6\x98\xaf\xe4\xbc\xa0\xe7\xbb\x9f\xe7\x9a\x84 `iscsi` \xe5\x8d\xb7\xe7\xb1\xbb\xe5\x9e\x8b\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\x8d\xb7\xe3\x80\x82
  * \xe5\xa6\x82\xe6\x9e\x9c\xe4\xbd\xbf\xe7\x94\xa8\xe5\x9f\xba\xe4\xba\x8e CSI \xe9\xa9\xb1\xe5\x8a\xa8\xe7\xa8\x8b\xe5\xba\x8f\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\x8d\xb7\xef\xbc\x8cCSI \xe9\xa9\xb1\xe5\x8a\xa8\xe7\xa8\x8b\xe5\xba\x8f\xe5\xbf\x85\xe9\xa1\xbb\xe8\x83\xbd\xe5\xa4\x9f\xe9\x80\x9a\xe8\xbf\x87\xe5\x9c\xa8 CSIDriver
    \xe5\xae\x9e\xe4\xbe\x8b\xe4\xb8\xad\xe8\xae\xbe\xe7\xbd\xae `spec.seLinuxMount: true` \xe4\xbb\xa5\xe6\x94\xaf\xe6\x8c\x81 `-o context` \xe6\x8c\x82\xe8\xbd\xbd\xe3\x80\x82

<!--
For any other volume types, SELinux relabelling happens another way: the container
runtime  recursively changes the SELinux label for all inodes (files and directories)
in the volume.
The more files and directories in the volume, the longer that relabelling takes.
-->
\xe5\xaf\xb9\xe4\xba\x8e\xe6\x89\x80\xe6\x9c\x89\xe5\x85\xb6\xe4\xbb\x96\xe5\x8d\xb7\xe7\xb1\xbb\xe5\x9e\x8b\xef\xbc\x8c\xe9\x87\x8d\xe6\x89\x93 SELinux \xe6\xa0\x87\xe7\xad\xbe\xe7\x9a\x84\xe6\x96\xb9\xe5\xbc\x8f\xe6\x9c\x89\xe6\x89\x80\xe4\xb8\x8d\xe5\x90\x8c\xef\xbc\x9a
\xe5\xae\xb9\xe5\x99\xa8\xe8\xbf\x90\xe8\xa1\x8c\xe6\x97\xb6\xe4\xb8\xba\xe5\x8d\xb7\xe4\xb8\xad\xe7\x9a\x84\xe6\x89\x80\xe6\x9c\x89\xe8\x8a\x82\xe7\x82\xb9\xef\xbc\x88\xe6\x96\x87\xe4\xbb\xb6\xe5\x92\x8c\xe7\x9b\xae\xe5\xbd\x95\xef\xbc\x89\xe9\x80\x92\xe5\xbd\x92\xe5\x9c\xb0\xe4\xbf\xae\xe6\x94\xb9 SELinux \xe6\xa0\x87\xe7\xad\xbe\xe3\x80\x82
\xe5\x8d\xb7\xe4\xb8\xad\xe7\x9a\x84\xe6\x96\x87\xe4\xbb\xb6\xe5\x92\x8c\xe7\x9b\xae\xe5\xbd\x95\xe8\xb6\x8a\xe5\xa4\x9a\xef\xbc\x8c\xe9\x87\x8d\xe6\x89\x93\xe6\xa0\x87\xe7\xad\xbe\xe9\x9c\x80\xe8\xa6\x81\xe8\x80\x97\xe8\xb4\xb9\xe7\x9a\x84\xe6\x97\xb6\xe9\x97\xb4\xe5\xb0\xb1\xe8\xb6\x8a\xe9\x95\xbf\xe3\x80\x82

{{< note >}}
<!--
In Kubernetes 1.25, the kubelet loses track of volume labels after restart. In
other words, then kubelet may refuse to start Pods with errors similar to  "conflicting
SELinux labels of volume", while there are no conflicting labels in Pods. Make sure
nodes are
[fully drained](https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/administer-cluster/safely-drain-node/)
before restarting kubelet.
-->
\xe5\x9c\xa8 Kubernetes 1.25 \xe4\xb8\xad\xef\xbc\x8ckubelet \xe5\x9c\xa8\xe9\x87\x8d\xe5\x90\xaf\xe5\x90\x8e\xe4\xbc\x9a\xe4\xb8\xa2\xe5\xa4\xb1\xe5\xaf\xb9\xe5\x8d\xb7\xe6\xa0\x87\xe7\xad\xbe\xe7\x9a\x84\xe8\xbf\xbd\xe8\xb8\xaa\xe8\xae\xb0\xe5\xbd\x95\xe3\x80\x82
\xe6\x8d\xa2\xe8\xa8\x80\xe4\xb9\x8b\xef\xbc\x8ckubelet \xe5\x8f\xaf\xe8\x83\xbd\xe4\xbc\x9a\xe6\x8b\x92\xe7\xbb\x9d\xe5\x90\xaf\xe5\x8a\xa8 Pod\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\x8e\x9f\xe5\x9b\xa0\xe7\xb1\xbb\xe4\xbc\xbc\xe4\xba\x8e \xe2\x80\x9cconflicting
SELinux labels of volume\xe2\x80\x9d\xef\xbc\x8c
\xe4\xbd\x86\xe5\xae\x9e\xe9\x99\x85\xe4\xb8\x8a Pod \xe4\xb8\xad\xe5\xb9\xb6\xe6\xb2\xa1\xe6\x9c\x89\xe5\x86\xb2\xe7\xaa\x81\xe7\x9a\x84\xe6\xa0\x87\xe7\xad\xbe\xe3\x80\x82\xe5\x9c\xa8\xe9\x87\x8d\xe5\x90\xaf kubelet
\xe4\xb9\x8b\xe5\x89\x8d\xe7\xa1\xae\xe4\xbf\x9d\xe8\x8a\x82\xe7\x82\xb9\xe5\xb7\xb2\xe8\xa2\xab[\xe5\xae\x8c\xe5\x85\xa8\xe8\x85\xbe\xe7\xa9\xba](/zh-cn/docs/tasks/administer-cluster/safely-drain-node/)\xe3\x80\x82
{{< /note >}}

<!--
## Discussion

The security context for a Pod applies to the Pod's Containers and also to
the Pod's Volumes when applicable. Specifically `fsGroup` and `seLinuxOptions` are
applied to Volumes as follows:
-->
## \xe8\xae\xa8\xe8\xae\xba   {#discussion}

Pod \xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\xae\x89\xe5\x85\xa8\xe4\xb8\x8a\xe4\xb8\x8b\xe6\x96\x87\xe9\x80\x82\xe7\x94\xa8\xe4\xba\x8e Pod \xe4\xb8\xad\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\xae\xb9\xe5\x99\xa8\xef\xbc\x8c\xe4\xb9\x9f\xe9\x80\x82\xe7\x94\xa8\xe4\xba\x8e Pod \xe6\x89\x80\xe6\x8c\x82\xe8\xbd\xbd\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\x8d\xb7\xef\xbc\x88\xe5\xa6\x82\xe6\x9e\x9c\xe6\x9c\x89\xe7\x9a\x84\xe8\xaf\x9d\xef\xbc\x89\xe3\x80\x82
\xe5\xb0\xa4\xe5\x85\xb6\xe6\x98\xaf\xef\xbc\x8c`fsGroup` \xe5\x92\x8c `seLinuxOptions` \xe6\x8c\x89\xe4\xb8\x8b\xe9\x9d\xa2\xe7\x9a\x84\xe6\x96\xb9\xe5\xbc\x8f\xe5\xba\x94\xe7\x94\xa8\xe5\x88\xb0\xe6\x8c\x82\xe8\xbd\xbd\xe5\x8d\xb7\xe4\xb8\x8a\xef\xbc\x9a

<!--
* `fsGroup`: Volumes that support ownership management are modified to be owned
  and writable by the GID specified in `fsGroup`. See the
  [Ownership Management design document](https://git.k8s.io/design-proposals-archive/storage/volume-ownership-management.md)
  for more details.

* `seLinuxOptions`: Volumes that support SELinux labeling are relabeled to be accessible
  by the label specified under `seLinuxOptions`. Usually you only
  need to set the `level` section. This sets the
  [Multi-Category Security (MCS)](https://selinuxproject.org/page/NB_MLS)
  label given to all Containers in the Pod as well as the Volumes.
-->
* `fsGroup`\xef\xbc\x9a\xe6\x94\xaf\xe6\x8c\x81\xe5\xb1\x9e\xe4\xb8\xbb\xe7\xae\xa1\xe7\x90\x86\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\x8d\xb7\xe4\xbc\x9a\xe8\xa2\xab\xe4\xbf\xae\xe6\x94\xb9\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\xb0\x86\xe5\x85\xb6\xe5\xb1\x9e\xe4\xb8\xbb\xe5\x8f\x98\xe6\x9b\xb4\xe4\xb8\xba `fsGroup` \xe6\x89\x80\xe6\x8c\x87\xe5\xae\x9a\xe7\x9a\x84 GID\xef\xbc\x8c
  \xe5\xb9\xb6\xe4\xb8\x94\xe5\xaf\xb9\xe8\xaf\xa5 GID \xe5\x8f\xaf\xe5\x86\x99\xe3\x80\x82\xe8\xbf\x9b\xe4\xb8\x80\xe6\xad\xa5\xe7\x9a\x84\xe7\xbb\x86\xe8\x8a\x82\xe5\x8f\xaf\xe5\x8f\x82\xe9\x98\x85
  [\xe5\xb1\x9e\xe4\xb8\xbb\xe5\x8f\x98\xe6\x9b\xb4\xe8\xae\xbe\xe8\xae\xa1\xe6\x96\x87\xe6\xa1\xa3](https://git.k8s.io/design-proposals-archive/storage/volume-ownership-management.md)\xe3\x80\x82

* `seLinuxOptions`\xef\xbc\x9a\xe6\x94\xaf\xe6\x8c\x81 SELinux \xe6\xa0\x87\xe7\xad\xbe\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\x8d\xb7\xe4\xbc\x9a\xe8\xa2\xab\xe9\x87\x8d\xe6\x96\xb0\xe6\x89\x93\xe6\xa0\x87\xe7\xad\xbe\xef\xbc\x8c\xe4\xbb\xa5\xe4\xbe\xbf\xe5\x8f\xaf\xe8\xa2\xab `seLinuxOptions`
  \xe4\xb8\x8b\xe6\x89\x80\xe8\xae\xbe\xe7\xbd\xae\xe7\x9a\x84\xe6\xa0\x87\xe7\xad\xbe\xe8\xae\xbf\xe9\x97\xae\xe3\x80\x82\xe9\x80\x9a\xe5\xb8\xb8\xe4\xbd\xa0\xe5\x8f\xaa\xe9\x9c\x80\xe8\xa6\x81\xe8\xae\xbe\xe7\xbd\xae `level` \xe9\x83\xa8\xe5\x88\x86\xe3\x80\x82
  \xe8\xaf\xa5\xe9\x83\xa8\xe5\x88\x86\xe8\xae\xbe\xe7\xbd\xae\xe7\x9a\x84\xe6\x98\xaf\xe8\xb5\x8b\xe4\xba\x88 Pod \xe4\xb8\xad\xe6\x89\x80\xe6\x9c\x89\xe5\xae\xb9\xe5\x99\xa8\xe5\x8f\x8a\xe5\x8d\xb7\xe7\x9a\x84
  [\xe5\xa4\x9a\xe7\xb1\xbb\xe5\x88\xab\xe5\xae\x89\xe5\x85\xa8\xe6\x80\xa7\xef\xbc\x88Multi-Category Security\xef\xbc\x8cMCS)](https://selinuxproject.org/page/NB_MLS)\xe6\xa0\x87\xe7\xad\xbe\xe3\x80\x82

  <!--
  After you specify an MCS label for a Pod, all Pods with the same label can
  access the Volume. If you need inter-Pod protection, you must assign a unique
  MCS label to each Pod.
  -->
  {{< warning >}}
  \xe5\x9c\xa8\xe4\xb8\xba Pod \xe8\xae\xbe\xe7\xbd\xae MCS \xe6\xa0\x87\xe7\xad\xbe\xe4\xb9\x8b\xe5\x90\x8e\xef\xbc\x8c\xe6\x89\x80\xe6\x9c\x89\xe5\xb8\xa6\xe6\x9c\x89\xe7\x9b\xb8\xe5\x90\x8c\xe6\xa0\x87\xe7\xad\xbe\xe7\x9a\x84 Pod \xe5\x8f\xaf\xe4\xbb\xa5\xe8\xae\xbf\xe9\x97\xae\xe8\xaf\xa5\xe5\x8d\xb7\xe3\x80\x82
  \xe5\xa6\x82\xe6\x9e\x9c\xe4\xbd\xa0\xe9\x9c\x80\xe8\xa6\x81\xe8\xb7\xa8 Pod \xe7\x9a\x84\xe4\xbf\x9d\xe6\x8a\xa4\xef\xbc\x8c\xe4\xbd\xa0\xe5\xbf\x85\xe9\xa1\xbb\xe4\xb8\xba\xe6\xaf\x8f\xe4\xb8\xaa Pod \xe8\xb5\x8b\xe4\xba\x88\xe7\x8b\xac\xe7\x89\xb9\xe7\x9a\x84 MCS \xe6\xa0\x87\xe7\xad\xbe\xe3\x80\x82
  {{< /warning >}}

\xe5\x88\xa0\xe9\x99\xa4\xe4\xb9\x8b\xe5\x89\x8d\xe5\x88\x9b\xe5\xbb\xba\xe7\x9a\x84\xe6\x89\x80\xe6\x9c\x89 Pod\xef\xbc\x9a

```shell
kubectl delete pod security-context-demo
```

b'--- reviewers: - tallclair title: Pod Security Standards description: > A detailed look at the different policy levels defined in the Pod Security Standards. content_type: concept weight: 10 --- The Pod Security Standards define three different _policies_ to broadly cover the security spectrum. These policies are _cumulative_ and range from highly-permissive to highly-restrictive. This guide outlines the requirements of each policy. | Profile | Description | | ------ | ----------- | | Privileged | Unrestricted policy, providing the widest possible level of permissions. This policy allows for known privilege escalations. | | Baseline | Minimally restrictive policy which prevents known privilege escalations. Allows the default (minimally specified) Pod configuration. | | Restricted | Heavily restricted policy, following current Pod hardening best practices. | ## Profile Details ### Privileged **The _Privileged_ policy is purposely-open, and entirely unrestricted.** This type of policy is typically aimed at system- and infrastructure-level workloads managed by privileged, trusted users. The Privileged policy is defined by an absence of restrictions. Allow-by-default mechanisms (such as gatekeeper) may be Privileged by default. In contrast, for a deny-by-default mechanism (such as Pod Security Policy) the Privileged policy should disable all restrictions. ### Baseline **The _Baseline_ policy is aimed at ease of adoption for common containerized workloads while preventing known privilege escalations.** This policy is targeted at application operators and developers of non-critical applications. The following listed controls should be enforced/disallowed: {{< note >}} In this table, wildcards (`*`) indicate all elements in a list. For example, `spec.containers[*].securityContext` refers to the Security Context object for _all defined containers_. If any of the listed containers fails to meet the requirements, the entire pod will fail validation. {{< /note >}}
Baseline policy specification
Control Policy
HostProcess

Windows pods offer the ability to run HostProcess containers which enables privileged access to the Windows node. Privileged access to the host is disallowed in the baseline policy. {{< feature-state for_k8s_version="v1.23" state="beta" >}}

Restricted Fields

  • spec.securityContext.windowsOptions.hostProcess
  • spec.containers[*].securityContext.windowsOptions.hostProcess
  • spec.initContainers[*].securityContext.windowsOptions.hostProcess
  • spec.ephemeralContainers[*].securityContext.windowsOptions.hostProcess

Allowed Values

  • Undefined/nil
  • false
Host Namespaces

Sharing the host namespaces must be disallowed.

Restricted Fields

  • spec.hostNetwork
  • spec.hostPID
  • spec.hostIPC

Allowed Values

  • Undefined/nil
  • false
Privileged Containers

Privileged Pods disable most security mechanisms and must be disallowed.

Restricted Fields

  • spec.containers[*].securityContext.privileged
  • spec.initContainers[*].securityContext.privileged
  • spec.ephemeralContainers[*].securityContext.privileged

Allowed Values

  • Undefined/nil
  • false
Capabilities

Adding additional capabilities beyond those listed below must be disallowed.

Restricted Fields

  • spec.containers[*].securityContext.capabilities.add
  • spec.initContainers[*].securityContext.capabilities.add
  • spec.ephemeralContainers[*].securityContext.capabilities.add

Allowed Values

  • Undefined/nil
  • AUDIT_WRITE
  • CHOWN
  • DAC_OVERRIDE
  • FOWNER
  • FSETID
  • KILL
  • MKNOD
  • NET_BIND_SERVICE
  • SETFCAP
  • SETGID
  • SETPCAP
  • SETUID
  • SYS_CHROOT
HostPath Volumes

HostPath volumes must be forbidden.

Restricted Fields

  • spec.volumes[*].hostPath

Allowed Values

  • Undefined/nil
Host Ports

HostPorts should be disallowed entirely (recommended) or restricted to a known list

Restricted Fields

  • spec.containers[*].ports[*].hostPort
  • spec.initContainers[*].ports[*].hostPort
  • spec.ephemeralContainers[*].ports[*].hostPort

Allowed Values

  • Undefined/nil
  • Known list (not supported by the built-in Pod Security Admission controller)
  • 0
AppArmor

On supported hosts, the runtime/default AppArmor profile is applied by default. The baseline policy should prevent overriding or disabling the default AppArmor profile, or restrict overrides to an allowed set of profiles.

Restricted Fields

  • metadata.annotations["container.apparmor.security.beta.kubernetes.io/*"]

Allowed Values

  • Undefined/nil
  • runtime/default
  • localhost/*
SELinux

Setting the SELinux type is restricted, and setting a custom SELinux user or role option is forbidden.

Restricted Fields

  • spec.securityContext.seLinuxOptions.type
  • spec.containers[*].securityContext.seLinuxOptions.type
  • spec.initContainers[*].securityContext.seLinuxOptions.type
  • spec.ephemeralContainers[*].securityContext.seLinuxOptions.type

Allowed Values

  • Undefined/""
  • container_t
  • container_init_t
  • container_kvm_t

Restricted Fields

  • spec.securityContext.seLinuxOptions.user
  • spec.containers[*].securityContext.seLinuxOptions.user
  • spec.initContainers[*].securityContext.seLinuxOptions.user
  • spec.ephemeralContainers[*].securityContext.seLinuxOptions.user
  • spec.securityContext.seLinuxOptions.role
  • spec.containers[*].securityContext.seLinuxOptions.role
  • spec.initContainers[*].securityContext.seLinuxOptions.role
  • spec.ephemeralContainers[*].securityContext.seLinuxOptions.role

Allowed Values

  • Undefined/""
/proc Mount Type

The default /proc masks are set up to reduce attack surface, and should be required.

Restricted Fields

  • spec.containers[*].securityContext.procMount
  • spec.initContainers[*].securityContext.procMount
  • spec.ephemeralContainers[*].securityContext.procMount

Allowed Values

  • Undefined/nil
  • Default
Seccomp

Seccomp profile must not be explicitly set to Unconfined.

Restricted Fields

  • spec.securityContext.seccompProfile.type
  • spec.containers[*].securityContext.seccompProfile.type
  • spec.initContainers[*].securityContext.seccompProfile.type
  • spec.ephemeralContainers[*].securityContext.seccompProfile.type

Allowed Values

  • Undefined/nil
  • RuntimeDefault
  • Localhost
Sysctls

Sysctls can disable security mechanisms or affect all containers on a host, and should be disallowed except for an allowed "safe" subset. A sysctl is considered safe if it is namespaced in the container or the Pod, and it is isolated from other Pods or processes on the same Node.

Restricted Fields

  • spec.securityContext.sysctls[*].name

Allowed Values

  • Undefined/nil
  • kernel.shm_rmid_forced
  • net.ipv4.ip_local_port_range
  • net.ipv4.ip_unprivileged_port_start
  • net.ipv4.tcp_syncookies
  • net.ipv4.ping_group_range
### Restricted **The _Restricted_ policy is aimed at enforcing current Pod hardening best practices, at the expense of some compatibility.** It is targeted at operators and developers of security-critical applications, as well as lower-trust users. The following listed controls should be enforced/disallowed: {{< note >}} In this table, wildcards (`*`) indicate all elements in a list. For example, `spec.containers[*].securityContext` refers to the Security Context object for _all defined containers_. If any of the listed containers fails to meet the requirements, the entire pod will fail validation. {{< /note >}}
Restricted policy specification
Control Policy
Everything from the baseline profile.
Volume Types

The restricted policy only permits the following volume types.

Restricted Fields

  • spec.volumes[*]

Allowed Values

Every item in the spec.volumes[*] list must set one of the following fields to a non-null value:
  • spec.volumes[*].configMap
  • spec.volumes[*].csi
  • spec.volumes[*].downwardAPI
  • spec.volumes[*].emptyDir
  • spec.volumes[*].ephemeral
  • spec.volumes[*].persistentVolumeClaim
  • spec.volumes[*].projected
  • spec.volumes[*].secret
Privilege Escalation (v1.8+)

Privilege escalation (such as via set-user-ID or set-group-ID file mode) should not be allowed. This is Linux only policy in v1.25+ (spec.os.name != windows)

Restricted Fields

  • spec.containers[*].securityContext.allowPrivilegeEscalation
  • spec.initContainers[*].securityContext.allowPrivilegeEscalation
  • spec.ephemeralContainers[*].securityContext.allowPrivilegeEscalation

Allowed Values

  • false
Running as Non-root

Containers must be required to run as non-root users.

Restricted Fields

  • spec.securityContext.runAsNonRoot
  • spec.containers[*].securityContext.runAsNonRoot
  • spec.initContainers[*].securityContext.runAsNonRoot
  • spec.ephemeralContainers[*].securityContext.runAsNonRoot

Allowed Values

  • true
The container fields may be undefined/nil if the pod-level spec.securityContext.runAsNonRoot is set to true.
Running as Non-root user (v1.23+)

Containers must not set runAsUser to 0

Restricted Fields

  • spec.securityContext.runAsUser
  • spec.containers[*].securityContext.runAsUser
  • spec.initContainers[*].securityContext.runAsUser
  • spec.ephemeralContainers[*].securityContext.runAsUser

Allowed Values

  • any non-zero value
  • undefined/null
Seccomp (v1.19+)

Seccomp profile must be explicitly set to one of the allowed values. Both the Unconfined profile and the absence of a profile are prohibited. This is Linux only policy in v1.25+ (spec.os.name != windows)

Restricted Fields

  • spec.securityContext.seccompProfile.type
  • spec.containers[*].securityContext.seccompProfile.type
  • spec.initContainers[*].securityContext.seccompProfile.type
  • spec.ephemeralContainers[*].securityContext.seccompProfile.type

Allowed Values

  • RuntimeDefault
  • Localhost
The container fields may be undefined/nil if the pod-level spec.securityContext.seccompProfile.type field is set appropriately. Conversely, the pod-level field may be undefined/nil if _all_ container- level fields are set.
Capabilities (v1.22+)

Containers must drop ALL capabilities, and are only permitted to add back the NET_BIND_SERVICE capability. This is Linux only policy in v1.25+ (.spec.os.name != "windows")

Restricted Fields

  • spec.containers[*].securityContext.capabilities.drop
  • spec.initContainers[*].securityContext.capabilities.drop
  • spec.ephemeralContainers[*].securityContext.capabilities.drop

Allowed Values

  • Any list of capabilities that includes ALL

Restricted Fields

  • spec.containers[*].securityContext.capabilities.add
  • spec.initContainers[*].securityContext.capabilities.add
  • spec.ephemeralContainers[*].securityContext.capabilities.add

Allowed Values

  • Undefined/nil
  • NET_BIND_SERVICE
## Policy Instantiation Decoupling policy definition from policy instantiation allows for a common understanding and consistent language of policies across clusters, independent of the underlying enforcement mechanism. As mechanisms mature, they will be defined below on a per-policy basis. The methods of enforcement of individual policies are not defined here. [**Pod Security Admission Controller**](/docs/concepts/security/pod-security-admission/) - {{< example file="security/podsecurity-privileged.yaml" >}}Privileged namespace{{< /example >}} - {{< example file="security/podsecurity-baseline.yaml" >}}Baseline namespace{{< /example >}} - {{< example file="security/podsecurity-restricted.yaml" >}}Restricted namespace{{< /example >}} ### Alternatives {{% thirdparty-content %}} Other alternatives for enforcing policies are being developed in the Kubernetes ecosystem, such as: - [Kubewarden](https://github.com/kubewarden) - [Kyverno](https://kyverno.io/policies/pod-security/) - [OPA Gatekeeper](https://github.com/open-policy-agent/gatekeeper) ## Pod OS field Kubernetes lets you use nodes that run either Linux or Windows. You can mix both kinds of node in one cluster. Windows in Kubernetes has some limitations and differentiators from Linux-based workloads. Specifically, many of the Pod `securityContext` fields [have no effect on Windows](/docs/concepts/windows/intro/#compatibility-v1-pod-spec-containers-securitycontext). {{< note >}} Kubelets prior to v1.24 don't enforce the pod OS field, and if a cluster has nodes on versions earlier than v1.24 the restricted policies should be pinned to a version prior to v1.25. {{< /note >}} ### Restricted Pod Security Standard changes Another important change, made in Kubernetes v1.25 is that the _restricted_ Pod security has been updated to use the `pod.spec.os.name` field. Based on the OS name, certain policies that are specific to a particular OS can be relaxed for the other OS. #### OS-specific policy controls Restrictions on the following controls are only required if `.spec.os.name` is not `windows`: - Privilege Escalation - Seccomp - Linux Capabilities ## FAQ ### Why isn't there a profile between privileged and baseline? The three profiles defined here have a clear linear progression from most secure (restricted) to least secure (privileged), and cover a broad set of workloads. Privileges required above the baseline policy are typically very application specific, so we do not offer a standard profile in this niche. This is not to say that the privileged profile should always be used in this case, but that policies in this space need to be defined on a case-by-case basis. SIG Auth may reconsider this position in the future, should a clear need for other profiles arise. ### What's the difference between a security profile and a security context? [Security Contexts](/docs/tasks/configure-pod-container/security-context/) configure Pods and Containers at runtime. Security contexts are defined as part of the Pod and container specifications in the Pod manifest, and represent parameters to the container runtime. Security profiles are control plane mechanisms to enforce specific settings in the Security Context, as well as other related parameters outside the Security Context. As of July 2021, [Pod Security Policies](/docs/concepts/security/pod-security-policy/) are deprecated in favor of the built-in [Pod Security Admission Controller](/docs/concepts/security/pod-security-admission/). ### What about sandboxed Pods? There is not currently an API standard that controls whether a Pod is considered sandboxed or not. Sandbox Pods may be identified by the use of a sandboxed runtime (such as gVisor or Kata Containers), but there is no standard definition of what a sandboxed runtime is. The protections necessary for sandboxed workloads can differ from others. For example, the need to restrict privileged permissions is lessened when the workload is isolated from the underlying kernel. This allows for workloads requiring heightened permissions to still be isolated. Additionally, the protection of sandboxed workloads is highly dependent on the method of sandboxing. As such, no single recommended profile is recommended for all sandboxed workloads. '

--- Pod \xe5\xae\x89\xe5\x85\xa8\xe6\x80\xa7\xe6\xa0\x87\xe5\x87\x86\xe5\xae\x9a\xe4\xb9\x89\xe4\xba\x86\xe4\xb8\x89\xe7\xa7\x8d\xe4\xb8\x8d\xe5\x90\x8c\xe7\x9a\x84**\xe7\xad\x96\xe7\x95\xa5\xef\xbc\x88Policy\xef\xbc\x89**\xef\xbc\x8c\xe4\xbb\xa5\xe5\xb9\xbf\xe6\xb3\x9b\xe8\xa6\x86\xe7\x9b\x96\xe5\xae\x89\xe5\x85\xa8\xe5\xba\x94\xe7\x94\xa8\xe5\x9c\xba\xe6\x99\xaf\xe3\x80\x82 \xe8\xbf\x99\xe4\xba\x9b\xe7\xad\x96\xe7\x95\xa5\xe6\x98\xaf**\xe5\x8f\xa0\xe5\x8a\xa0\xe5\xbc\x8f\xe7\x9a\x84\xef\xbc\x88Cumulative\xef\xbc\x89**\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\xae\x89\xe5\x85\xa8\xe7\xba\xa7\xe5\x88\xab\xe4\xbb\x8e\xe9\xab\x98\xe5\xba\xa6\xe5\xae\xbd\xe6\x9d\xbe\xe8\x87\xb3\xe9\xab\x98\xe5\xba\xa6\xe5\x8f\x97\xe9\x99\x90\xe3\x80\x82 \xe6\x9c\xac\xe6\x8c\x87\xe5\x8d\x97\xe6\xa6\x82\xe8\xbf\xb0\xe4\xba\x86\xe6\xaf\x8f\xe4\xb8\xaa\xe7\xad\x96\xe7\x95\xa5\xe7\x9a\x84\xe8\xa6\x81\xe6\xb1\x82\xe3\x80\x82 | Profile | \xe6\x8f\x8f\xe8\xbf\xb0 | | ------ | ----------- | | Privileged | \xe4\xb8\x8d\xe5\x8f\x97\xe9\x99\x90\xe5\x88\xb6\xe7\x9a\x84\xe7\xad\x96\xe7\x95\xa5\xef\xbc\x8c\xe6\x8f\x90\xe4\xbe\x9b\xe6\x9c\x80\xe5\xa4\xa7\xe5\x8f\xaf\xe8\x83\xbd\xe8\x8c\x83\xe5\x9b\xb4\xe7\x9a\x84\xe6\x9d\x83\xe9\x99\x90\xe8\xae\xb8\xe5\x8f\xaf\xe3\x80\x82\xe6\xad\xa4\xe7\xad\x96\xe7\x95\xa5\xe5\x85\x81\xe8\xae\xb8\xe5\xb7\xb2\xe7\x9f\xa5\xe7\x9a\x84\xe7\x89\xb9\xe6\x9d\x83\xe6\x8f\x90\xe5\x8d\x87\xe3\x80\x82 | | Baseline | \xe9\x99\x90\xe5\x88\xb6\xe6\x80\xa7\xe6\x9c\x80\xe5\xbc\xb1\xe7\x9a\x84\xe7\xad\x96\xe7\x95\xa5\xef\xbc\x8c\xe7\xa6\x81\xe6\xad\xa2\xe5\xb7\xb2\xe7\x9f\xa5\xe7\x9a\x84\xe7\xad\x96\xe7\x95\xa5\xe6\x8f\x90\xe5\x8d\x87\xe3\x80\x82\xe5\x85\x81\xe8\xae\xb8\xe4\xbd\xbf\xe7\x94\xa8\xe9\xbb\x98\xe8\xae\xa4\xe7\x9a\x84\xef\xbc\x88\xe8\xa7\x84\xe5\xae\x9a\xe6\x9c\x80\xe5\xb0\x91\xef\xbc\x89Pod \xe9\x85\x8d\xe7\xbd\xae\xe3\x80\x82 | | Restricted | \xe9\x99\x90\xe5\x88\xb6\xe6\x80\xa7\xe9\x9d\x9e\xe5\xb8\xb8\xe5\xbc\xba\xe7\x9a\x84\xe7\xad\x96\xe7\x95\xa5\xef\xbc\x8c\xe9\x81\xb5\xe5\xbe\xaa\xe5\xbd\x93\xe5\x89\x8d\xe7\x9a\x84\xe4\xbf\x9d\xe6\x8a\xa4 Pod \xe7\x9a\x84\xe6\x9c\x80\xe4\xbd\xb3\xe5\xae\x9e\xe8\xb7\xb5\xe3\x80\x82 | ## Profile \xe7\xbb\x86\xe8\x8a\x82 {#profile-details} ### Privileged **_Privileged_ \xe7\xad\x96\xe7\x95\xa5\xe6\x98\xaf\xe6\x9c\x89\xe7\x9b\xae\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\x9c\xb0\xe5\xbc\x80\xe6\x94\xbe\xe4\xb8\x94\xe5\xae\x8c\xe5\x85\xa8\xe6\x97\xa0\xe9\x99\x90\xe5\x88\xb6\xe7\x9a\x84\xe7\xad\x96\xe7\x95\xa5\xe3\x80\x82** \xe6\xad\xa4\xe7\xb1\xbb\xe7\xad\x96\xe7\x95\xa5\xe9\x80\x9a\xe5\xb8\xb8\xe9\x92\x88\xe5\xaf\xb9\xe7\x94\xb1\xe7\x89\xb9\xe6\x9d\x83\xe8\xbe\x83\xe9\xab\x98\xe3\x80\x81\xe5\x8f\x97\xe4\xbf\xa1\xe4\xbb\xbb\xe7\x9a\x84\xe7\x94\xa8\xe6\x88\xb7\xe6\x89\x80\xe7\xae\xa1\xe7\x90\x86\xe7\x9a\x84\xe7\xb3\xbb\xe7\xbb\x9f\xe7\xba\xa7\xe6\x88\x96\xe5\x9f\xba\xe7\xa1\x80\xe8\xae\xbe\xe6\x96\xbd\xe7\xba\xa7\xe8\xb4\x9f\xe8\xbd\xbd\xe3\x80\x82 Privileged title: Migrating telemetry and security agents from dockershim
content_type: task 
reviewers:
- SergeyKanzhelev

{{% thirdparty-content %}}

<!-- 
Kubernetes' support for direct integration with Docker Engine is deprecated and
has been removed. Most apps do not have a direct dependency on runtime hosting
containers. However, there are still a lot of telemetry and monitoring agents
that have a dependency on Docker to collect containers metadata, logs, and
metrics. This document aggregates information on how to detect these
dependencies as well as links on how to migrate these agents to use generic tools or
alternative runtimes.
-->
Kubernetes \xe5\xaf\xb9\xe4\xb8\x8e Docker Engine \xe7\x9b\xb4\xe6\x8e\xa5\xe9\x9b\x86\xe6\x88\x90\xe7\x9a\x84\xe6\x94\xaf\xe6\x8c\x81\xe5\xb7\xb2\xe8\xa2\xab\xe5\xbc\x83\xe7\x94\xa8\xe4\xb8\x94\xe5\xb7\xb2\xe7\xbb\x8f\xe8\xa2\xab\xe5\x88\xa0\xe9\x99\xa4\xe3\x80\x82
\xe5\xa4\xa7\xe5\xa4\x9a\xe6\x95\xb0\xe5\xba\x94\xe7\x94\xa8\xe7\xa8\x8b\xe5\xba\x8f\xe4\xb8\x8d\xe7\x9b\xb4\xe6\x8e\xa5\xe4\xbe\x9d\xe8\xb5\x96\xe4\xba\x8e\xe6\x89\x98\xe7\xae\xa1\xe5\xae\xb9\xe5\x99\xa8\xe7\x9a\x84\xe8\xbf\x90\xe8\xa1\x8c\xe6\x97\xb6\xe3\x80\x82\xe4\xbd\x86\xe6\x98\xaf\xef\xbc\x8c\xe4\xbb\x8d\xe7\x84\xb6\xe6\x9c\x89\xe5\xa4\xa7\xe9\x87\x8f\xe7\x9a\x84\xe9\x81\xa5\xe6\xb5\x8b\xe5\x92\x8c\xe7\x9b\x91\xe6\x8e\xa7\xe4\xbb\xa3\xe7\x90\x86\xe4\xbe\x9d\xe8\xb5\x96
docker \xe6\x9d\xa5\xe6\x94\xb6\xe9\x9b\x86\xe5\xae\xb9\xe5\x99\xa8\xe5\x85\x83\xe6\x95\xb0\xe6\x8d\xae\xe3\x80\x81\xe6\x97\xa5\xe5\xbf\x97\xe5\x92\x8c\xe6\x8c\x87\xe6\xa0\x87\xe3\x80\x82
\xe6\x9c\xac\xe6\x96\x87\xe6\xb1\x87\xe6\x80\xbb\xe4\xba\x86\xe4\xb8\x80\xe4\xba\x9b\xe4\xbf\xa1\xe6\x81\xaf\xe5\x92\x8c\xe9\x93\xbe\xe6\x8e\xa5\xef\xbc\x9a\xe4\xbf\xa1\xe6\x81\xaf\xe7\x94\xa8\xe4\xba\x8e\xe9\x98\x90\xe8\xbf\xb0\xe5\xa6\x82\xe4\xbd\x95\xe6\x8e\xa2\xe6\x9f\xa5\xe8\xbf\x99\xe4\xba\x9b\xe4\xbe\x9d\xe8\xb5\x96\xef\xbc\x8c\xe9\x93\xbe\xe6\x8e\xa5\xe7\x94\xa8\xe4\xba\x8e\xe8\xa7\xa3\xe9\x87\x8a\xe5\xa6\x82\xe4\xbd\x95\xe8\xbf\x81\xe7\xa7\xbb\xe8\xbf\x99\xe4\xba\x9b\xe4\xbb\xa3\xe7\x90\x86\xe5\x8e\xbb\xe4\xbd\xbf\xe7\x94\xa8\xe9\x80\x9a\xe7\x94\xa8\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\xb7\xa5\xe5\x85\xb7\xe6\x88\x96\xe5\x85\xb6\xe4\xbb\x96\xe5\xae\xb9\xe5\x99\xa8\xe8\xbf\x90\xe8\xa1\x8c\xe3\x80\x82

<!-- 
## Telemetry and security agents 
-->
## \xe9\x81\xa5\xe6\xb5\x8b\xe5\x92\x8c\xe5\xae\x89\xe5\x85\xa8\xe4\xbb\xa3\xe7\x90\x86 {#telemetry-and-security-agents}

<!-- 
Within a Kubernetes cluster there are a few different ways to run telemetry or security agents.
Some agents have a direct dependency on Docker Engine when they run as DaemonSets or
directly on nodes.
-->
\xe5\x9c\xa8 Kubernetes \xe9\x9b\x86\xe7\xbe\xa4\xe4\xb8\xad\xef\xbc\x8c\xe6\x9c\x89\xe5\x87\xa0\xe7\xa7\x8d\xe4\xb8\x8d\xe5\x90\x8c\xe7\x9a\x84\xe6\x96\xb9\xe5\xbc\x8f\xe6\x9d\xa5\xe8\xbf\x90\xe8\xa1\x8c\xe9\x81\xa5\xe6\xb5\x8b\xe6\x88\x96\xe5\xae\x89\xe5\x85\xa8\xe4\xbb\xa3\xe7\x90\x86\xe3\x80\x82
\xe4\xb8\x80\xe4\xba\x9b\xe4\xbb\xa3\xe7\x90\x86\xe5\x9c\xa8\xe4\xbb\xa5 DaemonSet \xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\xbd\xa2\xe5\xbc\x8f\xe8\xbf\x90\xe8\xa1\x8c\xe6\x88\x96\xe7\x9b\xb4\xe6\x8e\xa5\xe5\x9c\xa8\xe8\x8a\x82\xe7\x82\xb9\xe4\xb8\x8a\xe8\xbf\x90\xe8\xa1\x8c\xe6\x97\xb6\xef\xbc\x8c\xe7\x9b\xb4\xe6\x8e\xa5\xe4\xbe\x9d\xe8\xb5\x96\xe4\xba\x8e Docker Engine\xe3\x80\x82

<!-- 
###  Why do some telemetry agents communicate with Docker Engine?
-->
### \xe4\xb8\xba\xe4\xbb\x80\xe4\xb9\x88\xe6\x9c\x89\xe4\xba\x9b\xe9\x81\xa5\xe6\xb5\x8b\xe4\xbb\xa3\xe7\x90\x86\xe4\xbc\x9a\xe4\xb8\x8e Docker Engine \xe9\x80\x9a\xe4\xbf\xa1\xef\xbc\x9f

<!-- 
Historically, Kubernetes was written to work specifically with Docker Engine.
Kubernetes took care of networking and scheduling, relying on Docker Engine for launching
and running containers (within Pods) on a node. Some information that is relevant to telemetry,
such as a pod name, is only available from Kubernetes components. Other data, such as container
metrics, is not the responsibility of the container runtime. Early telemetry agents needed to query the
container runtime **and** Kubernetes to report an accurate picture. Over time, Kubernetes gained
the ability to support multiple runtimes, and now supports any runtime that is compatible with
the [container runtime interface](/docs/concepts/architecture/cri/).
-->
\xe4\xbb\x8e\xe5\x8e\x86\xe5\x8f\xb2\xe4\xb8\x8a\xe7\x9c\x8b\xef\xbc\x8cKubernetes \xe6\x98\xaf\xe4\xb8\x93\xe9\x97\xa8\xe4\xb8\xba\xe4\xb8\x8e Docker Engine \xe4\xb8\x80\xe8\xb5\xb7\xe5\xb7\xa5\xe4\xbd\x9c\xe8\x80\x8c\xe7\xbc\x96\xe5\x86\x99\xe7\x9a\x84\xe3\x80\x82
Kubernetes \xe8\xb4\x9f\xe8\xb4\xa3\xe7\xbd\x91\xe7\xbb\x9c\xe5\x92\x8c\xe8\xb0\x83\xe5\xba\xa6\xef\xbc\x8c\xe4\xbe\x9d\xe9\x9d\xa0 Docker Engine
\xe5\x9c\xa8\xe8\x8a\x82\xe7\x82\xb9\xe4\xb8\x8a\xe5\x90\xaf\xe5\x8a\xa8\xe5\xb9\xb6\xe8\xbf\x90\xe8\xa1\x8c\xe5\xae\xb9\xe5\x99\xa8\xef\xbc\x88\xe5\x9c\xa8 Pod \xe5\x86\x85\xef\xbc\x89\xe3\x80\x82\xe4\xb8\x80\xe4\xba\x9b\xe4\xb8\x8e\xe9\x81\xa5\xe6\xb5\x8b\xe7\x9b\xb8\xe5\x85\xb3\xe7\x9a\x84\xe4\xbf\xa1\xe6\x81\xaf\xef\xbc\x8c\xe4\xbe\x8b\xe5\xa6\x82 pod \xe5\x90\x8d\xe7\xa7\xb0\xef\xbc\x8c
\xe5\x8f\xaa\xe8\x83\xbd\xe4\xbb\x8e Kubernetes \xe7\xbb\x84\xe4\xbb\xb6\xe4\xb8\xad\xe8\x8e\xb7\xe5\xbe\x97\xe3\x80\x82\xe5\x85\xb6\xe4\xbb\x96\xe6\x95\xb0\xe6\x8d\xae\xef\xbc\x8c\xe4\xbe\x8b\xe5\xa6\x82\xe5\xae\xb9\xe5\x99\xa8\xe6\x8c\x87\xe6\xa0\x87\xef\xbc\x8c\xe4\xb8\x8d\xe6\x98\xaf\xe5\xae\xb9\xe5\x99\xa8\xe8\xbf\x90\xe8\xa1\x8c\xe6\x97\xb6\xe7\x9a\x84\xe8\xb4\xa3\xe4\xbb\xbb\xe3\x80\x82
\xe6\x97\xa9\xe6\x9c\x9f\xe9\x81\xa5\xe6\xb5\x8b\xe4\xbb\xa3\xe7\x90\x86\xe9\x9c\x80\xe8\xa6\x81\xe6\x9f\xa5\xe8\xaf\xa2\xe5\xae\xb9\xe5\x99\xa8\xe8\xbf\x90\xe8\xa1\x8c\xe6\x97\xb6**\xe5\x92\x8c** Kubernetes \xe4\xbb\xa5\xe6\x8a\xa5\xe5\x91\x8a\xe5\x87\x86\xe7\xa1\xae\xe7\x9a\x84\xe4\xbf\xa1\xe6\x81\xaf\xe3\x80\x82
\xe9\x9a\x8f\xe7\x9d\x80\xe6\x97\xb6\xe9\x97\xb4\xe7\x9a\x84\xe6\x8e\xa8\xe7\xa7\xbb\xef\xbc\x8cKubernetes \xe8\x8e\xb7\xe5\xbe\x97\xe4\xba\x86\xe6\x94\xaf\xe6\x8c\x81\xe5\xa4\x9a\xe7\xa7\x8d\xe8\xbf\x90\xe8\xa1\x8c\xe6\x97\xb6\xe7\x9a\x84\xe8\x83\xbd\xe5\x8a\x9b\xef\xbc\x8c
\xe7\x8e\xb0\xe5\x9c\xa8\xe6\x94\xaf\xe6\x8c\x81\xe4\xbb\xbb\xe4\xbd\x95\xe5\x85\xbc\xe5\xae\xb9[\xe5\xae\xb9\xe5\x99\xa8\xe8\xbf\x90\xe8\xa1\x8c\xe6\x97\xb6\xe6\x8e\xa5\xe5\x8f\xa3](/zh-cn/docs/concepts/architecture/cri/)\xe7\x9a\x84\xe8\xbf\x90\xe8\xa1\x8c\xe6\x97\xb6\xe3\x80\x82

<!-- 
Some telemetry agents rely specifically on Docker Engine tooling. For example, an agent
might run a command such as
[`docker ps`](https://docs.docker.com/engine/reference/commandline/ps/)
or [`docker top`](https://docs.docker.com/engine/reference/commandline/top/) to list
containers and processes or [`docker logs`](https://docs.docker.com/engine/reference/commandline/logs/)
to receive streamed logs. If nodes in your existing cluster use
Docker Engine, and you switch to a different container runtime,
these commands will not work any longer.
-->
\xe4\xb8\x80\xe4\xba\x9b\xe4\xbb\xa3\xe7\x90\x86\xe5\x92\x8c Docker \xe5\xb7\xa5\xe5\x85\xb7\xe7\xb4\xa7\xe5\xaf\x86\xe7\xbb\x91\xe5\xae\x9a\xe3\x80\x82\xe6\xaf\x94\xe5\xa6\x82\xe4\xbb\xa3\xe7\x90\x86\xe4\xbc\x9a\xe7\x94\xa8\xe5\x88\xb0
[`docker ps`](https://docs.docker.com/engine/reference/commandline/ps/)
\xe6\x88\x96 [`docker top`](https://docs.docker.com/engine/reference/commandline/top/)
\xe8\xbf\x99\xe7\xb1\xbb\xe5\x91\xbd\xe4\xbb\xa4\xe6\x9d\xa5\xe5\x88\x97\xe5\x87\xba\xe5\xae\xb9\xe5\x99\xa8\xe5\x92\x8c\xe8\xbf\x9b\xe7\xa8\x8b\xef\xbc\x8c\xe7\x94\xa8
[`docker logs`](https://docs.docker.com/engine/reference/commandline/logs/)
\xe8\xae\xa2\xe9\x98\x85 Docker \xe7\x9a\x84\xe6\x97\xa5\xe5\xbf\x97\xe3\x80\x82
\xe5\xa6\x82\xe6\x9e\x9c\xe7\x8e\xb0\xe6\x9c\x89\xe9\x9b\x86\xe7\xbe\xa4\xe4\xb8\xad\xe7\x9a\x84\xe8\x8a\x82\xe7\x82\xb9\xe4\xbd\xbf\xe7\x94\xa8 Docker Engine\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\x9c\xa8\xe4\xbd\xa0\xe5\x88\x87\xe6\x8d\xa2\xe5\x88\xb0\xe5\x85\xb6\xe5\xae\x83\xe5\xae\xb9\xe5\x99\xa8\xe8\xbf\x90\xe8\xa1\x8c\xe6\x97\xb6\xe7\x9a\x84\xe6\x97\xb6\xe5\x80\x99\xef\xbc\x8c
\xe8\xbf\x99\xe4\xba\x9b\xe5\x91\xbd\xe4\xbb\xa4\xe5\xb0\x86\xe4\xb8\x8d\xe5\x86\x8d\xe8\xb5\xb7\xe4\xbd\x9c\xe7\x94\xa8\xe3\x80\x82

<!-- 
### Identify DaemonSets that depend on Docker Engine {#identify-docker-dependency}
-->
### \xe8\xaf\x86\xe5\x88\xab\xe4\xbe\x9d\xe8\xb5\x96\xe4\xba\x8e Docker Engine \xe7\x9a\x84 DaemonSet {#identify-docker-dependency}

<!-- 
If a pod wants to make calls to the `dockerd` running on the node, the pod must either:

- mount the filesystem containing the Docker daemon's privileged socket, as a
  {{< glossary_tooltip text="volume" term_id="volume" >}}; or
- mount the specific path of the Docker daemon's privileged socket directly, also as a volume.
-->
\xe5\xa6\x82\xe6\x9e\x9c\xe6\x9f\x90 Pod \xe6\x83\xb3\xe8\xb0\x83\xe7\x94\xa8\xe8\xbf\x90\xe8\xa1\x8c\xe5\x9c\xa8\xe8\x8a\x82\xe7\x82\xb9\xe4\xb8\x8a\xe7\x9a\x84 `dockerd`\xef\xbc\x8c\xe8\xaf\xa5 Pod \xe5\xbf\x85\xe9\xa1\xbb\xe6\xbb\xa1\xe8\xb6\xb3\xe4\xbb\xa5\xe4\xb8\x8b\xe4\xb8\xa4\xe4\xb8\xaa\xe6\x9d\xa1\xe4\xbb\xb6\xe4\xb9\x8b\xe4\xb8\x80\xef\xbc\x9a

- \xe5\xb0\x86\xe5\x8c\x85\xe5\x90\xab Docker \xe5\xae\x88\xe6\x8a\xa4\xe8\xbf\x9b\xe7\xa8\x8b\xe7\x89\xb9\xe6\x9d\x83\xe5\xa5\x97\xe6\x8e\xa5\xe5\xad\x97\xe7\x9a\x84\xe6\x96\x87\xe4\xbb\xb6\xe7\xb3\xbb\xe7\xbb\x9f\xe6\x8c\x82\xe8\xbd\xbd\xe4\xb8\xba\xe4\xb8\x80\xe4\xb8\xaa{{< glossary_tooltip text="\xe5\x8d\xb7" term_id="volume" >}}\xef\xbc\x9b\xe6\x88\x96
- \xe7\x9b\xb4\xe6\x8e\xa5\xe4\xbb\xa5\xe5\x8d\xb7\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\xbd\xa2\xe5\xbc\x8f\xe6\x8c\x82\xe8\xbd\xbd Docker \xe5\xae\x88\xe6\x8a\xa4\xe8\xbf\x9b\xe7\xa8\x8b\xe7\x89\xb9\xe6\x9d\x83\xe5\xa5\x97\xe6\x8e\xa5\xe5\xad\x97\xe7\x9a\x84\xe7\x89\xb9\xe5\xae\x9a\xe8\xb7\xaf\xe5\xbe\x84\xe3\x80\x82

<!-- 
For example: on COS images, Docker exposes its Unix domain socket at
`/var/run/docker.sock` This means that the pod spec will include a
`hostPath` volume mount of `/var/run/docker.sock`.
-->
\xe4\xb8\xbe\xe4\xbe\x8b\xe6\x9d\xa5\xe8\xaf\xb4\xef\xbc\x9a\xe5\x9c\xa8 COS \xe9\x95\x9c\xe5\x83\x8f\xe4\xb8\xad\xef\xbc\x8cDocker \xe9\x80\x9a\xe8\xbf\x87 `/var/run/docker.sock` \xe5\xbc\x80\xe6\x94\xbe\xe5\x85\xb6 Unix \xe5\x9f\x9f\xe5\xa5\x97\xe6\x8e\xa5\xe5\xad\x97\xe3\x80\x82
\xe8\xbf\x99\xe6\x84\x8f\xe5\x91\xb3\xe7\x9d\x80 Pod \xe7\x9a\x84\xe8\xa7\x84\xe7\xba\xa6\xe4\xb8\xad\xe9\x9c\x80\xe8\xa6\x81\xe5\x8c\x85\xe5\x90\xab `hostPath` \xe5\x8d\xb7\xe4\xbb\xa5\xe6\x8c\x82\xe8\xbd\xbd `/var/run/docker.sock`\xe3\x80\x82

<!-- 
Here's a sample shell script to find Pods that have a mount directly mapping the
Docker socket. This script outputs the namespace and name of the pod. You can
remove the `grep '/var/run/docker.sock'` to review other mounts.
-->
\xe4\xb8\x8b\xe9\x9d\xa2\xe6\x98\xaf\xe4\xb8\x80\xe4\xb8\xaa shell \xe7\xa4\xba\xe4\xbe\x8b\xe8\x84\x9a\xe6\x9c\xac\xef\xbc\x8c\xe7\x94\xa8\xe4\xba\x8e\xe6\x9f\xa5\xe6\x89\xbe\xe5\x8c\x85\xe5\x90\xab\xe7\x9b\xb4\xe6\x8e\xa5\xe6\x98\xa0\xe5\xb0\x84 Docker \xe5\xa5\x97\xe6\x8e\xa5\xe5\xad\x97\xe7\x9a\x84\xe6\x8c\x82\xe8\xbd\xbd\xe7\x82\xb9\xe7\x9a\x84 Pod\xe3\x80\x82
\xe4\xbd\xa0\xe4\xb9\x9f\xe5\x8f\xaf\xe4\xbb\xa5\xe5\x88\xa0\xe6\x8e\x89 `grep '/var/run/docker.sock'` \xe8\xbf\x99\xe4\xb8\x80\xe4\xbb\xa3\xe7\xa0\x81\xe7\x89\x87\xe6\xae\xb5\xe4\xbb\xa5\xe6\x9f\xa5\xe7\x9c\x8b\xe5\x85\xb6\xe5\xae\x83\xe6\x8c\x82\xe8\xbd\xbd\xe4\xbf\xa1\xe6\x81\xaf\xe3\x80\x82

```bash
kubectl get pods --all-namespaces \
-o=jsonpath='{range .items[*]}{"\n"}{.metadata.namespace}{":\t"}{.metadata.name}{":\t"}{range .spec.volumes[*]}{.hostPath.path}{", "}{end}{end}' \
| sort \
| grep '/var/run/docker.sock'
```

<!-- 
There are alternative ways for a pod to access Docker on the host. For instance, the parent
directory `/var/run` may be mounted instead of the full path (like in [this
example](https://gist.github.com/itaysk/7bc3e56d69c4d72a549286d98fd557dd)).
The script above only detects the most common uses.
-->
{{< note >}}
\xe5\xaf\xb9\xe4\xba\x8e Pod \xe6\x9d\xa5\xe8\xaf\xb4\xef\xbc\x8c\xe8\xae\xbf\xe9\x97\xae\xe5\xae\xbf\xe4\xb8\xbb\xe6\x9c\xba\xe4\xb8\x8a\xe7\x9a\x84 Docker \xe8\xbf\x98\xe6\x9c\x89\xe5\x85\xb6\xe4\xbb\x96\xe6\x96\xb9\xe5\xbc\x8f\xe3\x80\x82
\xe4\xbe\x8b\xe5\xa6\x82\xef\xbc\x8c\xe5\x8f\xaf\xe4\xbb\xa5\xe6\x8c\x82\xe8\xbd\xbd `/var/run` \xe7\x9a\x84\xe7\x88\xb6\xe7\x9b\xae\xe5\xbd\x95\xe8\x80\x8c\xe9\x9d\x9e\xe5\x85\xb6\xe5\xae\x8c\xe6\x95\xb4\xe8\xb7\xaf\xe5\xbe\x84
\xef\xbc\x88\xe5\xb0\xb1\xe5\x83\x8f[\xe8\xbf\x99\xe4\xb8\xaa\xe4\xbe\x8b\xe5\xad\x90](https://gist.github.com/itaysk/7bc3e56d69c4d72a549286d98fd557dd)\xef\xbc\x89\xe3\x80\x82
\xe4\xb8\x8a\xe8\xbf\xb0\xe8\x84\x9a\xe6\x9c\xac\xe5\x8f\xaa\xe6\xa3\x80\xe6\xb5\x8b\xe6\x9c\x80\xe5\xb8\xb8\xe8\xa7\x81\xe7\x9a\x84\xe4\xbd\xbf\xe7\x94\xa8\xe6\x96\xb9\xe5\xbc\x8f\xe3\x80\x82
{{< /note >}}

<!-- 
### Detecting Docker dependency from node agents
-->
### \xe6\xa3\x80\xe6\xb5\x8b\xe8\x8a\x82\xe7\x82\xb9\xe4\xbb\xa3\xe7\x90\x86\xe5\xaf\xb9 Docker \xe7\x9a\x84\xe4\xbe\x9d\xe8\xb5\x96\xe6\x80\xa7 {#detecting-docker-dependency-from-node-agents}

<!-- 
If your cluster nodes are customized and install additional security and
telemetry agents on the node, check with the agent vendor
to verify whether it has any dependency on Docker.
-->
\xe5\x9c\xa8\xe4\xbd\xa0\xe7\x9a\x84\xe9\x9b\x86\xe7\xbe\xa4\xe8\x8a\x82\xe7\x82\xb9\xe8\xa2\xab\xe5\xae\x9a\xe5\x88\xb6\xe3\x80\x81\xe4\xb8\x94\xe5\x9c\xa8\xe5\x90\x84\xe4\xb8\xaa\xe8\x8a\x82\xe7\x82\xb9\xe4\xb8\x8a\xe5\x9d\x87\xe5\xae\x89\xe8\xa3\x85\xe4\xba\x86\xe9\xa2\x9d\xe5\xa4\x96\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\xae\x89\xe5\x85\xa8\xe5\x92\x8c\xe9\x81\xa5\xe6\xb5\x8b\xe4\xbb\xa3\xe7\x90\x86\xe7\x9a\x84\xe5\x9c\xba\xe6\x99\xaf\xe4\xb8\x8b\xef\xbc\x8c

The SignalFx Smart Agent (deprecated) uses several different monitors for Kubernetes including

The `docker-container-stats` monitor is the one affected by dockershim removal.
Do not use the `docker-container-stats` with container runtimes other than Docker Engine.

How to migrate from dockershim-dependent agent:
1. Remove `docker-container-stats` from the list of [configured monitors](https://github.com/signalfx/signalfx-agent/blob/main/docs/monitor-config.md).
   Note, keeping this monitor enabled with non-dockershim runtime will result in incorrect metrics
   being reported when docker is installed on node and no metrics when docker is not installed.
2. [Enable and configure `kubelet-metrics`](https://github.com/signalfx/signalfx-agent/blob/main/docs/monitors/kubelet-metrics.md) monitor.

{{< note >}}
The set of collected metrics will change. Review your alerting rules and dashboards.
{{< /note >}}

The Pod accessing Docker may be named something like:

- `signalfx-agent`
